reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is far slicker and more balanced than that 2013 reboot. Lara’s graduation from naïve punch-bag to confident adventurer opens up her skills as she traverses the ice of the Siberian Mountains, sidling across cliff-sides, using axes to climb sheer faces, firing arrows from her hand-crafted bow to create rope swings. Abilities learned in the first game that are built upon here.

Set one year after the events that began her journey to becoming the ultimate raider of tombs, Lara is now obsessed with completing her late father’s quest to find The Prophet’s Tomb. Despite concerns by her pal Jonah, she embarks on a quest to snowy Siberia, determined to discover the truth about The Prophet before a shadowy military group called Trinity does. It is said that whomever solves the mystery of the Prophet will unlock the secret to immortality.

Believe it or not, that’s the quick version of the plot summary. Throughout the campaign, many secrets and a few well-placed plots twists are revealed, with tons of content on the history of the Prophet delivered by way of audio logs. In the last game every time Lara came across these logs, she would need to stop moving and listen to these entries. Worse, the backstory was not at all compelling. In Rise of the Tomb Raider this function is exactly the same, but the events leading up to finding this quasi-religious leader is engaging. It helps that the voice acting is utterly convincing now.

Siberia itself is a beautiful, hostile and believable setting. Storms whirl, battering Lara as she crunches onward through sheet-white snow; abandoned Russian military outposts sit rusting between peaks. And further down, the snow melts away and forests sprout up, the tribespeople setting up camps and huts between the trees. Despite every inch being meticulously designed with conveniently placed hooks and overhanging tree branches to aid Lara’s clambering, there is a tremendous sense of place. The whistle of the wind and a cinematic flair to framing environments as huge expanses communicate a sense of isolation. One woman against the elements.

Crystal Dynamics put forth a fantastic effort with audio and sound for Rise of the Tomb Raider. When you hear the sound of Lara’s boots crunching against the fresh fallen snow, you’ll be brought right into the game. I could almost feel the bow stretching to its limits by the sound of the string crackling and tightening. This is good audio, people. When the sound design can make you feel the action you’re doing, that’s an A+ in my book. Lara’s voice work is remarkable. She could be brought to life through her dialogue alone.

The gameplay of Rise of the Tomb Raider is reminiscent of the 2013 game which requires the player to control Lara in a third person perspective which features exploring, climbing, stunts, combat and a healthy dose of puzzles. The title also boasts some great quick-time events which flawlessly switch from ingame to an interactive cinema that requires you to push a button or perform an action such as jumping at the right time or attempting to use your pick axe.

Climbing mechanics seem much sturdier then the previous game as you precariously explore dangerous mountains and forgotten cities looking for clues, documents and ancient treasures. So as you jump, climb and hang, the control of Lara is perfect and even the wall scrambles which require you to run up the wall in order to reach a climbing point all work well.

Combat is another element of the game which works well and it’s always a joyous moment when Lara gets her handguns because it pays homage to the original series. So while you shoot and use a variety of different weapons against your enemies, you’ll also need to use the environment to your advantage that may be covering or using something else to destroy your enemies.

There’s a stronger emphasis on stealth this time around, using the environment around Lara to get the edge on her opponents. So for example, in most encounters, at least outside of the guided and highly entertaining cinematic set pieces, enemies won’t know they’re being hunted unless the player makes themselves known. There are trees to climb to avoid detection, shrubs to move through to silently incapacitate foes and various distractions to use to your advantage. There’s even a minimal detection meter that will pop up over enemy heads, but this feels a bit underutilized as it’s just a two state alert (curious and found) and rarely came into play.

As you progress, you are awarded points that can the be used to purchase these skills plus the items you found in the world can also be used to upgrade your weapons and equipment. Apart from the main mission, there are also challenge missions such as exploring a new tomb or using some newly acquired skill to help complete this task. This definitely increases the gameplay.

Crystal Dynamics have effortlessly done the impossible with Rise of the Tomb Raider, crafting a sequel that is superior to their reboot in every single way possible. It’s a bigger, more expansive experience that has a captivating narrative, engrossing gameplay loops and an absolutely stunning presentation.

reviewText:
Lara’s back but she hasn’t changed much since last time, though that’s not necessarily a bad thing
Rise of the Tomb Raider is the follow up to 2013’s Tomb Raider reboot and has recently been released on Steam after a short period of XBOX One exclusivity. RoTR takes place one year after the events of TR2013 and you are of course playing as the character we all know and love, Lara Croft. This time around, Lara has set her sights on something known as the Divine Source, an ancient artefact that her father was trying to locate until his untimely death. While your adventure begins in Syria, the majority of the game takes place in Siberia in an area once controlled by the Soviets. Lara’s interest in the Divine Source has attracted the unwanted attention of an organisation known as Trinity who also wish to find the Source though they want it for different reasons, they are willing to do whatever it takes to get their hands on it. While the story isn’t really RoTR’s main selling point it is an engaging and for the most part well-written story that ties all of the missions together well.

As you’d expect from a recent release, RoTR is an absolutely gorgeous game though you’ll need quite a powerful rig to run it on the higher settings. While the appearance of the game does help make exploration more interesting the game is still enjoyable on lower settings. Personally I was running the game on lowest graphics settings on 1280x720 (my native res is 1920x1080) and while it wasn’t exactly easy on the eye I didn’t find that it took away from my enjoyment of the game. While we’re on the topic of appearances, I’ll briefly mention animations. RoTR is very well animated, as you’d hope, both with lip sync and general movements which really helps the characters feel real and give the player a real sense of just how cold Siberia is and what harsh conditions the characters have to put up with.

RoTR’s gameplay is very similar to TR2013 though there is less of a focus on combat and more of a focus on the exploration side of things. If you’re familiar with TR2013 then you’ll know that the reboots are third person action adventure games with a few puzzles thrown in, if you can really call them puzzles. While RoTR has cut down on combat the gunplay is still a hell of a lot of fun, especially the stealthy portions which make up most of the enemy encounters in the game. You’ve got four different types of weapons at your disposal: the bow & arrow, a rifle, a pistol and a shotgun. While you start out with a bow the other three weapon types are unlocked over the course of the game with a few variations to unlock too. Speaking of unlocks, one of RoTR’s new additions is an item shop where you can buy equipment using the collectible currency in the game. While it can be handy to have the shop available to you it’s not a huge problem if you can’t find enough of the currency to buy what you want as most of what can be bought in the shop can also be found just by playing through the game. As well as this currency there are a few other types of collectibles most of which act as a way to feed you the backstory, such as Russian documents that discuss the layout of the building you find yourself in or even the origins of some of the in-game factions.

One of the other new additions is crafting equipment as well as ammo and bandages. The equipment you can craft is what you’d expect, ammo capacity upgrades though they do require quite a lot of resources which you’ll find by hunting animals as well as keeping an eye out for certain things in the world. You can now craft arrows, both regular and special, as well as use things you find in the environment to craft useful things such as using a bottle of alcohol and a rag to make a Molotov cocktail. Bandages can be crafted in and out of combat, though you’ll probably only need them in combat, and are again made using resources found in the world around you. Of course there’s also weapon upgrades in the game which you again make using resources found in-game and there are quite a few new outfits for Lara which are mainly unlocked by completing certain missions. There are a few other new mechanics introduced in a similar vein to the rope arrows we became acquainted with in TR2013 (which you also get in RoTR) but I won’t talk about them so I don’t spoil them, I will say they’re a lot of fun to use though.

A big part of any Tomb Raider game is obviously the challenge tombs you can play. This is another area in which RoTR is very similar to TR2013, the tombs aren’t hugely challenging and they’re quite short but you do get nice rewards for completing them. Rather than the weapon part rewards in TR2013, RoTR offers players special skills for completing the optional challenge tombs which can’t be unlocked in any other way. The skills aren’t game changing with what they offer the player but they do make it worthwhile completing the tombs if you wouldn’t want to otherwise though the tombs are pretty enjoyable anyway. The similarities continue when you look at the skills available to you when you level up. While there are some new skills related to some of the new gameplay mechanics the majority of the skills are either the same or very similar to those available in TR2013. The skills are still useful of course but it can be a little bit frustrating having to unlock skills Lara learnt an in-world year ago (if you played TR2013). Speaking of skills, a couple of them do feel almost like cheats, such as once which gives you automatic headshots on three enemies when your bow is fully drawn but if you do think that's cheating you can simply avoid unlocking it.

Like I said earlier, RoTR seems to be less focused on combat and more focused on exploration. RoTR gives the players several large areas and a few smaller ones to play around in and these areas can be explored in whatever way you want at whatever pace you want. If you want to you can just rush through the game, only doing the story missions and complete the game in around twelve hours. The game really is meant to be played with you doing at least a little exploration though. It is beneficial to go through the areas doing the tombs, exploring crypts, hunting and finding the strongboxes mainly for the upgrades that these will give you access to, making the later game slightly easier where the enemies are significantly more difficult. If you want to do a 100% completion run through the game you’re obviously going to be spending a lot more time in the game since you’ll have to go back through each and every area but I imagine most players won’t be aiming for this so it’s probably going to be around fifteen hours of gameplay for most players, that’s the main story anyway. There’s also a new game mode to keep you busy called Expedition Mode. Expedition Mode lets you replay story missions while using cards (earned by reaching certain story milestones and can be bought using in-game currency earned in a similar way) to either make the level more challenging or easier. The difficulty factor of the cards contributes to how many points you earn, points can then be compared with your friends for each level with the game’s leaderboards.

Verdict
While Rise of the Tomb Raider doesn’t offer huge improvements over the previous title it does give fans of the reboot more of what they enjoyed. It’s a gorgeous game with great gameplay and while it does require a good PC it can still be enjoyed on lower graphics settings.

Lone Ranger Reviews.

El K.

reviewText:
Compared to the 2013 release, this one is waaaaay better. They have addressed the low count of tombs while keeping each tomb unique with it's puzzles.

Just like the previous tomb raider, it has almost perfect:

- Ratio of combat vs platforming
- Pacing
- Graphics
- Story and Voice acting

Then they added more weapon variety and effects, outfits, stuff to collect, platforming variety, crafting, hunting system, unlocks and upgrades, sensible DLCs.

They also added replay modes to give the game replayability. Only thin I hate is I 100% the game but I have only unlocked 49% of achievements because most of it are on the extra modes

TL;DR everything in the 2013 release, minus the glaring issues, and they raised the quality of every aspect on the game and added some stuff + improvements.

reviewText:
I cannot help to call this reboot of Tomb Raider in 2013 nothing but remarkable.

Do not get confused with my playtime, I already have played this game on Xbox one.

Rise of the graphics:
First of all, this game looks absolutely stunning. This is without doubt one of the best looking games out on the market now. Whether it is the lifelike snow where you can see the miniscule ice crystals, the way the sun rays shine through a massive cave system or the elegant painted on the walls of ancient tombs… It simply is just gorgeous. But also the small details will make you fall in love with this game, like Lara wringing her hair out after taking a swim.

Rise of the gameplay:
Rise of the tomb raider has smooth controls, comparable to the previous title. It plays the same but you have more options now: for the first time you can climb in trees (hello assassin’s creed) and more weapons are available. Especially the bow and arrow feel really good compared to the one in Tomb Raider 2013. By improving previous features and adding new ones, Rise of the Tomb Raider plays like one of the old tomb raiders but still has a pleasant fresh feeling to it.

Rise of the tombs:
In the previous titles, tombs were small caves where you could find some extra ammo or some goodies, or a little experience if you’re lucky. The tomb design in this game is really powerful and makes me wonder why they are optional. They all contain memorable puzzle that will provide variety from all the action. Don’t expect any mind-bending puzzles that force you to look up a guide, but they all are gold-grabbing-finger licking good.

Rise of the conclusion:
Crystal Dynamics created a dazzling exciting adventure which exceeds her predecessors in every aspect. A magnificent action-adventure game with more freedom,  both in exploration and gameplay.

The real Lara has risen!

reviewText:
Rise of The Tomb Raider by Crystal Dynamics
Score 9 / 10 (Solid)

Great news for Lara fans; the PC version of “Rise of the Tomb Raider” delivers a grandiose noggin scratching ancient history conspiracy theory driven plot pitting the multi-generational Croftian zealotry for ‘divine artifacts’  versus the archetypal villains with too much money, power, and religiosity; ‘follie-a-trois’ n’est-ce pas? More importantly, does this game have puzzles?

Present and expected are the improbably improbable puzzles ubiquitous to the Lara universe; I ‘pray’ for these contraptions with secrets hidden beneath massive moveable walls and oversized cogs each controlled through a series of timed switches powered by gravity and water. A little bit of patience always yields a Codex with life changing knowledge (nudge-nudge wink-wink).  Inexplicably these puzzles seem to have been relegated to the “optional side missions”, a direct in-game quote. These are the classic Tomb Raider pieces that I love and I completed them as soon as possible; they always yielded extra XP, gold coins and skills; I wish these puzzling sections had been way longer. What then is ‘central’ to this digital archeological hunt? Read on….

The main plot unfolds wrapped as a “third person shooter”. Feeling a bit shaky are you? Yep, the spelunking has really taken a back seat to the shooter gameplay. There should have been far more dialogue options for negotiations, skillful stealth mode with zero death, and more creative gameplay in the central campaign.  Has Crystal Dynamics made a choice or a mistake? Don’t get me wrong, I love shooters but not this one. Combat with guns in tight spaces and an over the shoulder camera leads to a poor combat experience. Would you like a game with great combat, weapons and well designed arenas? Try Unreal Tournament 3 Black edition instead. Consequently, I found myself  avoiding all main story paths as long as possible because they were so combat unpleasant, and eventually I set the game to the easiest setting to make these encounters as short as possible. What else made the campaign a grind? The controls are ‘tuned’ for parkour platforming; mid combat my character kept putting away the gun and jumping into water or grabbing a ledge; who wants fudge? The default graphics settings use over-the-top screen effects making it uncomfortable: ‘water splashes on the lens’, ‘depth of field’, and others, all of them summing to a ‘digital finger in the eye’. Thank you Crystal Dynamics for letting me turn off all those ‘enhancements’ in the options menu.

Crafting and skill trees were welcome and enjoyable although heavily dependent on hunting. The upgrade mechanics lead to a veritable slaughter-fest: I must have killed over 700 bunny rabbits, 300 deer, 50 wild boars, 10 grizzly bears, and a partridge in a pear tree. In fact I started farming previous maps for humans because they had the specialized parts. The weapon upgrades yielded for the most part palpable advantages in engagements: Would anyone like an RPG arrow head? Woooooo!  The remaining XP system felt hollow and served to redirect you back to previous maps, that is, if you want to find all coin stashes, hidden provisions, caves and relics. Meh. This is just a poor substitute for replayability.

Crystal Dynamics have done superbly well with the extra game modes. I was particularly impressed with “Endurance” mode placing Lara in the Siberian wilderness to see how many days you can survive; requirements to eat, stay warm, collect resources, craft, and collect artifacts improve your chance of survival and reward the players having skill. Many players will enjoy “Score Attack” mode, an arcade version of the campaign. “Replay” game mode allows you to compare yourself to your Steam buddies through point accumulation.

What else should you look forward too?
A visually stunning and sprawling game world. check.
Tons of Steam Achievements. check.
One Special achievement for teaching BBQ chicken to fly. Sweet!
Puzzle deaths: 30 times in a row with a game reload. Blame wonky controls. Rage quit. double check.
‘Collision detection’ that doesn’t know ‘collision’ from a ‘hole in the wall’. triple check.
Excessive grunts, breathing, and expletives in that sublime British accent. Yeah.

Buy this game; all Tomb Raider fans will find something they were looking for and ‘more’. Thumbs up.


My score 9 / 10
10 / exemplary execution of the genre with compelling innovation
9 / exemplary execution of the genre don’t miss out, for fans of the genre and the curious alike
8 / for well done not a must play, fans of the genre and newbs will be happy it is well done
7 / for calibrated expectations only, fans of the genre would not miss out if they skipped this
6 / only for serious fans of the genre for whom game play with bugs is acceptable
5 / enough bugs to make me unhappy

2016.02.17

reviewText:
Just finished Rise of the Tomb Raider. If you want to go in as a clean sheet, you might get spoilered FYI.

+ fewer control loss of player character for repetitive animations/transitions
+ sprinting exists
+ sublime visuals
+ animations are much better
+ visual variation much, much better
+ story much more interesting
+ characters are a vast improvement
+ VO overall much better
+ bigger tombs with unique flair to them, pay-off is worth it this time (special skills)
+ hunting big game is fun
+ enjoyable and fitting additions to Lara's moveset
+ deeper crafting system and thus expanded resource system
+ special ammo and throwable can be crafted on the go which spices up otherwise mundane combat system
+ stealth is serviceable
+ longer, meatier game

- inconsistent performance
- map bugs out frequently
- many useless skills
- despite giving hope at the start, not a globetrotting adventure
- platforming is way too linear, no chance of doing something wrong, it's a one-way street
- free-form jumping, somersaulting needs to come back for the good of platforming sections
- combat lacks fun, melee plain sucks
- acquiring new weapons is tedious and takes too long
- weapon variety is not enough, where is my sniper, rocket launcher, exotic weapon? the ones present are too safe"
- story progression feels too similar to prequel
- many useless collectibles which are not fun to waste hours on
- prehistoric audio-log mechanic makes them a chore to listen

Maybe it's TR13 disappointing me so much and me having little to no expectations for this but I had significantly more fun with RotTR. Story wrapped up faster than I liked just when I finally reached the MacGuffin but it was still OK. I don't like that Trinity is apparently becoming the overarching enemy from now on in the reboot though.
There's a lot of combat
date: just like in the prequel but the new crafting-on-the-go with the nice selection of alt-ammo for every weapon made it better. There's still a lot I want them to change
recommended: add and improve for the sequels. Combat is still nothing noteworthy and that is pretty bad when you have so much of it. Same goes for platforming. It's a glorified QTE system. Expand on the jumping system
hoursPlayed: design the levels so that I can jump

helpfulPercent: not this linear solution. It's not satisfying.\nOverall

reviewText:
1) Essential purchase2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

The John Rambo of Tomb Raider games
With 2013's successful Tomb Raider reboot Crystal Dynamix where finally able to wrestle one of gaming's most recognizable icons from becoming a complete caricature. The last generation saw games evolve past pretty pixels and simple gameplay mechanics as studios set about achieving their cinematic ambitions thanks to the available technology. The upside of all of this is that while trying to beat Hollywood at its own game, game studios and publishers are slowly placing good storytelling at the heart of their games. Audiences are growing up and demanding more mature content while graphics are constantly evolving and pushing the boundaries of realism. Fortunately, or unfortunately depending on which side of the coin you fall, gaming characters now need to appeal to a far more broader demographic than merely just teenage boys. So out with the highly sexualized, top-heavy gymnast who previously enjoyed traversing the snow peaked caps of Nepal in a set of hot-pants and tank top while supporting Mount Boobius on her chest in favor of someone more real and tangible - and flat chested.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623439786
Lara's origin story worked wonders giving us a more real, relatable and well rounded Lara that was not only NOT invincible but bled, cried and groaned. A lot! Where the origin story focused on survival, Rise of the Tomb Raider grapples with the nature of obsession with a head-strong Lara letting her obsession with with her late father's research into the lost city of Kitezh and the promise of a immortality take her down a dangerous path. Her father's partner, Ana, attempts to warn her from following this obsession with Kitezh as this sadly drove him to ruin and eventually suicide. Of course Lara ignores the warning, heading off to Syria to find The Prophets Tomb which supposedly houses the Prophet of Constantinople and hopefully the key to immortality. Of course things are not as simple as that. They really ever are. Hot on her heels, and to make sure she does not succeed with her current mission, are an ancient organisation of knights known as Trinity who have their own dubious reasons for wanting to get their hands on the the divine source.

Rise of the Tomb Raiders plot is a bit more expansive this time around with varied locations that sees Lara traverse from the dusty deserts of Syria to the snow peaked mountains of Siberia and its surrounding forests. Once Kitezh has been located and found an element of the supernatural is included where players will get to explore a hidden world ruled over by a sect known as the Deathless Guardians. Each locale is exquisitely designed with some of the most shiniest and beautiful graphics ever to grace the PC bringing each area to vivid life . Rise of the Tomb Raider is definitely the most downright lovely and detailed game I have ever played on the PC. While my specs where below minimum with regards to the GPU requirements (a 4GB mobile 680M GPU), the game still looked outstandingly good. I can only imagine how beautiful it can or could look with more PC power at the helm. Even with my minimum spec GPU I was able to sustain a relatively good 30FPS throughout most of the adventure. However, for some strange reason cut scenes really caused the frames to tank sometimes even dipping into single digit territory. While this didn't happen too often I did find that the frames tended to fluctuate wildly during cut scenes. Hopefully this is an issue Crystal Dynamix are hard at work trying to solve as it also affects beefier systems.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623682491
When it comes to gameplay, Rise of the Tomb Raider tinkers with very little that made the reboot so successful. Cover mechanics are as solid as they where back in the reboot with skills and perks getting a much needed and more detailed work over. If like me you where blown away by the reboots escape sequences, Rise of the Tomb Raider features a fair few that amplify the action and are simply exhilarating. Often I found myself  needing to catch a breather after each had just taken place. Much like the first one your successful run through each of these gauntlets will be determined by how quick your reflexes are as well as your muscle memory. None of them are particularly long so dying during a sequence thankfully doesn't end up becoming a chore. Rise of the Tomb Raider also features more tombs to raid this time around although they are not as detailed or intricate as the tombs from the past. It appears in this department we are taking baby steps.

While the reboots tombs where laughable at how simple they where, Rise of the Tomb Raider at least has the good graces not to overly dumb them down this time around but still they are not nearly where I was hoping them to be. The original series often struck a fine balance between gun battles and exploring and while exploring now also comes in the form of an open world to discover it would be nice if the next installment gave us tombs that are way more substantial. Gun battles against the game worlds enemies also appears to have been toned down somewhat from the first adventure although the ruthlessness with which Lara dispatches her enemies, I fear she may be in danger of turning into a complete psychopath. I highly recommend setting the game difficulty above normal because normal is just way to easy. Having gone back to play the reboot straight after finishing up the sequel it becomes very apparent, very quickly that Rise of the Tomb Raiders normal difficulty is a bit of a cakewalk. Having never touched the multiplayer portion that came with the reboot I certainly didn't miss it this time around. Instead the game offers up score attack modes for each level you clear that can then be used to challenge your friends. There is even an in-game card system that you slowly unlock through the main games campaign that grants perks and traits which are fully customizable and can be loaded in or out of a level when challenging your friends to beat your high scores.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=617638239
Rise of the Tomb Raider is that sequel that, while not straying too far off the beaten path, offers up everything the reboot did but on a far larger and grander scale. The games core systems have also been refined in positive way, such as the fact that Lara can now actually run, through to crafting and hunting that overall make the game a far more enjoyable one.  There is a lot to interact with here and thankfully the systems don't come across as too simple as the survival element of the reboot did or end up hindering ones enjoyment. With an adventure that is incredibly cinematic, Rise of the Tomb Raider is one of those games that I imagine is just as much fun to watch than play. Thanks to some truly phenomenal facial tech and and excellent voice cast headed by the fantastic Camilla Ludington, Rise of the Tomb Raider easily rises to the top as the consummate AAA blockbuster for 2016 that for the most part nails everything it sets out to do. Lara Croft is once again reborn and I for one eagerly await the release of her next adventure because as it stands, Rise of the Tomb Raider is now my favorite action adventure title. 2016 may still be young but Rise of the Tomb Raider certainly ranks up there with the best of the best. In fact by year end it very may well nab my GOTY for the year.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is an action adventure game developed by Crystal Dynamics and published by Square Enix. This game is the sequel to the 2013 release of Tomb Raider.  Rise of the Tomb Raider was released initially on Xbox in November 2015, but has just been released in January 2016 for PC. It is also due to release on PS4 later in the year.

Fans of the series will probably know what to expect when it comes to Tomb Raider. The reboot in 2013 changed the formula to the original series, and Rise of the Tomb Raider continues with the reboot’s theme. You play as Lara Croft in a third person view and you have to battle through enemies and solve puzzles with a good amount of platforming involved too.  Much like the previous game, there is also a crafting system, allowing you to create medi-packs, upgrades for your weapons, different ammunition along the way as you collect materials.  What I wasn’t too keen on in the previous release was that a lot of the game play was focused on the “all guns blazing” aspect, whereas Rise gives you a lot more option to play stealthily. You can of course go with route one and go gung-ho, but if you want to sit back and plan your attacks meticulously without being spotted, you can do that too.  The weaponry in the game is almost the same as the previous game too; with my favourite returning, Lara’s bow.  There is now the addition of throwing items such as tin cans and Molotov’s at the enemies to either act as a distraction or just for damage.  The platforming has had some interesting additions, such as being able to scramble up walls that are a little too high for Lara’s regular jump. This makes traversing the environments a little bit easier than normal.

I played Rise of the Tomb Raider on 4k, with all of the graphics turned up to max, and sweet baby Jesus this is one gorgeous looking release. The facial animations on every single character are finished to perfection. It is almost like you are sitting straight in front of Lara, so much detail and effort has gone into making everything look just gorgeous! I find myself saying this every couple of weeks, but the animation has seriously blown everything out of the water in my opinion. Not to mention the stellar voice acting throughout the game too, with Camilla Luddington returning to play Lara Croft.

I can’t say that Rise was a very difficult game to complete; there are a lot of puzzles to complete throughout the play through, but none of them are so hard I had to refer to a walkthrough. You simply have to study your surroundings for a second before taking any action. The combat scenes are probably the trickiest part of the game, especially in the later stages of the game when you are pretty much forced into using your bow against hordes of enemies instead of being able to rip them to shreds with your sub machine guns.

Throughout your play through of the game, you will find artefacts in abundance. These upgrade certain skills for Lara when finding them and you can even be rewarded with regular experience points if you choose that talent when you level up. They add a lot of extra plot and lore to the story with a lot of it revolving around a lot of the main characters. You will also find that there are hundreds of items to collect, whether it be scavenging for materials to make an upgrade for a weapon, or finding the collectables, you will never find a section of a level empty with nothing for you to want to explore and find.  A new addition for Rise is side quests. Throughout the game you will find a handful of side missions that you can complete which will reward you with either a new weapon or piece of equipment to help you on your travels. Whilst you can complete the game without any of the rewards, they are simply there as an additional resource for skills and experience.

I finished my play through of Rise in just over 12 hours. Whilst this is still fairly short, it is certainly an improvement over the previous game which only took me about 7 hours to complete.  There are a few additional game modes you can play when finishing the game. You can firstly go back and replay older chapters in order to finish collecting and finding items. You can replay the chapters but on an elite difficulty whilst also keeping all of your equipment and skills from your previous save though.  Score attack, which means trying to complete a chapter as quickly as possible but with a new set of rules in place, such as chaining together different attacks.  This means you can probably get about 20 hours of content out of the game, maybe more if you are really into it.  There is a season pass available for the game which promises a couple things, such as extending the single player experience in the story, and will also add a multiplayer mode.

As I said above, I played the game on 4K with all my settings ramped up to max. I was able to play the game perfectly fine with 60 FPS. The game was installed on an SSD so loading times were almost none existent. I played the game with keyboard and mouse due to the need to be quite precise when it comes to aiming and jumping etc.

The latest release of from the Tomb Raider series really does it self-proud in my opinion. Whilst some may consider this game bad due to the poor sales figures it received when releasing, a lot of that was due to another extremely popular title being released on the same day. Now the game has come to the proper gaming platform, it is truly an experience everyone needs to take for themselves.  The price of £35,99 on Steam is OK. I personally don’t ever tend to buy games for full price but this game was one that I actually pre-purchased just for my love of the series and I am more than happy with my purchase with this game.  As we’ve seen with the last game in the series, it will go on sale fairly quickly, so you may want to wait a few months to get it for at least half off.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY ENDURANCE MODE. READ BELOW.

Rise of the Tomb Raider is better at everything Tomb Raider (2013) did, which was a pretty good game. Rise is as good of an action adventure game of this type I've played. If you're into these types of games, this is one of the best ones, plain and simple.

Some minor complaints are that it starts to narrow to an action oriented game only in the last couple of hours. Throughout the game there is a healthy medium between exploring and combat. The last couple of area's of the game look very cool but basically cannot be explored at all. First of all, there is nothing noteworthy to find in them and secondly you're 'forced' into combat constantly. It's not that the main game lets you avoid combat, but you can engage with it when you are ready for the most part. In the final hours it's all: 'nope, more combat, go!'

It makes sense narratively, but I'd rather they would've come up with a way for it to make sense to still explore and be stealthy if you choose.

The very final hours are combat overload and keep spawning guys against you. It's not the greatest, but unlike most other games, it doesn't feel ridiculous. You are plenty powerful at that point and even playing on the highest difficulty setting I had no problem disposing of everyone. And the combat is fun. So it was still a fun section, just not as good as the rest of the game.

Now as for DLC...

DO NOT ♥♥♥♥ING BUY ENDURANCE MODE. It is a shell of a game mode. Survival? Nope. Here's the thing, it has a Hunger Meter and a Warmth meter. Kind of like Don't Starve. Shoot one deer, loot it, whoop! Hunger is full again. No food preperation, no setting up camp, nothing. There is also no crafting or camp creation. It's just a bunch of fires spread around the map and you can light them for 5 wood. Clothing has zero influence on all of it. You can wear a tanktop if you want. Stand near the fire, it's full again.

All meaningless survival stats. Start the game up, 2 minutes in you have a bunch of wood for fires and you shot a couple deer. Congratiolations! You've beaten Endurance Mode!

Yeah... it's bad. There is nothing to do to actually make survival matter. I was expecting skinning bears for better clothing or having to craft camp fires and build a shelter. Nope, none of that.

Don't. Buy. Endurance. Mode.

It's a waste of 10 bucks.

reviewText:
Lara Croft: Rise of the Murderous Psychopath.

Gameplay:
- Burn people alive, fill their lungs with toxic gas, explode them with grenades.
- Throw them from cliffs, impale them with climbing axes and combat knives.
- Shoot them in the head, legs, arms with bows and create fantastic modern artwork.
- Explore ancient crypts, and then blow the living ♥♥♥♥ out of them. No, really!

Graphics:
- Shoot animals in cold blood to collect their feathers for arrows to shoot more animals.
- Blow up animals with gas cans, molotov cocktails, lanterns, and barrels.
- Make rare creatures extinct, in an effort to collect leather to make bigger pouches for bullets,
which you'll use primarily to make other even more rare creatures extinct.

Sound Design:
- Climb ALL the things! Take screenshots while climbing all the things!
- Fall off ALL of the things! Take screenshots while falling off all of the things!
- Die in increasingly horrific ways like impalation, immolation, evisceration, and other-ations!
Don't forget to take screenshots while dying from things like all of the above!

Multiplayer:
- Buy the Season Pass and play Endurance Mode,
which is better than 95% of Early Access games!
- Get annoyed when next week the leaderboards have all been completely hacked,
but enjoy the gameplay too much to really care much at all about leaderboards!

I rate this game Uncharted 5/The Last Crusade.

GOTY 2016, until Ghost Recon Wildlands releases.

reviewText:
Tomb Raider is slowly but surely becoming one of my favorite game series.
I am fascinated by the fun, the beauty and the great story it tells.
Breathtaking visuals, fantastic music and sounds, The voice acting is great, it is so engaging, so immersive.
A little Uncharted here and there, some Zelda even, I am about a third through and I cannot go slowly enough for fear of it ending too quickly, it is just too too good. I hope they keep making them and making them better.
If you liked the previous Tomb Raider you will love this one, it is an improvement on every aspect.
Smarter deeper tombs and puzzles, more RPG elements, nicer story bigger levels, fun missions. So much replayability.
Just a fantastic title overall. Buy it now, it's worth every penny.

reviewText:
English and Portuguese reviews below.
*English*
In regards of graphical fidelity, it's the most advanced I've ever seen 'till todays day, most people would agree with that. Nothing comes even close, especially in 3D Vision, and the devs keeps adding more stuff like the new ambient occlusion called VXAO, that surpasses the already very good HBAO+, among other things. Gameplay is very enjoyable and it never gets boring, at least I didn't felt bored at any point while playing (some of my friends said it was so good that they rushed to the ending, and the game felt short due to this). Story is the usual hollywood cliche but that's not game breaking, it suits Lara Croft universe pretty well infact. The voiceover is very well done, like in the first of the franchise reboot (2013), and there is a brazilian voiceover option now that's above the standards.

PSA: The engine is a huge step up from the TR 2013, and it's also very GPU heavy, but it has so many options to mess with that even if you don't have a very powerfull highend PC, you still can enjoy the game with a relentless presentation. So there is no excuse to not play the game, unless you are the kind of PC player that buys a GPU at a given time and expects it to run all games at 60FPS maximum settings ad eternum, it's just silly. So don't expect to have top notch graphics with your GPU forever, 'cos that's not how it works. The engine is very flexible, so the player must to be flexible too. In other words: Don't be delusional.

I highly recommend this game for the ones that wants a very good single player gaming experience. Lara Croft has never looked so good.

*Portuguese*

Em relação de fidelidade gráfica, é o mais avançado que eu já vi até o dia de hoje, a maioria das pessoas concordaria com isso. Nada chega perto, especialmente em 3D Vision, e os devs continua a adicionar mais coisas como a nova técnica de oclusão de ambiente chamada VXAO, que ultrapassa o já muito bom HBAO+, dentre outras coisas. A jogabilidade é muito agradável e ela nunca fica chata, pelo menos eu não senti entediado em qualquer ponto durante a jogatina (alguns dos meus amigos disseram que era tão bom que eles rusharam para o final, e o jogo pareceu ser curto devido a isso). História é o habitual clichê de Hollywood, mas isso não estraga o jogo, ele combina com o universo Lara Croft muito bem na verdade. A dublagem é muito bem feita, como no reboot da franquia (TR 2013), e agora há uma opção de dublagem brasileira que é acima dos padrões.

PSA: O motor gráfico é um grande avanço baseado no mesmo motor do TR 2013, e também é muito pesado no lado da  GPU, mas tem tantas opções para mexer nele que, mesmo se você não tem um PC high-end muito potente, você ainda pode desfrutar do jogo com uma apresentação implacável. Portanto, não há desculpa para não jogar o jogo, a menos que você seja do tipo de jogador de PC que compra uma GPU em um determinado momento e espera que ela seja capaz de executar todos os jogos em configurações máximas a 60FPS ad eternum, isso é bobagem. Portanto, não espere ter  gráficos topo de linha com o sua GPU para sempre (como muitos infelizmente pensam), pois não é assim que a coisa funciona. O motor gráfico é muito flexível, de modo que o jogador deve ser flexível também. Em outras palavras: Não seja delirante.

Eu recomendo este jogo para aquele que quer uma experiência single player muito boa no gênero que o jogo se propôe.  Lara Croft nunca esteve tão bem.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider takes a formula used for the original reboot and creates a much cleaner, polished game overall. For fans of the first one, expect a lot more of the same overall gameplay. For those who were wary or had some complaints about the first, ths second installment may have addressed some of those issues.

At the heart, it's still very much an action-adventure ala the Uncharted series. Many of the same mechanics seen in the first TR are still here: wall climbing, upgrades to weapons, stealth kills, etc. However, these systems go somewhat deeper, allowing for a more varied and advanced crafting system, as well as outfits. The various areas of exploration proivde a wealth of materials, and many of the fights have opportunities for multiple solutions, be it straight up brawls, using moltov cocktails, or stealthily moving about. QTE's are kept to a minimum and used mostly in obvious locations. The addition of the Marketplace and Expedition system also add a good deal of replay to the game that fell flat in the first game, unlocking new gear, outfits, and customized challenges to certain areas of the game.

As you explore and fight, the game also has a plethora of hidden areas, tombs, achievement items, and so on. The tombs are more robust this time around, and there seem to be many more of them to go through. While not overly difficult, most of them also provide direct upgrades to your talents and weapons, giving players motivation to solve them. Plus, they are created in beautifully rendered environments that fully immerse players in the game world.

If there are any drawbacks, those graphics are still a bit of an issue. I'm using a somewhat older system with an HD 7750. The game runs, for the most part, fine. The hair effects in particular do not give me the same problems the original did at first. However, there is still noticeable slowdown in areas with large amounts of water effects, as well as the start of most cutscenes, which is frustrating. It's a gorgeous game, to be sure, but without an option to adjust draw distance, it can be quite hefty for lower-end systems.

Overall, I'd say this is a similar step up to the ones the Batman series had after Arkam Asylum: a great game that takes most of the template of the first installment and expands upon it in a largely positive way. They clearly took a lot of the feedback of the first game to heart and did their best to make one of Lara's best games yet. It might not win fans who want strict reliance on the original 1990's games, but I'm having a blast.

reviewText:
Pretty good game for the most part.
Pros:
- Decent story, however it's not executed as well as it could have been.
- The graphics are fantastic, really nice effects, Lara's hair looks awesome with purehair at very high. There's some nice scenic areas that are nearly as nice as witcher 3, nearly.
- There are some nice semi-open areas which are really nice, it's not sandbox though.
- The gameplay as far as tomb raiding is pretty good.

Cons: (Most of these are only a little annoying)
- most of the combat scenes are very linear, with very restricted ways to approach enemies and this can get boring and frustrating when you want to be creative. The distraction techniques only work so well.
- The combat areas are very scripted, often enemies coming from another room, with no possible way to see where Lara is, will know instantly where you are and immediately start firing exactly where you are.
- The AI is both stupid and omnipotent at the same time e.g. I've taken down a whole room of soldiers standing near each other but slightly off from directly in front of each other, just with my bow, and none noticed their friends dropping like flies. Other times you can throw a molotov near an enemy and none of them were looking anywhere to see where you threw it from, but they instantly knew exactly where I was.
- I've found times I've thrown a molotov, then hidden behind a wall, and all the while out of sight then moved to a different area and found the enemy to come straight to where I'm now hiding.
- The combat mechanics are really clunky. you can't block, you can't go crouch or prone unless it's scripted for you too. When near enemies, Lara often stands bolt upright when she should be crouched, there's limited way to move between cover in any stealthy way.
- The stealth mechanics are crap, I'm sorry, they just suck.
- Enemies being able to see through thick smock to shoot accurately at Lara, despite not being able to see them on the other side, and no, they didn't have thermal vision goggles.
- The camera often misbehaves, showing us what it thinks we want to look at. It would be nice to have more control over it, It also doesn't handle well when you move through a doorway whilst aiming a weapon, good luck seeing anyway but the wall.
- Maybe I'm just picky, but the tomb raiding" is too easy and too scripted.
- Want to jump over a knee high barricade? Nope

reviewText:
I'm only 5 hours in and Lara has narrowly escaped at least a 100 avalanches, landslides, collapsing caves, exploding buildings and what not. What the hell? It's like the developers thought unless every 5 minutes Lara slides off a cliff and grabs on to the edge at the last milisecond then players will get bored with the game. Well, they thought wrong, because it's the repetitiveness that is boring. As far as raiding tombs go, every time you think you're about to start exploring some ruins you get attacked by a 100 mercenaries. In this installment Lara being an adventurer/explorer is no longer the central point of the game. Instead exploring has been abandoned for the sake of shooting bad guys. Which in my eyes makes this game a non-Tomb Raider game, especially when tombs are now officially 'optional'. At best this is a third person shooter with Lara Croft.

Pros:
- Good graphics, gorgeous detailed environments.
- Smooth gameplay, smooth controls.

Cons:
- Narrow escape every 5 minutes.
- Horribly written dialogue. The kind that you would see in a mediocre fantasy movie.
- Lara does the dumbest sh*t and is incredibly lucky to be alive at all. She will climb any structure that is obviously about to fall apart. What kind of survival instinct is this? After a few bad decisions you lose any sympathy you had for Lara. She's not brave or wise or skilful anymore, she's just stupid and lucky.
- Like I said before, can't explore anything, have to keep shooting enemies. I suspect this is an effort by the developers to sell Lara to the GTA and Call of Duty crowd.
- Optional tombs are a joke and have no contribution to the story.
- As always some rich a**hole is after the same thing as Lara and has to stalk her relentlessly. Needless to say they have access to better equipment, better transportation, infinite number of mercenaries and so on. How many times do we have to see this story in a TR game/movie?
- Impossible to keep track of Lara's abilities. A new random ability is acquired every 10 seconds, with its own keyboard/mouse combination. And to use these you have to collect a ton of random sh*t and 'craft' things. Who has time for this? I for one don't.
- Native people of Syberia speak perfect English with various accents, including British and American. What?
- Where the hell is Putin when you need him? Trinity is bombing the crap out of Syberia in a modern day Russia and the only resistance they're getting is from Lara and some hillbillies.
- Seriously the plot is BS. It's the kind of story you'd expect to see in a Twilight grade movie. It's extremely hard to get invested in the story. Every cutscene contains at least 10 movie cliches.

Here's something for you to think about. Angel of Darkness is a better game than Rise of the Tomb Raider.

UPDATE (After finishing the game):
I was right, the game is r**arded, the writing is r**arded, Lara... is r**arded. If this was a movie, it would bomb hard. It would have like a rating 4 on imdb or something, max. Up to the very last cutscene they milk every Hollywood movie cliche any movie has ever suffered from. They made Lara the most boring character ever. Not because there's lack of action or anything like that. But because she is so perfect in every way that she comes across as pretentious, condescending and full of herself. At the end I found myself rooting more for the villains than Lara. At least they had a goal and a personal investment. Meanwhile Lara's goal was to show how better than everyone else she is, how noble and kind she is, while at the same time not having a problem killing a thousand people in the process. Thousand is an understatement, by the way. I feel like I killed more people in this game than I have killed in my 2000+ hours of Counter-Strike. In conclusion, I'm not writing off TR completely, but this is probably the last time I will pay to play TR. Also this will probably end up becoming the only TR game that I don't have any interest in replaying.

reviewText:
After finishing the campaign, all the tombs and almost all challenges, I will try to just name a few items that I consider important for the analysis, not detail every aspect of the game.

- The game is a little bigger than the last. I played for 36 hours to end the campaign and 90% of extra content. Dispending 40 hours you can make 100% of the game. Very good, but not consistent with the information of the producers 'would take 35 hours just for the campaign'. I estimate that the campaign can be completed in about 15-20 hours.

- The voice acting is great. Lara's voice with an English accent is beautiful. The sound effects are perfect. The soundtrack is almost imperceptible, with no memorable melodies, and only those ambient sounds, a little disappointing.

- Visually, it is one of the most beautiful games ever created. The optimization is reasonable, and fails in the shadow effects (very demanding and even at maximum quality are pixelated, Skyrim type). In open areas the frame rate drops significantly. The internal areas are much more beautiful, and you will find yourself often admiring every detail and forgetting to play. Lara's movement  is impeccable, interacting with the environment and the situation (cold, fear, danger, stealth, etc). Her modeling is awasome, many polygons and without any square curves"

reviewText:
Rise of The Tomb Raider set the bar high for 2016
Before i talk about anything else i'd just like to note that Rise of The Tomb Raider is currently one of the best looking games out there and has the best facial animations i've ever seen. I'm dead serious. The facial animations are AMAZING.
That's all you gotta know about the graphics. If you're looking for an eye candy then this is it.

Alright. The important" graphics are out of the way so let's talk about the actual game itself.
Rise of The Tomb Raider is the first big triple A title to hit PCs in 2016 and it hit us hard.
The half-arsed
date: unnessecary and unwanted multiplayer got removed and replaced by more fitting Remnant Resistance and Score Attack modes.\nRemnant Resistance is much like contracts mode in Hitman: Absolution. You can pick a level
recommended: create your own challenges with your own terms and then share it with the world...Or you can just try to complete challenges other people have created.\nScore Attack
hoursPlayed: like the title says
voteText:
is a mode where you try to get the best score you can in a singleplayer map/level.

The gameplay is pretty much the same as in the previous game but the setting took a quick 180.
Instead of being on an exotic and mystical island you're now located in a more known place...A place noone really wants to visit - Siberia.
You'll be doing lots of climbing
helpfulPercent: gathering materials for weapon upgrades and healing and you'll unlock new gadgets to progress into different areas. You'll also face another crazy cult. So in that sense Siberia really isn't that different from the previous island...Except there's A LOT of snow and in reality you would freeze to death...\n\nThe last title was all about Lara being an ordinary girl just trying to survive
votesHelpful: adapt and become a warrior. Well she has been through that transformation
votesTotal:
she's more confident in herself now and she's here to hunt and kill. Watch out 'cus she's dangerous!
You're not a scared little girl anymore. This time you'll be facing a crazy cult head on while helping locals to survive. You can even take side-quests from the locals which can turn out to be quite rewarding.
I also have to mention that all characters in RoTTR are very well written. Especially the villains who are just so amazingly done. They're not your typical video game villains. The game actually kind of explains you why the villains are doing what they're doing. It's nice to see villains who actually have reasonable motives.
In most games the villains just kill for the sake of killing.

The gameplay is smooth
votesFunny: graphics are amazing
commentsCount:
voice acting is top notch and i didn't encounter any bugs or glitches during my time in the game so i'd say that Rise of The Tomb Raider is worth your hard earned money.
If you liked the first game then this one should be a no-brainer for you.

Game on!"

reviewText:
Finished the campaign, all the tombs, and collected most of the optional stuffs like the challenges in over 23 hours, but it can take over 30-40hrs to 100% the game.

Great sequel to an already great return of Lara Croft on the 2013 Tomb Raider™ reboot. It's a bigger and a longer game than the first one. The game brings you to various huge and gorgeous environments, filled with (optional) tombs to explore and many treasures/relics to find. The level designs were improved as well from the first game, as the level are usually big and you can choose to stealth or go run and gun into battle where you can use the surroundings to your advantage, such as climbing trees, and crafting things from stuffs you pick up (even new outifts for Lara! Wow!).

The story is just fine, nothing too special, as it also brings you to Lara's dark past as well as the current events of trying to unearth the lost city of Kitezh and she faces a lot of difficulties to get there.
There are more tombs in the game than before and they are optional and you have to find the secret entrance to the tomb, which are usually not that secret anyway. The tombs' design could be better as they could've made better puzzles to solve the tombs and a little increase in the number of tombs wouldn't hurt, as I left unsatisfied after the game finished, as I wanted more tombs to explore.

Pros:
- Great, gorgeous environments
- Well optimized for a stable 60fps experience
- Good balance between combat and platforming
- Great action set pieces throughout the game
- More tombs, new game mechanics
- Great soundtrack and graphics

Cons:
- AI is still a bit weak, even on the higher difficulties
- Story could be better
- Boring collectibles that makes you not want to 100% the game
- A bit too easy, even on higher difficulty

RATING: 9/10, the pros outweigh the cons

Shoutout to my friend, follower, subscriber, and loyal viewer, ajigapar aka ajipagar aka backseat gamer.
#2 Shoutout to my favourite weaboo, friend, follower, subscriber, but not a viewer, Aoi-Chan aka BearDown for One Exam.

reviewText:
More Tombs to explore, More puzzles, better writing, fantastic graphics and it is a blast to play. As a long tim Tomb Raider fan, this game is alot more enjoyable than the last Tomb Raider game from 2013. I thought the last one had cool controls and nice graphics but was missing alot of the aspects that make TR enjoyable for me. I wanted more tombs to adventure in and more puzzles to solve, this game has started that thankfully.

The PC version runs well and looks gorgeous, another good PC version from the guys who did the PC port for Deus Ex HR, the latest Hitman and the latest Thief, all had good PC versions. Thank god they didn't pull an Arkham Knight with this one like WB did last year. This is a very competent PC version that looks good and runs well.

The atmosphere is also well done, really pulling you into the life of a Tomb Raider. I played this on xbox one before, now playing it on PC, I must say they have done a real nice version of this game for PC users. Pretty much a better version of the last Tomb Raider game, with some smaller improvements to bring back some of the feeling of the old TR games. This series is def heading in the right direction, not perfect yet but heading there! Get ready to try and survive the cold winter!

reviewText:
I'm underwhelmed so far. Instead of building upon the strengths of the last Tomb Raider game and pushing this maybe a little further towards Uncharted with its intrepid action, compelling story, challenging puzzles and shooting sequences, they of course had to go a different road the with Rise of the Tomb Raider to appeal to the masses.

It appears that games no longer sell unless they get «openworldified» and filled with boring fetch quests where you need to collect X tons of garbage at some random location and need to help dozens of insignificant NPCs that don’t even get a proper introduction to begin with. This game feels like Assassin’s Creed and Far Cry combined with all their tower climbing, radio-tower-deactivating and animal skinning glory. To add insult to injury, the puzzles in this game have been simplified as much as possible.

The openworldish areas in the game lack credibility like in the last Tomb Raider game. They are filled with zip lines and seem like a show-jumping course in an amusement park. Due to all the nonsense I’m coerced to do or collect in these hubs I’m constantly being reminded that I’m actually playing a video game that ultimately just lacks immersion and builds upon empty time fillers and skinner box mechanisms instead. A lot of times it feels like I’m doing chores instead of having fun.

Of course the game isn’t without strengths. It’s beautiful to look at for example, but the performance is weak even on fast systems. The story feels generic and uninspired, but I’ve seen worse overall. The combat is supposed to have gotten better since the last game, but there is very little challenge in it due to how dumb the AI is, and the clunky controls don't exactly make up for it...

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider which is the sequel of Tomb Raider series is becoming the most attractive and wanted game for mostly it's fascinating dynamic GFX, interesting story and brilliant gameplay. I am impressed with the great story it tells. There is much more adventures than Tomb Raider 2013. It has more than my expectations. This title definitely worth 59.99$ as Tomb Raider worth 19.99$. You can't even guess how much amazing and fabulous is it. Though i completed the story with much time to feel the every moment of this game. I already can say it's gonna be awarded for Game of the Year 2016. Because it deserves something great and massive. Well, now i am gonna share my opinion and experience about this title.

Story
As we have experienced the story of Tomb Raider 2013 which was mind blowing. But i have to say Rise of the Tomb Raider got far better story then ever. It's like reaching Lara's destination to discover divine source and uncover the truth what her father couldn't made it before his death. So it was Lara's destination to know the reason of the death of her father. So still there are so much barricades to stop Lara and find the Divine Source before her. She have to face something terrible with betrayal and conspiracy. So it was quiet attractive to live the story of Lara Croft in Rise of the Tomb Raider. I hope you are not gonna be disappointed.

Graphics Quality
I just stopped to take breathing when i watched the GFX of this game. It's seems so amazing and great. Never saw that sun light effect and skyline in other games. I took more than 100+ snapshots when i was in the top of the mountain. I thought The Witcher 3, Assassin's Creed Unity and Assassin's Creed Syndicate got the most attractive GFX ever. But Rise of the Tomb Raider failed me this time, that just crossed all other renowned games and became the most incredible. Developers really worked hard to polish facial work in this game. I can see they applied few numbers of facial layers on the face to make it more and more realistic. That was quiet more than my expectations for GFX of this title. Finally i got something like my taste.

Pros :
1. Remarkably Optimized Game
2. Stunning Dynamic Graphics Quality (GFX)
3. Adventurous and Brilliant Story
4. Detailed and Fascinating Gameplay
5. Interesting and Useful New Features
6. Enjoyable Combating and Actions

New Features and Gameplay
I found few new features in this one. Like Expedition. Expedition allows us to reply any of the chapters with Score Attack or Chapter Reply or Chapter Reply Elite. We can earn credits by completing their given objectives by replying those chapters. We can upgrade ourselves to reach a bit higher in the leaderboards. Also there is Play Card which we can use through chapters. I also got few new outfits, some of them were gonna be unlocked by progressing on story mode and some of them were gonna be unlocked by completing their given tasks. But i just loving her Leather Jacket and Grey T-Shirt, these two suits her amazingly and She looks so beautiful and innocent. Well, that's what she is, too innocent and determined. There are few more upgrades available for Bow, Pistol, AK-47, Shotgun and Axe. Now i am gonna say about the Grappling Axe which helps us to grapple ledge if we fall from it or if we have to reach somewhere quickly. We can still use Axe to make finisher or melee attack as always. You can choose four types of difficulty in game like Adventurer, Tomb Raider, Survivor. I completed the game on adventurer difficulty because i had to feel it's story amazingly. Not just wanna die again and again for hard difficulty. I got many puzzles to be done to progress story more then Tomb Raider 2013.

Optimization
I have to say this is one of the best optimized games ever. They optimized it so brilliantly. Really loved it. i played this game with Very High settings and 1920X1080 resolution. Everything were maxed out, Even i maxed out Anti-Aliasing for best experience. My FPS crossed 135+ when i reached Syria. But averagely FPS stays between 60-80. My configuration : Intel Core i5 4690K, RAM 8GB DDR3, R9 290 Vapor-X 290 4GB GDDR5 OC Version with S2240L 1080P display. Well that's all happened with me, so don't know about your experience. Just said my opinion about it's brilliant optimization.

Error, Crashes, Bug, Stuttering
Well, my gameplay experience was so smooth as hell, there was no error or crashes like Assassin's Creed Syndicate, no bugs, no stuttering. They made it just remarkable. There was no unexpected shut downs what bothers you the most of all. Just stunning as hell.

My Opinion and Ratings on this masterpiece :
Story : 8/10
Graphics Quality (GFX) : 10/10
Gameplay : 8/10
Optimization : 10/10
Combats and Actions : 8/10
New Features : 9/10
OVERALL : 9.3/10

So i hope you are not gonna be regreted if you have planned to purchase this masterpiece. Remember, Rise of the Tomb Raider worth more than 59.99$. Highly recommending so try it if you can.(CROFT)

reviewText:
Rise Of The Tomb Raider is the sequel to 2013's stellar Reboot hit - Tomb Raider. Once again you take control of Lara Croft in third person as you go about the unknown, discover conspiracy plots and face dangers of nature and man alike. Who can you trust? Who will betray you, and why? These are things you will need to figure out as you play this game.

Unlike the first game, you'll be playing the majority of this game in frozen Siberia, it's cold and Lara is freezing. The conditions are even harsher than the first game. There is more exploration to be had, more caves, more tombs, more secrets... just more of everything in general and that's a good thing. Not only is the campaign bigger, the locales are more open and there is a larger sense of freedom. The levels seem less linear as well, which is great for people to get more creative.

While the 2013 game acted as a pilot to the series, Rise Of The Tomb Raider refines that foundation and builds upon it. It basically sets the bar higher in any imaginable way. Is it classic Tomb Raider? No, but it is a whole outher beast, a force to be reckoned with in the action/adventure genre. As Lara, you'll learn even more than tricks to help you survive in the wild against your foes, you'll continue to collect salvage an upgrade weapons and keep warm near fires but there is plenty of new things as well.

The high octane has been pushed to the 11 in this fluid action/adventure game. Everything has made more accessible from the plot to the graphics, giving the player more clarity to the world around Lara. It's not just all about running and gunning or climbing, the game has a great atmosphere and story and that's one of the many things that make me like it better than the first.

Pros  Amazing graphics
Great storyline told very well with nicely voice acting
Refined game mechanics
The game has alot more tombs and treasures
Diverse locales
Full controller support
Cons  May not have enough differences from the 2013 game besides the locale and upped graphics
Hardcore classic Tomb Raider fans will be unsatisfied
A.I can be a bit clumsy
QTE's turn some people off
Lara's appearance has changed dramatically
Insane DLC... $9.99 for endurance mode just to give you an idea
Final Thoughts:
This is a great continuation of the 2013 Reboot, it's worth the price of admission. It's solid in all areas and lacks very little. It's a blockbuster action title that holds its own against other well-known giants such as Uncharted. The adrenaline pumping heroine is back and ready to plan her next attack.

Rating (9.3 out of 10)

This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

reviewText:
You often hear how AAA games don’t have the kind of pre-production time you’d expect, with projects often going into full production before anyone has a clear idea of what they’re making. Rise of the Tomb Raider feels like one of those games, as most of its story is thin and poorly thought out.

I was excited to play Rise of the Tomb Raider, being a fan not just of the last game, but the series as a whole. With the last game the devs raised the bar, creating a very interesting jumping off point for future installments. Unfortunately they don’t seem to have had any good idea for where the series is supposed to go. What you end up with here is a hodgepodge of ideas from Uncharted and Assassin’s Creed, with most of what happened in the last game completely forgotten.

When you’re in control of Lara, the game feels just as good as the last game. The feeling of climbing, sliding, shooting etc is all very well done, and it’s no problem at all that this basically plays exactly the same as last time. They haven’t run this system into the ground just yet. The way the game is paced feels perfect, with all the different elements getting just enough screen time for maximum effect. In general this feels like a better game to play than the last one, and is a big part of why I enjoyed this game despite the story being disappointing.

You just can’t make the exact same game a second time, wrap a different story around the systems, and expect it to come out the other end in a coherent manner. In Rise of the Tomb Raider I couldn’t buy into the villains, or Lara, or her allies, or the setting, or almost anything that was going on in the story. I liked the ideas on kind of an abstract level. But the way the story plays out is borderline incomprehensible. Events seem to happen out of order, and characters are as thinly developed as it’s possible, with audio logs acting as an emergency measure to add motivation and depth (in a way that does NOT work btw).

In the last game, Lara made sense to me. As the violence escalated, her willingness to go along with it made sense, as she was turning more feral, looking less and less like a normal person. In cutscenes the contrast between her wildness and her companions became more and more extreme. In Rise of the Tomb Raider that Lara seems to be gone. In every scene she seems kind of normal, even in later parts of the game. She doesn’t go through any kind of journey like last time, nor does she seem to have any baggage left from the previous game, which is strange. Much of the her motivation this time is around her father’s legacy, and the things he left undone before his death. Remember that father figure mentor guy from the last game? Because this game didn’t. The more I think about the details in the story, the less it all makes sense. Like doesn’t she love historic artifacts? Then why are many of the challenges designed around destroying them? I didn’t do some of them because it felt like sacrilege. One moment the native villagers directly say to Lara that she’s a friend, just before she goes off and robs their ancient tombs within eyesight of the village. Is she just pulling the wool over their eyes? Is this some allusion to how the British empire managed to spread back in the days? She tricks everyone into thinking she’s a friend, all while robbing them of their historic artifacts and leaving the rest in a pile of dust. The story doesn’t acknowledge this aspect at all.

Part of the appeal of the Tomb Raider series is getting to explore old mysterious ruins in exotic locations. They kind of botched part of that here, as you visit old soviet era factories and interact with locals who somehow all speak English without an accent. One of my favorite moments of Uncharted 2 was when you’re in Tibet and is led by a guide who doesn’t know a word of English. The environments in Rise of the Tomb Raider are very similar, but they for some reason decided that the people of North Asia should just look exactly like the island dwellers in the last game. Feels like they’re wasting the potential of the setting and kind of missing the point of making a game like this. They might as well have set the game in Canada instead if they weren’t interested in presenting other cultures to the player. Instead you get a strange contrast between the ruins & artifacts right next to the supposed descendants of those cultures still living there, not displaying any resemblance to those cultures in any way whatsoever. I’m just guessing this stems from the project being so poorly thought out before they started making it. If they knew in advance where the story was going to take place, they probably wouldn’t have made them like this.

But for all my complaints, I still had a great time playing Rise of the Tomb Raider. The way the exploration and combat feels is about as good as you can get from the genre right now. Just being in the world, looking at it, moving through it, hearing it, are all critical aspects for a game. And this game nails all that. Some of the set pieces feel overindulgent, throwing in more explosions than the story had earned. But when the finale rolled around, the way it built up to a crescendo of everything exploding and falling apart was very nicely done. I was hoping for more, but even so this is an easy recommendation. It’s highly unlikely you’ll have a bad time with this. It just doesn't inspire any confidence that the series will ever top the last one.

Crashes due to Not enough RAM". Since when are 16GB not enough?
The performance of the Game is clearly terrible.

We already know that the developers get cheaper and cheaper and instead of giving us a good performance they just say "buy better equipment".

Bugs:
Already in the first hour of playing this game there have been lot's of bugs.
At one point Lara even had a stone attached to her body
date: which was stuck there for about 15 minutes.\nEven though these small bugs are not very annoying or game breaking
recommended:
they exist and there are not just a few.

The game itself:
There has been alot of recycling in this game. I didn't see any big new features or ideas in this game. Even parts of the design and story have been ripped out of earlier games or even the movies.
Of course people like it when there are things in the game that remembers them of something they know

voteText:
it's just annoying.

The really bad thing about this game though is that they just use the name of the Tomb Raider franchise. It's not really Tomb Raider anymore. Not even Lara's looks are how they used to be.
Lara's background story is messed up as well.
The puzzles are too easy.
The game is too short
The performance is too bad.
All things that used to be way better in the earlier games of the Tomb Raider franchise.
