reviewText:
Tomb Raider series have always been able to find their fans, who were looking forward to a new game. The main character Lara Croft's seeking adventures throughout the world and reveals unknown mysteries, explores tombs and caves.
The series were indeed popular, so there were 2 Tomb Raider movies released in 2001 and 2003. Lara Croft was portrayed by beautiful Angelina Jolie, who was following trails left by her father. To be honest, potential of Tomb Raider franchise could have been used way better. Everything was fine, but not exciting at all. More climbing, more tombs were missing, basically we know Lara Croft in a better light.

Back to videogames. In 2013, Square Enix and Crystal Dynamics took this title into a whole different level. In collaboration with Nvidia they managed to improve the graphical side of the game. They’ve begun with a brand new story. Improved gameplay. We’re getting more detailed Lara. She’s leaving her known Dual Pistols and places more importance on a bow and stealth. Playthrough is way easier with the new Survival Instinct. Tomb Raider was definitely surprising and many of us were looking forward to continuing.

And now, here is the sequel, Rise of the Tomb Raider. It may sound a bit unbelievable, but the developers improved the already amazing graphics from 2013. The game looks insane even on lowest video settings, and Very High is a heaven for screenshoters. Characters look very realistic with sick voices and communication, the environment is breathtaking and you might stop at a view to take a screenshot so many times.

Despite the fact that the game works on the same basics as the previous one, there are few new details making the gameplay more enjoyable. One of the most important news are resources, which can be gathered throughout the world and further used for crafting arrows, equipment, upgrades etc. Of course the ammunition can be picked up directly, but you should barely run out of ammo during combat thanks to the crafting ability.

The story is quite good, although I have to say it takes after a regular FPS. From adventurous Lara Croft seeking for historical artifacts becomes a woman seeking for revenge, anyway, let’s see what the next sequel will bring us. Unlike the first game, there are more optional tombs, some of them are easier, some of them more difficult. In fact if you’re going for 100% game completion, you have to collect all relics, documents, caches and go through every single tomb and cave. Should take about 30 hours of playtime.

Back in Main Menu I recommend trying Extra Game Modes, thanks to which you’re able to replay earlier chapters of the story, or play any mission of your own volition.  The game is enriched by Expedition Cards, which can be bought for credits. Credits are earned for completing challenges, exploring the world or completing Game Modes mentioned above. These Expedition Cards further modify your missions, either they become an advantage or disadvantage and in combination with high difficulty can give you a really hard time.

For current price of 50€ Rise of the Tomb Raider offers an unforgettable gaming experience. If you fell in love with 2013’s Tomb Raider, there is really nothing to wait for. The game will pay off and you’re going to wish it’d never end.

Enjoy the game!
Matezz

reviewText:
This isn't a review as such, I just wanted to give my overall impression of the port for those interested.
My set up:
GTX 970
i7 4790K (OC to 4.2GHz)
8GB Ram
@1080p

Update - With SMAA on and everything else maxed (including triple buffer) the game runs at around 45-60fps (The texture detail appears to also be very demanding. I would recommend playing on High instead of Very High to save about 20 fps, with small differences.)

The game runs at around 40-45 Fps with max setting (except shadows turned off, V-synch set to double instead of triple buffer and msaa at x2 instead of x4 - this includes HBAO+ on and textures on very high etc. This seems to be a good port, but a demanding one all the same. I'd recommended anyone with a lower system than me, or people with a similar set up looking to get 60fps, to turn the hair effects off as I have heard they are demanding. HBAO+ is supposed to also be demanding too. Especially to those with AMD set ups. If you own an AMD system I can't confirm how this game runs with AMD, but Tomb Raider (2013) was pretty well optimised for AMD aswell as NVidia so hopefully this is the case with the sequel too. (Minus all the Gameworks NVidia features).

Overall seems like a solid port. I may update this with an actual review after I've played the game for a few hours.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider.
9/10

So it has finally arrived to PC and it was definitely worth it. I wasn't sure whether i'd get this game or not due to the fact that they made it Xbox exclusive (Timed exclusive, releasing later this year for the PS4) which was a big 'FokkYou' to the fans that played on PC and or PS. It was definitely something i do not support. With many people claiming they wouldn't buy the game because of that. Hopefully the people at Crystal have learned to not do this again.
Anyway.
I love this game, i really do.
But lets get right into the pros and cons.
Pros:
+ Decent story, definitely better than the first game IMO and a very intriguing after credits scene.
+ Fantastic graphics with Lara's hair looking beautiful with Purehair on.
+ Semi open areas, semi big open spaces to explore, not a sandbox/open world though.
+ Actual tombs to raid. But are completely optional. With challenging puzzles from time to time.
+ Improves on everything from the first game.
+ Great gameplay, works great with an Xbox One controller.
+ Crafting adds fun to the game.

Cons:
- Way too easy, played on the second hardest difficulty and died about 5 times from AI.
- Dumb AI
- Even with different weapons and explosives. Combat stays pretty much the same.
- There is stealth in the game, but its awful. Only went stealth once and ended up rushing the last guy.
- Mouse and Keyboard during some puzzles can be troublesome (Played with an Xbox One Controller though)

tl;dr: It's a great game that improves on everything the previous game did. Definitely worth it and i highly encourage anyone to go pick it up now despite its problems which are very minor.
9/10 without a doubt :))

reviewText:
This is a visually stunning story driven adventure that takes everything that was good about the 2013 game and enhances it. Graphically realistic with a smooth PC-port that has a couple of glitches, but great performance overall. The amount of detail in the background and setting is impressive and immersive whilst seamless integration between cutscenes and action really pulls you into the environment. In short, it looks flippin' awesome.

The controls are smoother than before, with even more climbing, jumping and in my case, excessive falling. Combat is reactive, and the bow a viable weapon choice - so much better than previously, with added stealth and distractions like a ton of different types of arrows and explosives. The upgrade and crafting system is relatively simple, but gives a feeling of growing power as you progress and makes it worth hunting down those extra resources. Puzzles are complicated enough to make me feel smart, whilst not so challenging as to leave me frustrated, and there are an absolute ton of collectibles for the trophy hunters. It starts off incredibly linear, but branches out more after the first 60 minutes of gameplay, giving you the option to take on side quests, hunt for collectibles, tackle optional challenges and puzzle tombs, or progress through the main story. Of course, a game like this is always going to be fairly linear overall, but there are enough optional things to make it feel like you have an element of choice and discovery. Oh, and remember those QTE events that were everywhere and annoying as hell? Yeah, they're gone!

The story is decent. It's not breaking any boundaries - but I wouldn't expect it to. It's the origin story of the most famous bad-♥♥♥ adventuring lady in the gaming world, who seems destined to save the world and grab some loot along the way. It's what you would expect, a mix match of legend and history and it works really well. Some of the dialogue and voice acting is top notch, and some of it leaves a lot to be desired, but even when I'm groaning at the lines or yelling at Lara to stop being so dumb it's still a super fun action adventure to play, and that's the important bit.

Overall it's a well crafted balance between story, exploration, brains and action. For me, it's been a thoroughly enjoyable  journey, but hell, if for some reason you hate Lara, you can enjoy the visceral entertainment of even more death scenes, over and over. Enjoy!

reviewText:
EDIT: Reworded most of this review to keep from misunderstandings and to get more in depth.

Honestly feels like a side step or a step back in every direction for this series of Tomb Raider reboots.
Upgrades, combat, navigation, optimization, story writing, set-pieces, etc. None of it is as good as TR2013 or changes without innovation for no reason.

This one was kind of disappointing. I'd like to see where the story is going somewhat, and I'm still kind of miffed Lara's iconic dual pistol thing isn't at least an upgrade in this since it was so perfectly built up in TR2013. I still like Lara's aggressive attitude and how she explains artifact lore.
Why are there two games to establish her starting character arc? That's a little much. A lot much. It is almost as if they made this alongside TR2013 and both are separate reboots. I say that when talking about mechanics and story both.
I can see the dev’ meetings are dry on ideas and hitting on popular tropes and cliche for TV. I see Jonah becoming a love interest immediately in the next game and that kills me inside. No one involved with Trinity is a compelling antagonist at all.

Upgrades are terribly paced, with backtracking and/or grinding to get most of the needed ones or ones that were in TR2013. This includes things such as the grenade launcher, pistol silencer (Now un-toggleable?), and rope ascender. This also ties to the tacked on side-quests, three of which were directly related to the main story, all others were backtracking for certain gear upgrades that you never needed and could pass by on accident as you had to actually go back to know you had these quests available. Weapons were overpowered on every difficulty regardless. Once you get any shotgun you'll go from powerful to being untouchable.
Combat is easy, stealth is too hard to manage but not unreasonable. Throwable/craftable objects added nothing but clutter to the game and made looting and stealth frustrating. Forced backtracking for some of the fun explorable side areas. PC port interface bugs forced me to restart the program several times, specifically I couldn't interact with the game at all once a tutorial prompt for certain skills appeared. Crashed once. Artifact and document side lore was very gripping, but choice in voice actors was limited to maybe two or three and ruined immersion. (Same as the enemy voice actors too.) No interesting music at all.

Runs like Hell on my PC for a few jarring seconds but then is suddenly smooth. This happens when it loads, but it also happens sometimes during set-pieces and every time I change weapons after fast-traveling, plus some others. I don't understand why it runs at 60fps and then suddenly drops to 3 seconds of a single frame. Seems to run more on my CPU than my GPU for reasons I can't begin to understand. This game looks almost live action (Which is impressive) at max settings and when it isn't stuttering. Can't seem to get the performance to be any different from min to max settings. I don't use NVidia hardware at the moment which the game seems to be more made for. It might somehow be my PC, but I really doubt it as I run other games just fine without these issues.

One of the big things to note is the additional content beyond the main game is unnecessarily convoluted. It's not set up very well to start with but then there's a micro-transaction store for other modes, where the fun New Game+ stuff should be. Replaying chapters with Big head mode" and "Bodies sometimes explode when looted" but stuff like that is incentivized to be payed for
date: with a random card pack mechanic on cards that can only be used once.\nThere's also permanent cards which are gear and costumes and there is a way to use the gear that you've collected in the main game for these other modes. This applies to some DLC and stretches somewhat into the costumes. You can still get the main game costumes and the card packs with some good grind time for free
recommended: minus the main game weapon skins.\nThere's some sort of online score attack thing connected to this where you're supposed to compete with your friends on a scoreboard.\nIt's a..."Multiplayer experience" with "Optional" micro-transactions. I usually don't mind this when the game is otherwise perfect
hoursPlayed: but in this title I can't let this slide because it gets in the way.\nThis was a pain to explain and is also a pain to wrap your head around in game
voteText: I probably missed something because there's so many stipulations to it. It feels like it's trying to compromise with both the players and corporate and it does a poor job.\n\nAll in all
helpfulPercent: I feel like I should really like this. A lot of performance
votesHelpful: design
votesTotal: writing

reviewText:
Somewhat disappointed.
Very shortly:

Pros:
- Outstanding gfx
- Very good controls

Cons:
- Story. Compared to previous TR, story is the weakest point. I started very hyped the game, after a few hours I started to notice how repetitive it gets. And story was not gripping enough to keep me enjoying the same actions over and over.
- Too many items. Items everywhere. In every corner.
- Games focus on achievements and completion of finding documents, murales, etc. The rest is a mediocre platform and an easy shooter

If you didn't play the previous TR, buy the previous one.
If you played it, be aware, this is the same thing but with a bad/generic story with update gfx.

You will definitely like it if you have a compulsive collector syndrome and want to collect every loot you can find.
But don't play it expecting a story-rich experience or gameplay variation.

reviewText:
You'll be taking control of Lara Croft yet again as, following her father's notes, she tries to uncover an artifact that is said to grant eternal life: things soon take a turn for the worse and what started as an expedition becomes a fight for survival.
Rise of the Tomb Raider doesn't stray too far from its 2013's predecessor and is more of a refinement than an overhaul but its great graphics, good puzzles and satisfying combat makes it an excellent game despite a few niggling problems.

PROS:

-great graphics and cinematic feel

-excellent sound design and soundtrack

-overall good story

-Lara Croft is still a memorable character, she's well defined, more set in her ways than she was in the previous game and ultimately a very effective and believable fighter: other characters- villains included- are done well and have enough depth to be interesting

-ambiental puzzles are quite good and will require some thought to solve

-extra tombs and crypts to solve and explore are truly good side activities with interesting rewards

-the world is segmented into areas but it still quite expansive and contains quite a few collectables/ secret areas to make exploration a worthwhile endeavor

-a good amount of stuff to craft both as consumables (special arrows, grenades, molotovs ect) and permanent upgrades (weapon upgrades, better satchels to improve carrying capaciting, special outfits)

-decent character progression thanks to three different skill trees

-great length, a 100% clear game on Survivor took me 22 hours

NEUTRAL:

-even on Survivor difficulty the game isn't too challenging if you stick to stealth and make liberal use of craftables

CONS:

-despite being good the story can't get past many cliches common to the genre

-it's sometimes a bit too easy to fall off a ledge or miss a jump even if properly aligned

-some forced combat situations can be a bit annoying and somewhat out of place

-enemy AI isn't especially bright

-a few bugs here and there (map not appearing correctly, a couple achievements unlocking before their conditions are met etc)

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=611623244

Rise of the Tomb Raider is truly a great action ride from start to finish, you'll be crossing several different environments going from snowy mountains, rolling hills, long lost cities, tombs and more all while solving puzzles and fighting enemies to progress: the overall gameplay doesn't stray too much from this formula but the different levels and enemies paired with the optional tombs/ crypts/ caves keep things fresh. I personally enjoyed going off the set path hunting animals for exp and crafting materials or simply looking for collectibles and caches: most actions and kills will reward you with exp that you can then spend on one of the three skill trees helping you tailor Lara to your chosen playstyle.

A few downsides are enemy AI which is ok on Survivor but still somewhat exploitable, a few bugs (the one making the map appear blank being the most annoying) and a few glitches with jumping or using your grappling tools: all the issues are easy to forgive though as they don't impact gameplay too much and even a bad jump will see you back at a checkpoint very near your starting position.

While you won't find an huge amount of innnovation in it the game is an absolute blast to play and will provide you with a lengthy, enjoyable experience through its story mode and (for those so inclined) through its score attack mode and DLC. I personally enjoyed every minute I've spent in it and heartily recommend it.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider - 10/10
I might even give it 11/10 for me personally. I have not gotten so absorbed into a game for a long time.
I immediately started to collect all of the collectibles in the zones as I started and really enjoyed running through the open world to find all these items and figure out how to get to some of them. The beautiful environment and the stunning graphics reallly helped in that regard as well.

For gameplay I felt the game had everything. A wide array of different arrows like poison arrows for those nasty guys with shields, fire arrows for either objects or your enemies, even explosive arrows to bring down a group of enemies! There were 4 different weapons (bow, pistol, rifle and shotgun) with several different choices for each one. All weapons had lots of upgrades as well, which made collecting resources in order to upgrade them quite fun.
Leaping from trees and roof tops to assassinate targets, or doing a stealth kill from a bush felt really awesome, reminded me quite a lot of Assassins Creed. :p  And the stealth in general was really good. Could distract enemies with bottles and things to help you in that regard.

The exploration and platforming had quite a lot of variety as well how to reach items and places. You start off with the basic climbing axes, then get rope arrows, climbing arrows and some other stuff. And you unlock them at different points in the story, which makes exploration and collecting feel sort of fresh throughout the game as you get that new stuff.
The puzzles in Tombs and other places wasn't very hard, but I guess that is a preference how hard you want that to be. So even if they were not terribly hard on their own, I think there is plenty of those small puzzles or places you have to stop and think about how to proceed to keep it interesting.

The story was great and kept me interested throughout the game and the ending did not disappoint either. Plenty of documents that tell the story from different peoples perspectives, from different sides and from different times. So you gather small pieces of clues all over that adds to the mystery.

I think I spent 50+ hours before I completed the story, but that was with doing 100% completion in all zones (besides the last one I have a few things left) and doing every achivement I could.
Also has Score Attack and Endurance mode (Endurance is from DLC) to keep you busy as well. So now I just need to pick up the last achivements I got in story mode, then I need to get all the achivements from Endurance and Score Attack, which means getting Gold Medals on all levels.. so should be very many hours of game time left for me.  :)

reviewText: Rise of the Tomb Raider's opening is pretty great. It starts out with a tutorial in Siberia to teach you the basic navigation controls, then you're moved into a beautiful green landscape with a decently large tomb with a few puzzles, a few texts to read, and a few artifacts to nab. For these brief moments, the game feels like they really did listen to peoples' comments about the first game, and were actually working to make the game feel more in line with the original games. Then the first of many explosions kicks off, and you realize that isn't the case.\n\nThe primary theme of Tomb Raider 2013 was survival, and in that sense the primary theme for this game is also survival" because Rise of the Tomb Raider is essentially just a rehash of a reboot. It brings back all the obligatory cookie cutter modern survival game mechanics; you'll hunt a few deer

Having played Lara Croft since The Last Revelation, this game is a hugely satisfying one for me. The Tombs are back, the combat and the exploration mechanics gel fluidly. reviewText:
Let’s get right down to it, Rise of the Tomb Raider (RoTR) is undoubtedly a gorgeous game, graphically pushing the envelope offering richly detailed environments, quality character animations & visual effects. Everything you look at is superbly crafted together, from the camera direction, animal animations to the smallest plants or rocks. This really brings the locations to life. Going hand-in-hand with this is the competent narrative that is always well voiced & engaging cut-scenes from the main story arc that seamlessly bend into the gameplay. RoTR's well-polished presentation is an entertaining experience.

Yet by the end of my play through, there were some elements of the game I found disappointing; such as, finding the plot a bit predictable after the main reveal or that there was some grindy gameplay mechanics.

One of the big things I was looking forward to in this sequel was the 'Return to Tomb Raiding' with bigger & better tombs. The nine optional tombs on offer in RoTR had some crafty puzzles, but regrettably they are relatively short & quick to complete. They primarily centre on an entrance/discovery section followed by a main room with a short series of puzzle steps to get to your prize. Not as elaborate or engaging as I was hoping for.

The same can be said for the open world exploration sections where I found most easy to figure out how to navigate around or find hidden locations. There were a few tricky bits that took me some time to find, but overall not too difficult to progress. Everything you need is always put right where you need it, and shown on the map so you rarely need to actually hunt around for much. There are some open sections such as Soviet Installation or Geothermal Valley where you have some freedom to do missions or challenges, and go Easter Egg hunting, ahem, farming to upgrade your kit, but much of the game levels are more linear or scripted in nature.

I did get the feeling there was less combat in this verses the first reboot, which I prefer, but would have liked to see more mission/tomb/challenge content instead of the massive amount of collectibles (murals, strongbox, documents, coin cache etc.) you need to track down if you want to 100% complete the game. Hunting & gathering is also required for some crafting, so you get lots to do, but does become a bit mundane after a while. Much of this is optional content so can be avoided though if you just want to progress the story.

As with the previous instalment the controls are forgiving and controlling Lara's wide range of abilities is intuitive. It’s situational based so it’s easy to traverse a cliff face or square off in a gun fight. The further you progress the game will add more moves, weapons & abilities. Some are useful like larger storage space, but others like show all traps do make an easy game even easier.

The AI ‘Henchmen’ are not the brightest bunch still (not sure if they improve on hardest difficulty or just are tougher to take down). Seem to be prone to line of sight issues allowing Lara to get away with a lot before being discovered, and in combat tend to follow the same attack patterns, making most fights feel fairly generic. Although there is stealth Lara can deploy in most locations to varying degrees, I would have liked to see better utilisation. There are also places that it seems you cannot avoid a fight using stealth.

Multiplayer has been dropped in this sequel, but a new replayable system has been introduced called Expeditions. These have various challenges like Score Attack & Chapter Replay. Each challenge can be modified with up to five Expedition Cards. Cards are unlocked by playing the campaign, coins can be converted into card packs & also cards are unlocked in Expedition mode itself. Cards can offer all manner of buffs/debuffs to change up your gameplay, from Big Head mode, to weapons/gear, to other game mechanic modifiers. Certainly more appealing than multiplayer was to me, but I am not sure how many times I would find replaying the same levels fun. Regardless, for those wanting further replayability it a nice addition.

RoTR ticks a lot of the right boxes that kept me wanting to play it through to the end, it’s an enjoyable ride for the most but over time the lack of challenge & overall casual nature of the game mechanics and level design left me feeling it was a bit lacklustre. Story was a tad predictable, linear, puzzle tombs were a bit of a letdown & collectibles system is a little excessive. Still .. I find myself recommending RoTR. I had a lot of fun in my play through, entertaining, despite some dislikes in the gameplay department it is one slick action-adventure game.


If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow True Blue Reviews for more recommendations!

reviewText:
Runs as smooth as butter for me but some others aren't which is baffling. I ran the game in 1920x1080 at the big open areas (most complained screen spec), NO FRAMERATE DROPS, up the settings to higher resolutions and a bit of frame sacrifice but barely noticeable and this includes the soviet area. The game absolutely runs fine for me

As for the game itself? More Tomb Raider but more emphasis on crafting and better graphics along with so much better improvements. I dig the hunting, the graphics and the gameplay so far and it reminds me of uncharted although not at the same level.

*Note also wtf is happening to steam thumbs lol, all the positives are getting low scores? Who in the world is just downvoting everyone? The system is now completely broken and everyone should pound at steam to fix it up.

Video review
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=plpwSPVKQKk

Pros
+ Mostly improved version of the same formula but better, bigger and more exciting.

+ Great storyline and flow of story.

+ Great sound effects from environments adding immersion, voice acting and music also well done.

+ Graphics and attention to detail, from Lara's wound, blood and sweat to even the snow sticking to her hair, deer leaving blood trails when shot etc The little details are surprising and those small animations you can catch her doing such as swimming out on water and wringing her hair out.

+ Environments from desert, to snow and more snow and dangerous caves and ancient tombs galore
+ Everything crumbling around Lara (Reminds me of Uncharted) but not above that level but still good.
+ Good amount of open areas with hidden tombs and caves to explore and items to find.


+ Emphasis on the crafting system in this game to upgrade items, weapons and skills.

+ Bonus tombs for upgrading skills which is worth if for more efficient killing

Cons
- Difficulty scaling, even on the hardest difficulty it was still a bit easy but you can only heal via herbs
and harvested materials.

- Fxaa film grain setting is very ugly, only performance problem is when I set SSAA x 4 on which of course impact performance but SSAA x2 works fine for me

- Optimization problems for folks

- Specs can be quite heft for those who ran tomb raider before and expect the same, it isn't and the requirements are much higher.

- Spamming survivor vision can be quite tedious because it can only be used while standing still to know what can be interacted with.

- Some guns could use better sound effects and handling it felt a bit weak at first but improves later on as you upgrade them but you'll find other guns which makes the other one feels a bit obselete even upgraded fully so you never go back.

- Lara changing her looks again  (Got use to it this is a preference but still, I perfer 2013 Lara)

- Expedition is the only replayability in the game, running through the maps you've done already to see who scored the highest points no other multiplayer options, replayability is low.

reviewText:
First of all, the main reason i am buying any Tomb Raider game, is because of my daughter, who is a big fan of Lara Croft. We have great time together playing this game.
The game looks great, feels great and the gameplay is somehow rewarding even if a Swan Dive has no tutorial and nobody on internet knows how to perform one. I totaly recommend buying it and playing it.

I do have some critics to make about this one though:
1. Being unable to loot weapons from enemies. You have a chance to get 2 pistols so you can fight a bear, but instead you go into the fight with a bow, armed with some arrows poisoned with mushrooms that you do not know if will have any effect. She clearly knows how to handle a pistol, previously she had one with infinite ammo in Syria. But let's all jump with joy when we find part 1/4 of a pistol in an ancient tomb.
2. In game micro transactions: You can flip some cards that can give you some changes when you try to replay the levels . A Challenge, a perk, an outfit. Normaly you can buy the pack of cards using the credits you get in game, or you can pay 2euro to buy a pack. Very unnecessary feature. (to be ignored)
3. Day 1 DLCs and season pass: 3 outfits (3 euro each), 1 extra mission with a Baba Yaga that costs 10 euro and will take 1h or so to finish. (to be ignored)  But look, they have a 10% discount, so clearly they are not greedy.
4. No game+ mode, once you have finished the main story, you can return to the areas to find rest of collectable items and eventualy unlock some outfits, but there is no point in having that because when you start a new game everything resets. (You can use your character progress in the Expeditions.)
5. Steam Community manager with 91 games on her list and zero played time. That explains why this game was launched in the same day as Fallout 4 before the PC Launch. Some people are just not into gaming.

I will not go in depth with the story and the clichees and the absurdities, this is still fictional character with fictional story and i did have a laugh at some of the finds.

Despite all the aspects mentioned, i still recommend this game. I feel that those that are working in the development team did a brilliant job and deserve 11/10 for their work. I recommend they take some time off to play Witcher 3 and get inspired for next Tomb Raider. And maybe some Dying Light. You get the point :)

reviewText:
This game is awesome in so many way:

- Great, consistent story. It feels like a playable movie at times (in a good way), but the cinematic aspect does not overshadow gameplay. It's pretty much a perfect balance.

- Superb graphics. And I'm not just talking textures, particles, lighting, and shadows. The facial expressions Lara and others give while talking are hands down amazing. The way Lara's hair blows in the wind, or just jiggles ever so slightly as she talks blows me away. It's almost to the point where I can forget that these characters are nothing more than CGI. Futhermore, the way snow gives way at your feet and your legs leave dents, it's remarkable!

- Fast paced gameplay with respect to exploration, combat, and puzzles. It's really wonderfully paced all around.

- The amount of content is spot on. There is plenty to do: side quests, resource gathering, crafting, hidden tomb exploration, etc. Also, to expand a bit on tomb exploration, unlike Tomb Raider 2013, there are A) more tombs, and B) the rewards are MUCH more lucrative; so much so that it is worth finding and exploring every tomb you can.

reviewText:
Rambo Croft is back. Why did Crystal Dynamics turn Lara into a total pshycopath? She is a killing machine more than an adventurer now and I think it is entirely the wrong direction for the character and games.

Tomb Raider Anniversary will remain my favourite because it was a remake of the first and both were mainly about solving puszzles in tombs - a lone character exploring the mysterious unknown, not some Hollywood style action fest.

Still, like the Tomb Raider reboot, this is a fun game to play.  The mechanics are great.

The graphics this time around are impressive but not enough of an improvement over the last game to justify such steep system requirements. And the last game had amazing stereoscopic 3d, which this one lacks.

Some of the supernatural elements of the story feel like a copy paste of the last game, which is a bit dissapointing.

I debated whether to vote yes or no on this game and decided on no because of it's price. The campaign just doesn't feel long enough and the ending is stilted and rushed. At half this price, it would be a definate yes - at the current price I suggest that interested players that haven't jumped in yet hold off.

reviewText:
After the impressive revival of the Tomb Raider franchise in 2013, I had high hopes for this installment. It certainly doesn't disappoint. Rise of the Tomb Raider improves in most, if not all, of the areas that players wanted improvement from Tomb Raider (2013) including more actual tombs! I'll get to that in a bit.

PROS

- Beautiful environments. Graphics were really good generally.

- Voice acting was good, It definitely helps the game.

- The story, overall, is immersive and enjoyable.

- Side quests are a welcome addition that add a bit more length to the game and include some interesting rewards

- Tombs are definitely improved on the 2013 version, there are more of them and they're suitably challenging.

- Character progession offers choice to players. 3 different skill trees with a wide variety of skills that will help personalise your playing experience and augment your play style.

- Plenty of collectibles for people like myself who like that kind of thing. It provides a great reason to explore more of the world as well, which is well worth doing. It's not open world, but it's still fairly expansive in some areas.

- Level design, especially toward the latter stages, is very impressive.

NEUTRAL

- I personally found key bindings on keyboard to be a little awkward, you'll probably want to rebind them.

- The story, although really enjoyable overall, gets a bit cliche toward the end and I found myself beginning to pick holes in it, which ruined the immersion somewhat.

CONS

- Enemy AI just isn't that bright at times.

- Controls when playing with a mouse and keyboard seem a little clumsy. Sometimes you'll randomly miss zip wires and jumps for no reason. I feel like this is a product of the game being exclusive to Xbox initially.

- Definitely some bugs around. I found one type of craftable explosive to be paticularly buggy. As one example, n the final boss battle, it exploded next to the boss, who then just disappeared through the floor meaning I had to reload.

Intensity the video game! The game is great, The upgrade system encourage you to play, just to see how the gameplay with change with the perks. The story? I was drowned out by the action, couldnt play too much attention to the story because i wanted to continue the thrill ride.

This thrill ride will come to a halt when you decided to do side stuff like hunt and explore more, which will slow down the pace a but. When youre done doing that, the thrill ride continues. The combat is super satisfying and will leave you wanting more.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is the sequel to the reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise that launched 2 years ago. ROTTR takes what was awesome about the first game and gives it a complete upgrade while introducing new mechanics to make it feel like a sequel. I'll go into a little more detail down below.

Pros:

More of a survival orientated game.

Wildlife  are more of threat than ever now. Be careful where you tread.

Crafting is now introduced, allowing you to craft special ammunition with resources you have gathered throughout the enviroment - great incentive to explore and gather what you can.

Cut scenes, motion capture and voice acting are some of the best I've ever seen in a game

Big effort went into the level design, levels are beautiful with great variation. From the cold, icy Siberia to the deserts of Syria.

Graphics are really big step up. Definately a treat to look at if you have a higher end setup.

Quite a few new mechanics are introduced giving multiple new ways to engage enemies as well as adding replay value.

Tombs and puzzles are definately more challenging than the 2013 reboot and require a bit more thought, but they are not nearly as difficult as some of the earlier games.

Story is great. There is always that feeling that you want to see what happens around the next corner.

New characters definately add to the Tomb Raider universe while giving great possibilities for a sequel

Cons:

Overpriced DLC. The DLC for this game is really over priced. Pick the extra content up on a sale if you really want to try it out.

AI can act in strange ways sometimes.

Anti aliasing isn't that great.



Overall a great game, definately pick it up if you are a fan of the franchise. While not a true Tomb Raider game, it is still a worthy sequel

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is a sequel to the 2013 reboot Tomb Raider. In this game you can see that our beloved protagonist Lara Croft has evolved from a fragile survivor into a seasoned raider (which is coincidentally the difficulty in which I completed my playthrough).


What I loved most :D

What I truly love about this game is how lifelike Lara is. Lip movement and facial expressions are spot on. Couple those with the great voice acting of Camilla Luddington and you got yourself a very believable character. This allows the player to really feel Lara's emotions as she is forced to face all kinds of difficult situations and attempt to overcome them.
Those seamless cutscenes that blend nicely with the storytelling. No wonder the description on Steam includes the phrase cinematic survival action adventure".
I also loved how the environment affects Lara and vice versa. Snow accumulates on her jacket and hair. Her breath is visible in the cold and she shivers. She gets blood and wounds on her skin after a nasty fight with a beast or human foes. Lara makes footprints in the snow. Her clothes gets dirty over time but you can always change to clean ones at camps.


What I liked :)

Additions to types of upgrades from the previous game for weapons and skills. It's quite satisfying to acquire a skill and using it like performing a jumping kill from above.
More tombs! It's Tomb Raider after all

And they actually look well-designed and practical (who wears a tanktop and shorts for climbing in the icy cold?) or just cool like those ancient outfits.\nCombat can be intense especially with a bear

Side missions/challenges which I felt more compelled to do rather than willingly. If I want to do a side mission

reviewText:
I've played all the Tomb Raiders since the original on PS1 way back when I was a kid. So as a  TR game I really enjoyed this game a lot! It has the feel and the exploration and platforming of a TR game that I love.
The graphics are spectacular with great effects and immersive beautiful environments everywhere! Its really very very well done visually.

What I didn't like though is the difficulty of the game. I played it on the hardest difficulty and it was far to easy! Compared to the last game the combat was just a cakewalk. In fact it was so easy to headsshot every enemy that I  NEVER even saw the close combat dodge/quick kill mechanic till the VERY END OF THE GAME when the final boss fight forced you into it as part of the battle. Because of this I had no idea wtf to do LOL like seriously I had no idea wtf was going on since I never saw that screen the ENTIRE game due to the enemies being so easy to headshot with the bow. Even when the enemies get armor and helmets its still a cakewalk.
I remember when they introduced the harder enemies/mercenaries. They play a small clip where they walk out and look all badass.....2 poison arrows later they are dead.... I seriously thought I was being trolled it was so easy.
You will not run out of ammo unless you try to waste it and run out.
Now Im not saying combat isn't fun, cause it is fun...but It just isn't satisfying when you see a room setup for you to use all these perches and such to take out enemies but there is no point in doing all that when you can end a fight in 5 seconds against 10-20 enemies so easily.

The previous games combat was MUCH more satisfying and felt like you earned every victory in battle. People complained so much about the combat that the devs dumbed it down tremendously in this new game. To me I would rather just play a game without the combat if its going to be this easy...just Saying.
Either make a TR game with proper combat or just make a TR game without it entirely next time.

Overall the game is WORTH playing 100%. Just be prepared for easy peezy fights if you are the least bit skilled at shooting games at all!

Also I didn't bother with the endurance or survival modes or whatever they are called. To me that stuff is just hamfisted attempts at making the microtransaction valid.

reviewText:
TL;DR: bad writing, poor QA

I wish I could tick the yes button, but at least at the time of writing, I can't really do it. I just got the credits, and the steam time counter says 15 hours. In the beginning I did a lot of collecting, but after about the half way point I couldn't really be bothered, so take the length of the game as you will.

Main reason I can't say yes to the recommendation is the writing.
From start to finish I couldn't really care less about the situation Lara was in, who she was fighting and what she was doing.
They did a really poor job of introducing the situation and giving you reasonsto be engaged in the story. Which was nearly opposite in the first game. You wanted to find your friends and know what was going on, it was mysterious in a very good way.
In this one, you're just told Trinity are the bad guys, they're really bad, and your father knew something so you should know it too.

The second main part is the feel of the platforming. Lara seems to constantly jump whereever she feels like, quite often to her death. Which really drags the game down since you feel frustrated at the technical aspect of playing the game, and not a challenge in the game itself. (counter point would be the Rocksteady Batman games, which usually feel really fluid and in control)
Admittedly I did play with a keyboard and mouse, which could be part of the problem. Not having an analog direction to push to might cause issues for the game to know what to do.

I was such a fan of the first game that this feels like a major step down, which is a shame.
If you can get it for half price or some such at a sale, I'd say it'd be worth it just to fool around and shoot bad guys, and to see what little there is of the story.
One example is that at the end credits, the writing team was shoved pretty much at the end.
When the User Interface Art  people are before the writers, you have some serious issues to deal with in terms of priority.

Which brings us finally to Do I wish for another game?" If they could just give the writing team more time
date:
or whatever they need to make it a good game. Then yes. I definitely would like to see Lara have some proper adventures again.

reviewText:
Some people will like this game a lot. Others, like me, won't.

Sensationally, this game is extremely well done. The visuals are beautiful in a realistic sort of way, animations are mostly smooth and life-like, and the sound/music complements the adventure-outside-of-civilization really well. The exception to all of those rules is the gunplay. Shooting a bow feels great. Shooting a gun feels lightweight and flat, and the gunfire sound effects are nowhere even close to realistic.

Now, for the material shortcomings. The game is dumb. It's stupid, and it wants to believe you are, too. Lara will literally tell you what she needs to do to get through a puzzle. The region's natives speak in that pseudo-Queen's-English that Hollywood swears sounds sophisticated, even though these natives have lived in isolation in the Siberian mountains for thousands of years. Every character over pronounces every word and avoids contractions like leprosy in that way that the worst Sci Fi movies try to make characters sound noble. We must not fail!" says the military grunt from the US
recommended: or We can't lose!" or something else more natural-sounding. Good guys are unflinchingly righteous
hoursPlayed: virtuous and self-sacrificial. Bad guys are unflinchingly selfish
voteText: short-sighted and viscious.\n\nAll of that amounts to a story/game that's not fooling anyone. Lara's character is a piece of baloney that couldn't possibly exist in real life. Even if she did
helpfulPercent: she'd be someone you'd want to tell to crawl out of her own ♥♥♥ as soon as she's able. The same goes for the villains. Puzzles aren't puzzles in Rise--they're scripted adventure setpieces. Platforming is the same. Follow the onscreen prompt and look for the inexplicably white edges or the bafflingly placed ziplines (in the middle of a Siberian mountain range!) and press either "A" or "X" to use the appropriate contextual animation trigger.\n\nI'd recommend this game if you were someone looking for setpieces

This is a fully upgraded, updated, Tomb Raider 2013, so if you enjoyed that, then this will not disapoint, the detail is thru the roof, eye color, teeth, emotion, and I'm playing on a 1gb gfx amd r7, avg. fps 52, play time can range from 15-20+hrs just learning your way, with afew new key commands to make you think about what your doing, then there's the wolves, a bear, and a mtn cat, not to mention rabbits, birds, deer, and alot more weapons, the skill tree is bigger also, crafting is a major part, and this time there is no finish a area and move on, you will be using fast travel to complete each area.

reviewText:
Let's start it off with the negative side:
● Story 📖It's hard to say. It was OK, not something which could throw you of your chair with an OMG effect. Wasn't also sure to place it in the negative side. But the story in the 2013 game was slightly better and could stuck better in your mind.

● Game performance 🚀The game runs really bad on an I7 and a GTX 680 - (I'm aware that the GTX 680 is already out of date, but the grafical beauty isn't as much better as the 2013 game.)
Heard that it has also problems with a GTX 970 which is recommended for the game.

● Weather ☁Lara is going through rough temperatures below -40°C most of the time.
Snow, some rain here and there and that's all.
Missed the +35°C from the syria mission for the whole part of the game.

● Price € £ ¢It came out with a fixed price of 50€. It's a lot, even tho the game came out 2 months earlier on the Xbox one. Spoilers could be found anywhere on the internet before the release on PC.
After the release the gameprice dropped on 45€, which was not a really good move by the devs.

Positive side:
● Environment 🌅The bigger open world!
There is way much more to do and to explore.

● Bigger and more complicated tombs

● Lara's look (Ofcourse dependent by your preference.)
The 2013 version of Lara was too young looking. Now we have an older looking Lara. 😍

● More clothes (Mostly clothes for cold/rough temperatures) - Tank Top is unlocked by the end of the story.

● Slightly better graphics

● The purehair (better known as Tressfx 1.0 on PC) is now better optimized.
Haven't seen big performance drops, even with set on very high.

● More weapons, modifications, skills etc .. 🔫

Conclusion:
It's a really good game, especially if you're a Tomb Raider / Lara Croft Fan.
I liked the design of the open world and the story of the 2013 game more. (But it's just my opinion.)
Overall I recommend it to everyone who likes Action-adventure games!!

8.5/10 - ★★★★★★★★✬✰

reviewText:
A (more than) worthy sequelIt's been a long time since I get hyped for a game, buy it on day 1 and have an absolute blast from start to finish. Most fun I've had since Wolfenstein: The New Order.

✓ Good story
The story isn't exactly amazing, but it's definitely engaging and there's a decent amount of character development and plot twists. Be warned though: the ending is inconclusive.

✓ Great gameplay
RotTR is a delightful mix of guns, puzzles, explosions, and a true sense of exploration. Even though the story is linear, the maps are quite nice and you can go back any time, explore some more and find new stuff. Enemies respawn randomly as you revisit maps, so no place is ever empty.

✓ Visually stunning
I know we're only in february, but so far this is the prettiest game I've played in 2016. It's as gorgeous as it is demanding. The recommended specs" aren't wrong at all! Keep that in mind before buying or you might end up like the poor fellows in the negative reviews.

reviewText:
It's....not great. Its every flaw of the first game magnified by 10 in a severe case of sequilitis minus any character growth for Lara or any sort of decent plot ( The story is basically Tomb Raiders of the Lost Ark. ).

As opposed to continuing the first game's arc of Lara going from naive college student to seasoned veteran; You start the game as a remorseless superhuman killing machine and end the game as a remorseless superhuman killing machine that can climb a bit faster. Unless its a cutscence or scripted sequence, then Lara becomes a clumsy, bumbling idiot. Things will explode around you to give a false sense of urgency but there's no actual threat from them. Half of all the surfaces you touch will dramatically crack, crumble or give way. ♥♥♥♥ so overused and predicatable there is no suspense or excitement involved whatsoever.

On top of that the game will yell at you constantly about things being nearby ( OPTIONAL things it stresses ) and about items you don't have yet ( there's no surprises, it will yell at you exactly what item you need that you don't have yet. ). Every surface you can scamper up inexplicably has white paint on it even if its a centuries old tomb. Everything you can find is eventually marked on your map. So there's no real point in exploration and no sense of discovery. Just walking to map markers and pressing x.

Investing in skills actually makes the game worse as the majority are convenience options or things that add even more indicators the game can yell at you with. Or make the gunplay and press Y to instantly win easier.

Your gameplay boils down to thus:

Press X to not die.
Press Y to win every fight.
Collect a cynical amount of pointless things with no purpose but to pad out the game.
Run through a sequence where everything around you falls apart like its made of paper mache.
Press x to not die.
Kill critically endangered wildlife because Lara needs a new purse.
Collect a huge variety of pointless weapons you will never use.
Press x to not die.
Press RB to turn any random piece of garbage into an IED.
Run some more as everything comically crumbles around you.
Fall and slide into water several times.
Drown a couple of times.
Suffer at least two concussions.
Press x to not die.
Get waylaid, incapacitated, caught off guard or otherwise taken down because the plot says so.
Run some more.
Press Y to kill the end boss.
Uninstall game.

And yes, you kill the end boss with a quick time event. Don't expect any sort of epic battle. Just press Y and win the game. Its a dissappointingly low note to end the game on. There's basically no real finale. You just go through another extended run/climb panic sequence then press Y to win the game. Woo. Every plot twist is telegraphed a mile away and half the plot is lifted from Raiders of the Lost Ark, so don't bet on a gripping story to carry you through the game.

Also, Lara did not bring a knife or a compass and at one point she willingly drinks 50 year old insecticide. Lara is a ♥♥♥♥♥.

I was going to write a long review but it's just not worth the time. Short version:

Instead, most of the game is running, grabbing onto ledges, and climbing....over and over again without too much increase in challenge. Puzzle elements are few, but at least some of them are well done. The materials and crafting mechanic that was expanded for this game is underwhelming aside from the creation of throwable weapons while in combat. Stealth combat is fun but gets mostly thrown out the door near the end of the game. So. Much. Just. Running. Around.

I'd reccomend this game if you catch it on sale in the future. But at full price, I wasn't too impressed.

Pros

reviewText:
At a glance   Game Name:  Rise of Tomb Raider
Original Release:  28 January 2016
Genre Tags:  Adventure, Lara Croft, Puzzle, Pre-Open World, Woman Protagonist
My Overall Grade:  A+
Estimated Playtime:  Story Campaign averages 15-20 hours but if you want to complete everything, expect roughly 30- 40 hours.
Multiplayer Aspect:  Auxiliary
Recommended To:  Established fans of the genre; those intrigued by the genre; dangerous adventure lover.

Rise of Tomb Raider takes everything its predecessor did so well and makes it even better. This time round Lara Croft is driven by obsession, not survival, and for the first time we see her in shades of grey. Unlike 2013’s Tomb Raider, Instead Lara has learnt how to handle pain, command an arsenal of weapons and kill droves of enemies. She’s now a formidable fighter who inflicts more than she takes - but I did see the cracks in her moral compass.


Story  NO SPOILER, only the story key.
In 2013's Tomb Raider reboot, developer Crystal Dynamics puts Lara into danger against her will, straying her on a strange island with even stranger secrets. But she's since gained agency. In Rise of the Tomb Raider, she's running headlong into the fray at her own pace, seeking the key to eternal life.


Gameplay  This isn't a sandbox, though--subsequent areas are gated by ability unlocks. Now more than ever, you have territory worth exploring. By going back to older environments, you can venture off the beaten path in search of useful abilities. Several of Rise of the Tomb Raider's areas are open hub zones, hidden environmental challenge, replete with resources, NPC side missions, and secret passageways.

Backtracking to old areas is rewarding, too. Especially if you are a perfectionist—gamer who likes to finish game in 100% progress. It is rewarding because in Rise of Tomb Raider, every single collection/findings (mural, document, relics, etc) will boost your XP to upgrade your skills and coin caches to buy equipment and outfit. I knew exactly where that cave was I couldn't enter without the rope arrows. Unlike scavenging, scavenging does not reward you XP but worth to modify your weapon and craft your arrows and bullets.

The way the combat combines evolving weaponry and a choice of gameplay styles – you always have the option to go in loud or stealth and cover tactics – means that sequences are always tense. If you’ve forgotten to pick up some more wood, you’ll run out of arrows mid-fight and curse your laziness.

And as the traversal becomes more varied and complex with your increased abilities, the world becomes your playground and more like the Tomb Raider games I’ve always cherished.

In the interest of building Lara to fit your unique playstyle, Rise of the Tomb Raider incorporates three skill trees: hunting, brawling, and survival. Each contributes to their respective fields in disparate ways, by making certain aspects of the game less challenging or more rewarding. One allows Lara to shoot two arrows at a time, for instance. Another grants her more ammo when looting enemy corpses. The wide array of skills works well because each feels worthwhile. Pursuing them adds another layer in an already nuanced system.

The most fun parts are finishing the Secret Tomb. It boosts your XP a lot and rewards you with one Lara’s skill. Unfortunately, most of the Tomb puzzle is easy to solve but hard to find the entrance door. It feels like, finding the hidden Secret Tomb is harder rather than solving the puzzle.

Finishing the challenges, rewards you points to buy cards as well as to achieve 100% progress. Challenges in Rise of Tomb Raider are just like side activity to do to boost up fun. Burn the propaganda poster, cut the flags, find dark areas, etc.

For me the gameplay in Rise of Tomb Raider is very fun because it always keep you busy. You have so many things to do and touch up. If you enjoy the game and want to finish it in 100% progress, you will feel the same way as me. Anywhere you go, you find things to collect, finding new hidden map to reveal the hidden area or collection stuffs, finding new documents to follow the story plot, scavenging, fight with enemies or animals, find a new hidden areas, learning new languages continue main missions and do side missions and many more. You will even come back to previous place just to collect and finish up things you miss out.


What is new    The New Crafting System   – Makes Lara’s scavenging and hunting in flora and fauna more intuitive. It enables Lara to craft or to upgrade her weapons which will help her a lot along her journey.

Combat has also been revamped  - There’s now a much greater element of stealth so now, as well as engaging in close quarters combat, Lara can creep up and kill the bad guys using her new hunting knife, or even avoid combat altogether by diving into water or climbing up into trees and across rooftops. She can even create explosives with which to create chaos.

No longer will plants and animal carcasses  - Instead you’ll be gathering feathers from birds’ nests, poison from specific mushrooms, hide from a deer partially digested by a pack of wolves, and of course wood from saplings. These are just examples, but you’ll need them all if you want to be well-stocked for each mission.

There’s no multiplayer option this time around, instead you’ve got Expeditions  - Accessible via the main title menu, Expeditions let you replay missions within the campaign without affecting your main save game. They also let you tackle each mission in a variety of ways. This new single-player option allows you to replay chapters, jump into hub areas with new objectives or just go for a classic score chase. Each of these challenges can be modified in interesting ways.
As you progress through the story, you'll earn points that can be spent to purchase card packs. Cards can have gear or upgrades for Lara, or they can have other modifiers — tweaks that make enemies harder to take down or turn Lara into an unstoppable killing machine. Each modifier can have a major impact on how any one run through expedition mode plays out.
Note:  Packs of cards can also be purchased with real money. However, just playing expedition mode earns more points with which you can purchase more packs, so it doesn't seem like people will be forced to spend real money at any point.

Graphic  As for the graphics, the majority of the game takes place in Siberia, where the weather veers from fierce snowstorms and avalanches to bright, clear days. And regardless of the weather conditions, the world of Rise of the Tomb Raider is never less than stunning. The environments are often breathtaking, with some of the best snow and running water effects I’ve ever seen. Honestly, it is one of the best graphic video game. The detail of the character design is remarkable. Lara Croft's hair dancing smoothly, her facial expression is so believeable and cute, her skin feels alive, and her movement gives an impact.


Conclusion  Once again it’s Lara herself, however, who steals the show, her complex ambitions and hardened resolve showing new sides to a character who has well and truly grown from survivor to the most fascinating action hero in video games today.

If you love adventure, full of danger story, stealth, guerilla combat, acrobatic move, crafting weapon, upgrading weapon, bow, scavenging, collecting mysterious items, discovery, deadly land, wildlife, unique mechanism, exotic theme, challenging tomb puzzle, breathtaking view, woman, detail of Lara Croft that can make you c.u.m within 5 seconds. Buy this game! All those elements combined have just created an unforgettable game ever.

reviewText:
I've been waiting a long time for this game.
After i played the last game (The 2013 reboot), i was suprised by the game, it was a breath of fresh air for my day to day gaming experience.
I was very excited when i first heard about it, but it was a huge dissapointment for me that this game was a timed Xbox One exclusive until january (When it came out for PC).
Finally, after 3 months, i bought the game, and well...

About the story :

Let me start by saying that the story of the game is, in my opinion, better than the last game.
The characters were better designed and overall more beliveable than the last game.
The only character that i have a problem with is Jonah, he's shuch a p*ssy compared to lara.
The story of the game is considerably longer than the last one (It's around 12-14 Hours).
It's actually not that long, which is kinda sad, i expected a longer story to be honest, maybe around 20 Hours.
For completionists, the game can be as long as 30-40 Hours.
The story itself has a lot of content in it, like Tombs (Wow, rly ?), relics, documents, etc...
The game encourages players to explore the world, find and collect artifacts which grants you bonuses (Secret abilities, weapons, etc...).
These can really help you out if you are playing it for the first time, but it's not necessary and you can still beat the game even without collecting any arifact.

Gameplay:

The jumping mechanics are awesome, it's easy to get used to.
Shooting and other gameplay aspects" of the game are great as well.
The only problem for me is the difficulity.
I completed the game in survivor (Hardest availabe) in 13 Hours and i had no problems doing so.
There is no "Real challenge"

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is an improvement over the previous game on almost every aspect and should not be missed by fans of the series.
The story takes place one year after your adventures in Yamatai (previous Tomb Raider). This time, the opening level is in Siria with the rest of the action taking place in Siberia. Although most of the levels are set on a winter background, there is a lot of variation throughout the game, so it is not all cold and snow. I found the story to be more engaging with great cut-scenes and voice-acting to complement it. Characters are also well-written with back-stories and details that can be discovered by reading the documents found in the game.

Graphics are a strong point for this game and it shoes that Crystal Dynamics collaborated with Nvidia to bring the best visuals and optimisation for PC. The nice graphics also require a lot of horsepower, so no wonder that this title has been bundled with the latest GPU's from Nvidia.

Gameplay is very similar to the previous title, but the animation quality is better especially with the stealth movement and sneaky attacks. I disliked how Lara's stealth movement is auto-triggered whenever enemies are close. I would prefer a button to toggle this behaviour and discover the next enemy location on my own.There is more emphasis on exploration and hunting, as you need crafting materials to upgrade your equipment and weapons. Optional tombs are part of the game and unlock some of your best skills after completion. Unfortunately the tomb puzzles are very easy (same as in the previous title).

Level design is liniar in most zones with the exception of 3 areas that are more open and can be approached in different ways. Range combat still feels better than melee, but this time the levels provide more opportunities for stealth attacks. Expect some level sections that just throw waves of enemies at you and some sections in which you just run and jump for your life. However, I like that quick time events are fewer now and Lara is still in your control most of the time. There are lots of collectibles and challenges to be discovered, but please note that some can only be found after you finish and return to that level.

There is no multiplayer, but some replaybility is offered with Expeditions. This mode is basically a scenario creator where your enemies, objectives and character modifiers are represented in the form of cards. Load any level with your custom cards and play it or share it with the community. Upon completing an Expedition, you receive coins used to unlock different cards.

Overall: Rise of the Tomb Raider is a nice looking game and I can recommend it to anyone who likes 3rd person action/adventure. Offers good pacing between story, exploration and combat so that you don't get bored or overwhelmed at any time. It takes about 12h to complete if you rush the story or over 30h for No Stone Unturned (100% achievement).

reviewText:
Firstly I have already completed this game on Xbox 360 & to my surprise there are no graphical differences between 360 & Xbox one but with the PC version there are differences the graphics are duller & colour seems a little diluted ,I noticed this on Square Enix's live stream on twitch 2 days before launch day.
With that being said my main worry with the PC version was could my PC run the game? Yes it can run it , quite well too, while playing & not recording I can run it on high settings at 1080pp with a steady 50 to 55 fps. When recording I have lowered the settings (check my Videos below) with a steady 45 fps it still looks great IMO.

Rise of the Tomb Raider, the sequel to the 2013 reboot of the TR franchise is it a good game to play?
Answer : Yes
I was expecting Rise to pick up where TR left off - that didn't happen but yet again Lara is thrown into another action packed start to her new story. Lara's appearance has changed a lot from the March 5 2013 launch, not too happy with that but she is very pretty & alot shorter in stature lol
Pros
1. The main story is good not great but it is enjoyable.
2. There is so much to do on the map itself - this is where ROTTR really shines.
3. The optional Tombs are better puzzle wise and fun with a reward at the end, better than just a gasp of awe" or "a slight gasp" !
4. Lara can now sprint & swim .
5. lots of new equipment & weapons to have fun with.
6.  A new crafting system.
7. Side quests that give rewards once completed.
Cons
1. Really no need to play TR 2013 before playing this.
2. Tomb Puzzles are too easy & are optional again.
3. AI are so stupid -but do have the ability to spawn beside you and attack lol.
4. Equipment from TR 2013 only available by collecting coins and buying from an ingame shop.
5. A new crafting system - the amount of hides needed for a tiny ammo pouch or an outfit is ridiculous - but whatever floats your boat!
6. Lara has so many ways to kill she would put a serial killer to shame :D
I loved playing this game so many hours of fun and still having fun with the PC version extremely enjoyable .

reviewText:
Awesome sequel from Crystal Dynamics.

Tomb Raider 2013 was a bit far from a classic or LAU Tomb Raider experience. Rise of the Tomb Raider is getting closer to a Tomb Raider experience. Some of the complains have been taken into consideration. It means, we have tombs, explorations and less endless gunfights.

I can note a very nice performance from Camilla on that one.
Awesome graphics, controls, environments and longevity. Story suits very well with the game (Pratchett won the Writer's Guild 2016 award yesterday).

But, the game felt extremely easy and death traps were clearly too obvious. There is way too much babysitting sometimes.

You should definitely get it. Great job, Brian Horton and Crystal Dynamics's team.

reviewText:
FINAL EDIT: (about 5 hours of gameplay):

Since my original review, I have tweaked several different things with the game. I updated my Nvidia drivers and moved the game to my SSD. I think that moving the game to the SSD has fixed the bugs I have been experiencing. Therefore, I AM recommending this game (since it has been a lot of fun after getting past the bugs).

To elaborate, I originally encountered many bugs in my first 30 minutes of gameplay. This included:

- Cutscenes not triggering
- Graphical glitches and lag during cutscenes
- Large areas of the map not loading (allowing me to fall through the world)
- Music glitch (repeats same note over and over)
- VERY long loading time for campfires

After updating my Nvidia drivers, I still experienced most of these glitches. However, after moving the game to my SSD, I have experienced none of them. My guess is that my HDD loaded textures/cutscenes/parts of the world so slowly, that it was causing many issues with the game.

Now for the actual game:

Pros:

- Crafting is a really good addition and makes battles more fun
- Cutscenes have amazing graphics/animation
- The storyline is interesting and immersive
- Fighting mechanics have been improved slightly, but are still very familiar
- Graphics - the best I have seen in a game, personally
- Puzzles! (some are pretty hard)

Cons:

- Collectables are more of a chore to find than anything else. They are fun if you want to 100% the game, though.
- Some sections of the the world are too big. I find myself wandering around a lot and ending back in places I have already been. This may be a pro for those who enjoy open spaces.

Ignoring the initial glitches and issues, I would give this game 9/10. Definitely recommend.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

EDIT (about 3 hours of gameplay):

I restarted the game and have gotten past that first game-breaking bug in the cave. The problem seemed to have arisen from the order in which I activated objects in the cave. After that part, I had no more game-breaking bugs, but just little glitches here and there.

One such glitch involved major amounts of lag and graphical glitches during the first cutscene where the Trinity shows up, despite no graphical glitches or FPS drops during any of the gameplay.

Another involvs long loading times when activating a campsite. The UI (inventory/weapons/etc) of the campsite does not show up at first and took up to 4 minutes once to load.

Besides the aforementioned two glitches, the game has been much less glitchy after the first twenty minutes. If the game continues to run smoothly after a few more hours of gameplay, I will most likely recommend it (despite the rough beginning).

For those interested, I have a GTX 980 and am running on Windows 10.

-----------------------------------------------------------

ORIGINAL REVIEW (about 1 hour of gameplay):

I currently do not recommend this game. Note that I have only played about an hour, but I am running into many bugs tht I did not experience in the 2013 Tomb Raider PC version.

In just the first hour I played, I have experienced the following bugs:

- Sound looping glitch - This has happened about 4 times in the hour I have played. The sound track is great, but there is a glitch where it repeats the same note over and over again and will not stop until you die/go to the main menu.

- Cutscene would not trigger - In the first major ice climbing scene, I got to the part where there should be a cutscene, and there never was. After about 20-30 minutes of tinkering, I finally managed to trigger it. Nonetheless, this caused a lot of frustration.

- Story progression bug - I am currently stuck in the first cave that Lara visits where she is reading all the Greek writings and murals on the wall. The objective is to go to this wall and inspect it (which I suspect will progress the game to the next part), but I am unable to inspect it, leaving me trapped in this cave with no way out. This bug is currently game-breaking for me.

The Good:

- Graphics are fantastic. The hair and eyes are especially great.
- The cutscene animations look and feel very natural. It truly gives it a cinematic experience.

Besides that, I can't say much for the gameplay. I have mostly just pressed forward and inspected items so far in my playthrough. Unfortunately, due to game-breaking bugs, I cannot recommend this game as of yet. I will update if things are fixed.

reviewText:
MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS/READ AT YOUR OWN RISK

Since I finished the game (100% minus DLC and currently exploring the expedition modes), I still feel secure in recommending it to both longtime fans and newcomers. It's a good game in its own way for people who don't know or aren't as knowledgeable of Lara Croft's journey in the game industry, but imo it's not quite what it could be for diehard fans. Don't get me wrong, I very much enjoyed ROTR more than the reboot; it's just still lacking in certain areas that - based on the improvement thus far - I'm mostly confident they'll, well, fix for a lack of better words.

For starters, they captured the sense of adventure better than the reboot by providing better incentives to explore the land as well as expanding said area. Aside from collecting resources, collectibles (ugh), and challenges (double ugh), there's the bonus of a group of people you can interact with who give you missions to carry out. This, on top of the newly designed challenge tombs, makes the world feel more alive through the past and the present. It definitely helps that the entire game is more colorful and vivid than the dull colored maps of the reboot.

As for the action, they added a few more mechanics to spice up the combat a bit. There's an array of weapons to choose from rather than one weapon that's either swapped for a better one or upgraded to look different, and most of the weapons now have specially crafted ammo. In addition to this, they've added on the move crafting to allow different approaches to combat encounters; you can now craft throwables to either damage or distract, both of which can also be upgraded to do more damage or add damage respectively. There are more skills as well, but quite a few of them were hit or miss for me. All this combined with an enhanced survival instinct that allows you to see when an enemy is in view of another gives way for better stealth tactics if that tickles your fancy. I mostly played the game in this manner on the seasoned raider difficulty, so I don't know if that affects my opinion differently, but I'm almost tempted to say that the game seems to push for stealth more than guns blazing - which brings me to my next point.

The game unfortunately still went with the endless amount of men trying to kill one female, and I'll never understand why. This isn't a SJW or feminist point, this is from the standpoint of a longtime fan who wishes to see more adventure and puzzle solving than an illogical one woman army. It literally kills me inside when even the game acknowledges this with its oh so witty" comments from said men who can't believe they're getting their asses kicked by Lara Croft. Yes
date: Lara Croft is a badass but she's a badass because of her intellect more than her ability to kill someone or something. In all the TR games she has killed to survive

reviewText:
Oh Lara!
Now what can I say about her(and her sexy ♥♥♥♥). This game is just near perfection. The gameplay, the graphics and everything else. The story was so good that kept me glued till I finished the main story. The story is about her father who died mysteriously trying to uncover the truth of immortaility. Lara goes on a journey to Siberia to uncover the truth herself and also to justify her father.

There has been tons of improvements on the gameplay mechanics. Cover system has been improved. Combat is a lot more challenging and fun. The most fun part of the game is solving puzzles and tombs. And this one really makes your brain look like monkey trying to find a piece of banana. It's a lot more challenging and in some parts, its way more harder.

This game brings in new addition with side missions. While they are fun, but it's not that much connecting with the main story.

Weapon upgrades and skill tree are lot more detailed and diversed into various categories, which makes it even harder to level up and get more skill points.

Optimization wise, it's decent. It's not the best as there are some serious stuttering issues during loading and cutscene playing. When textures set to Very High, the game literally freezes during loading and even having 4gigs of VRAM does not help. This game has serious memory leak issues where at a point, it uses all of your Ram and crashes. I have a 16 GB of Ram and this game used all upto 15gigs which is insane. Otherwise, the game is good with detailed graphics.

This is a kind of game where you need to take your time and explore each and every bit of it because there is someting waiting for you to be found on each and every part of the world.

One needs to take the time to appreciate the level of detail, the devs put into the game. Just wow!

TL;DR

Just go get the damn game and play it! :)

reviewText:
Better than the last one. This time with actual Tomb Raiding and not an excuse to shoot hundreds of people in the face with an AK47 and mimic Uncharted which itself was an attempt to imitate Tomb Raider but went in its own direction...

Simple Points:
+Very intriguing Prophet story
+Byzantine
+Clever puzzles
+Good amount of Tombs
+A sizeable number of areas to explore

-Lara's story
-Konstantin (totally not a Byzantine reference name)
-Ridiculously amount of (often useless) audiologs scattered everywhere.
-Drab attempt at presentation that desperately tries to mimic 'hollywood blockbuster' cinema but feels very forced.
-Collectathon

I'm mixed on this game, it improved on a lot of things that I hated about the original but also adds other things that I'm not particularly fond of, such as the storyline and characters that just drain you mentally and emotionally.

I really liked the other part of the story that concerns the Prophet and his followers, Byzantine empire and the city of Kitezh as well as most of the Tombs.

reviewText: Rise of the Tomb Raider feels like a proper adventure, one in which you make discoveries, explore unbelievable locations, and tops this off with some heart-pounding action sequences. It helps that the dev team has created one of the most gorgeous games I've ever played, with gigantic underground tombs that dazzle and far-reaching vistas that inspire. This aspect is all the more impressive on PC, providing you've got a decent rig to game on.
