reviewText:
As Among Thieves was to Drake's Fortune, so this game is to the rebooted Tomb Raider.

There are just so many small things that I love about this game that, when put together, create a fantastic game. Perhaps my personal favorite is the introduction of resources and the crafting of crucial components, from a larger backpack to poison arrows to bring down a bear to weapon upgrades. I really disliked that hunting in the first game was useful for a grand total of maybe 20 minutes and then tossed aside, but this time they outdid themselves. Hunting anything from deer to bears to birds and rabbits is useful, and hides are in high demand. It also doesn't feel like a chore, but is actually a fun mechanic in the game. Resources are abundant if you are vigilant enough (and not just heedlessly sprinting through the game), and hunting is easy if you are patient enough to use a vantage point to snipe an unaware buck.

Combat is more or less the same as the first Tomb Raider. You really don't want to end up in melee combat, but you do have the dodge counter available through skills, which can be quite useful. The ability to craft molotovs is extremely useful, as you can snipe somebody from a safe distance by grabbing a random whiskey bottle, lighting it on fire, and tossing it at him. The heal mechanic is incredibly nice, especially on the upper difficulties where there is no in-combat regen, as it allows you to manually heal yourself instead of relying on the *I just got shot, let me sit here for 5 seconds and pretend like nothing happened* method. It's still prudent to stealthily take out enemies, as Lara can be fairly easily overwhelmed.

I can't put my finger on specifically why, but I like the collectibles (including tombs) in this game quite a bit more than the predecessor. For one thing, there are a bazillion of them, but they also seem to make more sense. The challenges for sure are better, while the tomb puzzles are fairly simple to solve, but also quite rewarding as you get a new skill for completing each tomb that is extremely useful (e.g. survival instincts will show trap placements). There are also coins that can be exchanged at a merchant (damn Russian sellout just wants his vodka), but anything that is worth purchasing is extremely expensive, even if you manage to get all of the coin caches as each cache has 7 coins and the important stuff costs around 150.

So far the story has been a lot better in this game. We get to learn about Lara's relationship with her father and what drives her in her quest for the Divine Source. The supporting cast of characters actually feel somewhat fleshed out, but they never overshadow Lara. This is, first and foremost, a game about Lara Croft (which the first game seemed to emphasize to the point of excluding any character development for the other characters), but you can actually come to understand both the villains and your allies.

I seem to keep talking about this point despite claiming to put no stock in it as far as making or breaking a game, but the graphics in this game are just fantastic. Just watch Lara, whether in a cinematic or during actual gameplay. Her face shows so much emotion, her outfit glistens with snow or water depending on the weather conditions, her hair is detailed down to individual strands of hair. This game really is a pleasure to just look at, even though it definitely feels like they removed a lot of the sex appeal shots for Lara (she actually wears several layers while trudging through the snow covered mountains of Siberia... Who would have ever guessed?)

A small thing that I am not entirely happy about is that the game still has some feaux linearity in the form of campfire fast travel. It feels like the game would go wonderfully with an open world scheme a la Far Cry 3, but it's still a great deal better than the Uncharted series as far as linearity is concerned.

A side note outside of the game itself: I preordered the game, and as soon as it released, the price dropped by 10% for more or less the same content, and this Endurance mode, which sounds like something that should be released with the game, is instead $10 DLC. I wanted to support the developer by preordering the game, as i know that their sales have not been great despite the original game being fantastic as well as reviews for the Xbone version being high, but I feel like i was punished for doing so. I would advise against pre ordering, and just purchasing it on day 1. Even the pre-loading benefit was not much as it took about an hour to unpack after launch.

Overall, this game has far exceeded my expectations. Tomb Raider was already a very solid game, but the improvements in this game have put it over that edge from a fun, solid game to a must play experience for me. I give this game a 9.5/10, and look forward to Crystal Dynamics' next game.

reviewText:
The second installment in the amazing, rebooted Tomb Raider franchise. Lara is now in search of the Divine Source, the relic of immortality, as is the illuminati-like group Trinity. The game is very similar in mechanics and playstyle, being a linear driven story with open world exploration with an almost absurd amount of collectibles, however being Tomb Raider that is part of the fun, exploring.

The combat is extremely similar with a new mechanic being introduced, the on the fly crafting and resource gathering for offensive and healing purposes. The similarities are not only in the gameplay and combat, but also in the tombs and puzzles, the only difference being the puzzles seem to have gotten easier to a point where figuring this optional tombs puzzle is as simple as shooting a rope arrow and turning a crank, congrats! you figured out how to use the controls.

The downsides being the overly simplified puzzles and the DLC is not great, an hr long story DLC, and two challenge  modes that arn't particular spectacular.

Overall the game is amazing, fun gameplay and exploration, amazing combat finishers and the return of the brutal Lara deaths. Extremely cinematic with amazing visuals and extremely fun running sequences where everything is falling apart as you leap from crumbling collums to a swinging peice of scaffolding to land onto a cable, only after sustaining wounds that would kill any normal human, as Lara does. 9/10.

reviewText:
Really liked the game, a good sequel to the first Tomb Raider.
Nice graphics, enough to explore (although quite a few collectibles or optional tombs and such are tricky, which is a good thing), decent combat and a good story.

You can't play this game for a lot of hours like other games such as Skyrim or Fallout but I have 0 regret buying this.
If more Tomb Raider games are made, I can only wish for 1 thing: quality above quantity.

PS: this isn't a game you want to rush through, take your time & enjoy :)

I've played just over the first hour and let me say I'm blown away. I almost chose to wait for a sale or for the PS4 release of the game, but I'm glad I took a chance and bought this full price.

The game looks amazing and handles even better. The mechanics are fluid and the multitude of enviroments and challenges will never get old.

For any other Steam Machine pioneers out there: I run this on the i3 Alienware Alpha on high and it's pretty & fully playable. I'm in the process of building a desktop to really milk out the ultra and free-flow hairworks settings down the road, but it's more than enough as is on the Alpha.

Get this game and it'll help you remember why you're a PC gamer.

reviewText:
A nice balance of gameplay, story, and collection. I liked Tomb Raider 2013 and praised both the smoothness of the character's movement through the game and how, while there was much to collect, it isn't overly burdensome for completionists. Yes, I do use guides for a few hard-to-find pieces (my rule of thumb is when it's not fun, break out the Gamefaqs or IGN guides...), but you can get most things yourself with a little extra effort, and it's not a complete pain in the butt.

Rise of the Tomb Raider just smoothed out the rough edges from 2013. So, if you like 2013, you're going to find more to like in Rise. They also toned down the death animations (there's less torture-porn, as I call it), and really let Lara into her own.

I'm also a sucker for the outfit changes (some functional variations, yes, but mostly aesthetics and immersion), and I was pleased to see that there was virtually no fan-service. Yes, her butt looks good in everything, but there's nothing overly showy or sexualized, which is always nice to see with female game characters. Everything else, however, was absolutely eye-candy. Roaming the map was simply beautiful, and the fluid animation of character movement was a joy.

Whole-hearted recommendation from me.

reviewText:
The reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise in 2013 was met with pretty much universal acclaim from critics and general users alike. It was a fresh take on the series which really focussed on Lara’s origins and gave her a very real personality. The gameplay was overhauled too, and the story was intriguing to follow. So it was a very tough act to follow.

I was hyped about this sequel, and will open this review by saying I felt Rise of the Tomb Raider lived up to this hype. If I may be so bold, I may even go so far as to say I enjoyed ROTTR more than Tomb Raider (2013).

So ROTTR takes off after the previous game and explores the circumstances surround the death of Lara’s father. The overarching story is about Lara’s quest for the key to immortality and involved exploring, or ahem, raiding ruins in the Middle East and Russia.

I felt the story had more depth to it in ROTTR. It felt grander, bigger and just more of a journey. Core elements of the game from the previous game had been conserved, though I felt there was a greater emphasis on crafting in ROTTR. Difficulty wise, they’re both about the same. I enjoyed the additions to gear that provided new ways to traverse terrain in this game. I felt they added to the skill level required with the game as one is mixing up different button combinations.

Visually, ROTTR was gorgeous. Perhaps. one of the better looking games of it’s generation, and  this is to be expected as we could say the same for Tomb Raider (2013). I think what the dev team did with this is take what made the previous game so successful and just add to it.

My big gripe at this point in time is with optimisation. At my first playthrough, before writing this review, My system was running Crossfired R9 290X, i7 4790k, 16GB RAM, game installed to SSD, and my frame rates weren’t particularly at amazing playing on high (though not Very high) settings at 1440p. I understand this is an NVIDIA title so perhaps that has something to do with it. At the time of writing, AMD is yet to push out it’s optimisation driver for this game so perhaps that has something to do with it. The open world regions would drop my frame rates to about the 30FPS mark, but most other regions seemed to hang around 50-60FPS mark, so a mixed bag overall. It wasn’t unplayable by any means, and the gameplay and story were enough to keep me going, but I expected better.

However, ROTTR has strengths in most other categories. There’s a great mix of fast paced action and slow paced head scratching puzzles, which really contributes to the scope of this game. The combat is good, standard third person shooter tactics. The bow is an excellent weapon which is utilised well in the game, both for combat and navigation. The stealth combat was one of my favourite aspects. A lot of emphasis is put on this, and I felt it was mostly well executed. I especially enjoyed the inclusion of water based stealth kills, as well as death from above and just general sneaking behind an enemy to kill them. Really good.

The world building was top notch. Exploring the lore, through artefacts and journals really added to the story and the settings were beautifully designed. I am a fan of how it was not homogenous at all, with a good variety of settings and colours. One part of the game you’re exploring sandy Syria, later you’re in the snowy tundra of Siberia, and then you explore caves, ruins, mountains.

Audio is fine. Ambient sounds were appropriate, voice acting was as you would expect from a modern AAA title. Controls were fine, I played with Keyboard/mouse. There was the odd time when I experienced some lag in controls, but I put that down to the same issues as frame rate as discussed earlier. But it wasn’t game breaking.

Overall, some irksome optimisation issues for AMD users, but a good story, lovely to look at and just fun, engaging gameplay. ROTTR took the successes from it’s predecessor and for the most part expanded on them. Recommended.

reviewText: Tomb Raider gets it right again.  This is a great game.  I enjoyed the 2013 game and I enjoyed this just as much if not more.  I sunk 30 hours into it and that only shows how much I enjoyed getting to grips with and finishing the game.  A strong story with an old school iconic gaming character that still lives up to her name.  The developers have done good for the most part and have released the games third patch already this week fixing a lot of issues and bugs etc that players are experiencing.  It's nice that this game launched as strongly as it did even though it does have it's share of some mild FPS issues.  I think both graphics and gameplay rock in this one.  Would definitely recommend to action/adventure lovers and followers of the series of course.

bonus thing that happened to me

ENJOY! no REALLY LOL


extended review:
the first (13) hours of the game was just... STUNNING! now i havent finished playing the game, because i've been busy with real life, but seriously, i played 13hrs straight the first day i bought it. and mind you, the pure hair setting was awesome lol

i usually dont spend this much cash on one game... like seriously, if you look into my library, most of my games i got from the Humble Bundle Giveaway megathread! and yes free keys from promos and such, and a few of them were gifts as well. just to let you know, my cap for a game would be $15 max and it depends if i really really want it! most of the time i wait for sale or bundles, so yes, i did cry, and yes i felt so guilty after hitting the purchase button, but as soon as i started playing, i didn't care anymore!

i played 13hrs straight, (i'll keep on saying this because that was the number i saw after i exited the game) but i played it NOT only for story, but also for the completion of each map. i'm a bit of a completionist, so i play for the best results and i like to grind til my player, Lara, is so bad ♥♥♥, that the next map becomes a piece of cake.

i streamed the first 3-4 hours of my game split into 2 videos(after having a quick dinner break in between), so if you're interested to watch me play, here's the link to my youtube channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCY0XQcj3GdYNRpOsOgclJAQ

i wont give away too much anymore. I loved TR 2013, and i love this one even more!
now stop reading and get the game! you won't regret it. i've already forgiven myself for splurging on this game. lol
you'll do the same i promise you :3

reviewText: A spectacular game and a stellar PC port. If you enjoyed the reboot, then you should definitely enjoy this one as well. Gameplay is very similar with a few well implemented additions. The graphics are absolutely amazing and the game is very well optimised (the port was done by Nixxes, these guys rock). There is a lot of content here as well. After 16 hours I finished the main story and I'm still at only 78% with lots of collectibles and tombs to find. This is a great game and I really couldn't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
A fantastic sequel to Tomb Raider (2013) that improves on it's predecessor in every aspect. The visuals are absolutely stunning, and the snowy landscapes are often breathtaking.

The gameplay is more refined, offering satisfying gunplay, traversal and exploring. The skill/level system is very familiar from the 2013 game, but it's more in-depth and offers are greater variety of choices and upgrades for weapons and skills this time around. You can also craft different clothes, which is a nice touch.

Story wise it's more complex and interesting than Lara's first" adventure. The lenght of the game is perfect and if you want to aim towards a 100% completion

reviewText:
Why is it, that in most games with a skill system the protagonists forgets everything I taught her in the previous game?

This game really got me. Far more than it predecessor, although I think it is a little bit behind on the story it still does everything right. You have to explore the world in order to become a real tomb raider or you just rush through the main story, which still manages to get the right atmosphere.

I have to admit the parts were Lara swims through icy water and then reacts to it really makes for great feelings.

The characters lack a little bit of depts, the well known flashbacks of the last part were something I missed.

The game plays well as it was expected, while this time the hunting is far more importent and the crafting is an interesting part of combat, since explosives are not carriable any more.

Will play again for sure.

reviewText:
http://fg-2.com/2016/02/11/review-rise-of-the-tomb-raider/

Two years after the release of the remake Tomb Raider, we finally get to see Lara Croft on her continued adventures in Rise of the Tomb Raider. The game is much like the first in that it is a 3rd person shooter with RPG and platforming elements in the gameplay. Not to much has changed between the the 2013 remake and this new one with the exception of a few new added gadgets. These gadgets whether it be the rope, fire or explosive arrows are unlocked over time to both further progress the story along with allow you to be able to go back through various parts of Siberia in order to do a full unlock of the game.

The platforming of the game is much better than the first remake in that there aren't any silly bugs that cause you to miss your jumps or camera angles that through your jumps off. They also toned down on the quick time events, allowing for more player interaction during the game itself instead of an interactive movie. Also a return was the on the fly crafting system that allows you to craft explosives and ammunition for various weapons much like that of Last of Us. It is a pretty simple system that doesn't require too much resources to craft. I never really ran out of any crafting materials except when I needed to upgrade my weapons and equipment. Those were a little more difficult to get however that said you could get most of them by just running around the maps and hunting the different animals and supply caches.

I would also like to mention though the gameplay was fun, it wasn't all that challenging, at least on the Tomb Raider difficulty. It might be a little more difficult on survivor mode but I can't see it being all that much more difficult as sneaking around, distracting your enemies with thrown bottles among other things made it incredibly easy to kill them and not get caught. But difficulty is never a requirement to make a game fun, as I said I enjoyed playing the game even though it might have only took me 23 hours to 100% it including all the hidden items.

One year after the events of Tomb Raider (2013), Lara is searching for answers for what happened on the island Yamatai and is looking to her father's research when she comes across what events pushed her father to the edge of “suicide”. She comes across him referencing the city of the Prophet, Kitezh and the Divine Source, some mystical artifact that supposedly gives those that find it immortal life. In pursuit of this artifact a secret organization of God called Trinity is also chasing it and killing all who oppose them or don't follow their beliefs. It ends up being a race to who can get to the Divine Source first. Overall the Story isn't anything special but the characters are interesting enough and it had enough to drive the game overall, making me want to find out more. What added a lot to the story, and I feel like a lot of people don't bother with it, is the various lore you find from the Mongolians that invaded the city first, the Greeks that followed after, the soviets that controlled Siberia looking for the city and Trinity themselves in their recorded messages. It was those subtle codex items that added a lot to the overall story and history behind Kitezh and the Prophet.

I want to touch on something that it seems like I constantly see people complaining about Lara being a killing machine and don't seem to understand what drove her to do that in both games. Since these are both reboots we won't talk about the fact that in the games before she was a killing machine, we'll just focus on these two new games as their own series. In the first game there was no mysterious force chasing Lara and her expedition team, they were already on the island, that said she was already starting to be broken emotionally from leading her team into the Dragon's Triangle and marooning them on a deadly island. Once she found out a force of mercenaries were capturing and killing her friends she saw it as time for vengeance especially after she was almost ♥♥♥♥♥ and killed herself before she killed her first person. You could even see her progression through the game where she accepted who she was and what she had to do to stop those that were there to harm her and her friends. All that even led to this pretty often screen capped photo in game where, in my opinion, shows that she has lost what made her human.

In the new game it is much the same but this time she knows what Trinity is after and knows that they were the one that defamed her father that led to his death. On top of that she meets a new group of people that have lived near and defended the city of Kitezh for thousands of years. A people that she wanted to protect from Trinity. Lara may have a murderous tendency but it isn't without reason. Some would argue that she should be more likely to sneak around and avoid killing and Nathan Drake (of the Uncharted series) is more prone to killing. I disagree with that and argue that it is the complete opposite. A lot of times Drake has no reason to kill, he is a thief that doesn't really have a play in most of these enemy forces, he just happens upon them. I will take the exception of Uncharted 2 where they attack the villagers in Nepal but that wasn't until ¾ through the game.

This game is one of the most beautiful games I've seen, from the scenery all the way up to the particle physics and  facial animations. Crystal Dynamics did a fantastic job of making every little detail pop out and all while having it run great (at least on my PC, I've heard of others having problems but I didn't – 5820k, 780ti, 16g ddr4). I really noticed when Lara or other characters had looks on their faces, so the voice actors didn't have to sell the emotions as much, you could definitely see them. There are so many great screenshot moments in this game I don't really want to bombard you with all the pics I took while playing but to say the least some of the most talented screenshot takers are taking some of the most amazing photos (I have one friend that is very talented at this, but if any of y'all have some impressive photos feel free to put them in the comments below, I'd love to see them).

On to the sound too, the music really sets the tone and has a similar composition of the 2013 remake which was great in its own right but makes this game really feel like a continuation of a series. The voice actors are also really on their game and make the characters believable especially since a lot of game developers use motion cameras to capture even the voice actors as they are playing the role.

Overall this game is fantastic continuation from the reboot that started in 2013, though I did 100% it in about 23 hours there is a lot of other content including endurance, score attack and if you decide to spend the money the DLC that is coming with season pass. Maybe not as much of a replay-ability as say an MMO or giant RPGs but definitely a great bang for your buck especially if you can find a sale for it at $40 like I did. The Graphics, Gameplay, Story and sound are all top notch with the only blemish might be not as strong story as some others but still very solid.

Story – 8
Gameplay – 8
Graphics – 10
Sound – 10
Fun – 9
Replay Value - 6

reviewText:
After 11 hours of gameplay, I finished the main story.

The first minutes inside the game are fantastic. You have a breathtaking graphic, insanely fluid movements, wonderful voiced characters and of course the cutest and sexiest girl in the gaming world: Lara Croft.

The game is linear, even tho you are kinda allowed to roam around and do stuff, you basically wanna follow the red string of the story. You will occasionally encounter some special hidden quests which are fun to do and give you a good reward. You solve everything in typical Lara Croft style, climbing walls and jumping off roofs. And all of that doesnt only ♥♥♥♥ing feel awesome, it also looks awesome.

Your character can level up, and you can invest points per Level into abilities, which are divided into 3 main groups. It allows you to customize the way you wanna finish the game. Do you prefer shooting around, stealthing around or building traps? It's all up to you.
Your Weapons can also be upgraded, in the same way as your character.

I really enjoyed it. Maybe because I have a huge thing for British girls. Or, and thats what I think, because this game just combines some of the core elements of some good games and brings us a wonderful next gen Lara Croft!

reviewText:
If you spoke to me when I was a kid and told me that one day there would be Tomb Raider games where Lara Croft didn't use her iconic dual Desert Eagles but she instead swapped them for a Bow, I would shun you and probably throw a tantrum.
But here I am in 2016, having just finished the second game and I am beyond amazed. This game takes the best aspects from the last game and adds things we all missed from the original games... RAIDING TOMBS!

PROS
-Great Graphics
-Amazing gameplay. Especially the crafting system when in combat
-Pretty solid story that keeps you intrigued
-You can finish the entire game with the Bow. The weapons found later on in the story were not automatically superior

CONS
-Constant hunting in areas for things like coins or strongboxes tends to get boring
-Combat was never really challanging. Bears were more of a challange than 10 or more Trinity Soldiers
-Framerate drops in movies (under 20fps for me in some places)

As a Tomb Raider fan since I was just out of nappies, who started his first Tomb Raider experience by being allowed to sit on my brothers lap and press the space bar to draw Lara's weapons when she needed to them, I Definitely think this game is a game worthy of the Tomb Raider name and any one who is a fan of the originals or just the newer ones should give it a playthrough.

OVERALL SCORE 9/10

reviewText:
If you loved the first game this is a further step forward in every way. On the higher difficulties it's actually a challenge now, the firefights are very strategic and satisfying and plenty of tombs to uncover. Be warned though it's like Crysis, you need an incredibly powerful rig to run it once you get to the lost city stages. My frame rate on an r290 fluctuates wildly from 60fps down to the teens on the high setting and tessellation set to 8x in crimson control panel, playing only 1080p. This is with the latest beta driver. I thoroughly disagree with the reviewers who say there's not much difference between the quality settings, there is a gulf. If you have the rig to run this congrats, I thought meeting the recommended specs was enough but it's sadly not at least on AMD. A g-sync or free-sync monitor is recommended to address the frame rate fluctuations. I am hoping they can add further optimisations to the frame rate because it really struggles in parts. Can consume up to 7gb of video ram on highest texture settings, even on high it's saturated my r290 4GB buffer. But boy it can look beautiful.

Update: I have updated this section now that I have tested the latest AMD Driver 15.3.1 and the new Patch which both support DirectX 12. This game is incredibly single core heavy in DirectX 11 mode, even an overclocked FX processor (my 8320 is running @ 4.7Ghz) is not fast enough to smoothly run this game. However with the DirectX12 support now added, the game spreads the load evenly across all the cores eliminating the large frame rate fluctuations. Coupled with AMD's optimisations and the game can easily hold 50fps just about all the time and closes in on the golden 60fps on the default High game setting at 1080p. There are still a few demanding areas but these drop to the 40s instead of the teens now so they aren't are noticable unless you are looking for them.

The future of AMD and DirectX 12 looks quite rosy ;)

reviewText:
If you liked the last Tomb Raider, you will most likely enjoy this.

+ Lara's character is a bit more developed here than the last game
+ Tombs are fun to explore, and satisfying to complete
+ Excellent visuals, with many options to tweak.. prepare to take many screenshots
+ Lots of environmental interaction (snow, wetness, dirt) and little details to add to immersion
+ Best hair physics ever

- Too much gunplay, not enough crazy complicated tombs.
- Certain areas of the game are significantly larger than others, causing framerate drops
- Survival senses and Lara's words can easily point you to tomb solutions, taking out some of the fun in solving it yourself

Overal this is an excellent adventure game, and I had a lot of fun with it. 9/10

reviewText:
Having played the 2013 Tomb Raider game just a couple months before I was pretty excited for Rise Of The Tomb Raider. It certainly didn't let me down the graphics visually are stunning in my opinion, they have kept lots of the survival elements, and the siberian mountains (wilderness) setting is perfect. The storyline is packed with action and adventure and theres nothing more satisfying than a long range headshot with the bow and arrow. It has a very simple and easy upgrade system and provides lots of interesting challenge tombs and interesting side missions which give you bonus such as lockpicking.

So if you're looking for an action/adventure with survival and crafting elements, and enjoy stunning visuals in the heart of the siberian wilderness then this game is for you! Also made by square enix so I guess they are doing something right!

9.5/10 - Visions

reviewText:
The reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise in 2013 was met with pretty much universal acclaim from critics and general users alike. It was a fresh take on the series which really focussed on Lara’s origins and gave her a very real personality. The gameplay was overhauled too, and the story was intriguing to follow. So it was a very tough act to follow.

I was hyped about this sequel, and will open this review by saying I felt Rise of the Tomb Raider lived up to this hype. If I may be so bold, I may even go so far as to say I enjoyed ROTTR more than Tomb Raider (2013).

So ROTTR takes off after the previous game and explores the circumstances surround the death of Lara’s father. The overarching story is about Lara’s quest for the key to immortality and involved exploring, or ahem, raiding ruins in the Middle East and Russia.

I felt the story had more depth to it in ROTTR. It felt grander, bigger and just more of a journey. Core elements of the game from the previous game had been conserved, though I felt there was a greater emphasis on crafting in ROTTR. Difficulty wise, they’re both about the same. I enjoyed the additions to gear that provided new ways to traverse terrain in this game. I felt they added to the skill level required with the game as one is mixing up different button combinations.

Visually, ROTTR was gorgeous. Perhaps. one of the better looking games of it’s generation, and  this is to be expected as we could say the same for Tomb Raider (2013). I think what the dev team did with this is take what made the previous game so successful and just add to it.

My big gripe at this point in time is with optimisation. At my first playthrough, before writing this review, My system was running Crossfired R9 290X, i7 4790k, 16GB RAM, game installed to SSD, and my frame rates weren’t particularly at amazing playing on high (though not Very high) settings at 1440p. I understand this is an NVIDIA title so perhaps that has something to do with it. At the time of writing, AMD is yet to push out it’s optimisation driver for this game so perhaps that has something to do with it. The open world regions would drop my frame rates to about the 30FPS mark, but most other regions seemed to hang around 50-60FPS mark, so a mixed bag overall. It wasn’t unplayable by any means, and the gameplay and story were enough to keep me going, but I expected better.

However, ROTTR has strengths in most other categories. There’s a great mix of fast paced action and slow paced head scratching puzzles, which really contributes to the scope of this game. The combat is good, standard third person shooter tactics. The bow is an excellent weapon which is utilised well in the game, both for combat and navigation. The stealth combat was one of my favourite aspects. A lot of emphasis is put on this, and I felt it was mostly well executed. I especially enjoyed the inclusion of water based stealth kills, as well as death from above and just general sneaking behind an enemy to kill them. Really good.

The world building was top notch. Exploring the lore, through artefacts and journals really added to the story and the settings were beautifully designed. I am a fan of how it was not homogenous at all, with a good variety of settings and colours. One part of the game you’re exploring sandy Syria, later you’re in the snowy tundra of Siberia, and then you explore caves, ruins, mountains.

Audio is fine. Ambient sounds were appropriate, voice acting was as you would expect from a modern AAA title. Controls were fine, I played with Keyboard/mouse. There was the odd time when I experienced some lag in controls, but I put that down to the same issues as frame rate as discussed earlier. But it wasn’t game breaking.

Overall, some irksome optimisation issues for AMD users, but a good story, lovely to look at and just fun, engaging gameplay. ROTTR took the successes from it’s predecessor and for the most part expanded on them. Recommended.

reviewText:
Perhaps there’s no better recommendation I can give Rise of The Tomb Raider than to say that despite my initial reluctance to play it, my old stick-in-the-mud attitude about it being another reboot, my aversion to her new face and my revulsion at the early insistence on providing a slick, commercial ‘experience’, it has made me want to stay longer in its world, to the extent that I bought DLC for it, as well laying out for the previous game (TR 2013).

This new one has made me think. It’s made me reflect on the incredible veracity that modern mo-cap technology can bring to games, and how that now genuinely predicates a need for good casting and quality acting (the Big Bad in this one was brilliant). It’s made me cringe and cheer alternately at its plot developments. It’s tired me with its technical brilliance, worn me down with its approachability, and pacified me with its onion layers of choices and systems. Eventually, it made me want to play it when I wasn’t playing it, and not stop when I was. And finally, it took me on a proper ride, away from work and stress and stupid obligations and into a world of adventure, and for that I shall always remember it with a smile.

(Read more at our friendly gaming blog: http://www.xp4t.com/review-rise-of-the-tomb-raider/ :)

reviewText:
When I got this game I honestly didn't expect much out of it. Was mostly bored and looking for something different from what I normaly play. Though I quikly fell in love with the game, looks amazing, and I run it smoothly at 60fps on Ultra settings, though I set texture quality down to High. (Think there where a unsignifisance moment, like during a cut scene, where the fps dropped slightly). The camera feels very smooth and I never felt it pointed in a way that was anoying or where I missed out on anything important which a lot of 3D platformers absolutely fail at.

Excellent character development, the antagonists have motives for, and raelly seem to belive in what they are doing. I also wanted the best possible outcome for the protagonist and that there was a sense of that what the protagonist goes through has a impact on who she is to become. It really felt like what she went through mattered. And this is something a lot of games and movies fail at. If a character dies or are hurt I couldn't really care less. I still think Crystal Dynamic have to tread carefully here. Watched a playthrough of the Tomb Raider (2013) on YouTube. And the only character I really felt anything for when they died was Roth. Theres something similar happening in RotTR but going deeply into to it would spoil a major plot twist. In the end, if we care about characters that die, we would understand the protagonist more and really get the feeling that we too want revenge.

During the game you will be able to craft equipment and ammo by collecting resources. You can also use the resources to upgrade your weapons. I never felt that I had to get better equipment or upgrade my weapons more to progress in the game, they where just nice upgrades that can be tailored to each individuals playstyle. The same really goes for the skills in the game. As you kill things, collect resources, discover hidden staches, complete challenges and explore tombs you get XP and the more XP you get the more skills you can unlock. Again I never felt like I needed anything in particular to be able to progress and thus I never felt that the game was grindy.

Finally but not least the tombs. Starting off early the tombs are quiet easy and get more dificult as you progress. Though most tombs are optional. Most tombs has a puzzle you have to solve before you can get to the end and get the reward. They certainly are entertaining though on a very few ocations I felt there wasn't really enough clues as to what I was supposed to do, but I figured them out eventually. I also feel like most tombs involved using ropes in some way or another.

If you would like to see some gameplay of the game I would like to refer to my Lets Play videos on YouTube.
Part 1: https://youtu.be/UgKC3wvF3yI
Part 2: https://youtu.be/WBDw0bAHe-o

My Lets Play videos contain no spoilers of the story.

Fantastic game! Absolutely love it! Can't wait for more. 9/10

reviewText:
This game is a finely crafted piece of Art!

Pros:

+Stunning Visuals.
+Solid Gameplay.
+Good Balance between Action and Puzzles.
+9 Tombs to raid (more than the 2013 version).
+Controls are easy to master whether you use KBM or a Controller.

Cons:

-Puzzles could be more challenging.
-You'll need a seriously high end PC if you want to turn on the visual treat (after doing that the phenomenal graphics nullifies the con! :P).

So if you want to buy this game go ahead and get it!

P.S-Just wanted to mention visually this game gets really really close to the Witch Cry [Chapter 0]" Demo of Square Enix!"

reviewText:
This was a great follow up to Tomb Raider 2013, but a few caveats that will have spoilers so be warned in reading.
.
.
.
.
.
.

The ending of the game is almost a mirror of the first game and that is very frustrating to me as a player who enjoys an epic climax to their ascension of genocide i literally felt like I was playing TR2013 with a helicopter finale instead of a sun god possessing a priest on the pinnacle".

Puzzle platformer with a few enemies.
Then action sequence on the top of a round structure with a lot of enemies.
Followed by a boss battle that has breaks in the middle to fight minor enemies
Then a quick final QTE to kill the antagonist.

Don't get me wrong
date: the gameplay is exactly what I wanted but from a story telling aspect and a design aspect it literally felt like I was playing the last level sequence of the first game. The boss battles executed differently but it felt like the same action ending and it bugs me.\n\nWas it worth the $40 I paid for it?  16.3 hours to complete the main story with minor deviations to break up a speed run and kinda explore so yeah? I guess? I have a bit of animosity because of the ending but I think I can get over it. The graphics were amazing
recommended: the glacier as a back drop to some cold tundra and muddy living areas was pretty stellar. The audio drew me into the game like none other. When ♥♥♥♥ started breaking under you as you're running across certain things the sound was impressive
hoursPlayed: scary. The gameplay was what I expected

reviewText:
Stunning graphics but, Nvidia means it when they reccomend a 980ti for 2k resolution.

It took me 29 hours for 100% completion on the 1st play through.

The story is fine but I think they missed the mark of trying to show us Lara's character evolving.

Gameplay is not challenging enough as the controls have been dumbed down and Lara is constantly telling you which way to go.

Overall, I did enjoy it but, I'm a TR fan from the original on and quite frankly, I feel short changed.

It's a fun game but I reccomend you wait for a discount, I don't think you'll have to wait too long.

reviewText:
What is Rise Of The Tomb Raider? Well, it’s a drama riddled glitché-fest episoode of CSI Miami  featuring Oprah Croft – a little girl with daddy issues.

Square Enix has done something right though. You can now disable any aiding feature of the game which turns it into quite a challenge which I enjoyed very much.

Visually the game is a stunning journey through variations of scenery and side-quests and raidable tombs never felt repetitive. Latter I can’t say for the story though.

Overall go ahead and buy this game – it’s a very good game. If you expect a Tomb Raider game though then you will be disapointed.

I’m running it between 50-60 fps on:
I7 4790K
GTX 970
Corsair 100i liquid cooler
SSD drive (quite bad one tbh)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WQb8gEsvgJ4

reviewText: This game is everything the reboot wasn't.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Did you like the first reboot? Well, this is more of the same - or rather more of the good things of the reboot. Less QTE's, more tombs and caves and exploration. Still some silly problems with bining keys to mouse on PC. It shows to press the [] button for various actions, but if you have two thumbbuttons used - you won't know which ones until you tried - and most likely died a few times.

The story is slightly tighter this time around, more focused - and that is both good and bad. If you're a completionist than it will feel like you leave people to die to be able to go off the beaten path to explore and find treasure. You also have to leave certain tombs and treasures behind since you will lack certain gear and features that you lock up later on in the story line.

The expeditions are fun DLC and really should come in more flavours since this is what most will be doing after they beat the game - or well only be doing since this is the real challenge.

The game has some technical flaws and hickups. There is a hguge FPS drop in expeditions that occurs with a few minutes regualr intervention that makes it feel like something is going on that shouldn't be happening. The single player part runs with most things on on my spec flawlessly. I don't use occular and lens flaires and depth of field - but other than that - I have most things on except the hair. And I have a steady 80-110 FPS regardless of fights in firelit places.
Gameplay issues range from minor nitpicks as to how the camera works and you have little control meaning that forward moves your character sideways end vice versa in some parts of the game. Sometimes you can't see where you are going, meaning that you have to die to your death hoping you are on the right track and then redo some climbing/jumping routines - I had rather seen more difficult pathfinding as an obstacle than the camera itself as your biggest problem.

Hopefully coming patches will make the expeditions better optimized since that is really something nice - oh and that's were most of your pre-order and DLC extras will come into play.

The card system is to beef out and tweak your expeditions adventures.

EDIT notes: after finishing the game and Baba Yaga DLC.
So, the game is ended and for that I have to give cred. I don't finish all my games but this one I did. The game gets slightly tedious at the end, trying to sweep the areas looking for missing documents, loot and item chests. But all in all - a nice game. Baba Yaga wasn't a hit though - if you think you're missing out due to this one - rest easy - it is not worth the time. I got a bit disapointed here with the season pass so far. Hopefully something that adds to replayability will come out because I have no intention of playing this again on other difficulties etc. In the end, you do get more of the tedious fights from the first game. This time around it is easier to either sneak past - or have some cat and mouse game out of the fights - but still, a few too many to my liking.

reviewText: A worthy follow-up to the excellent reboot.  It's basically more of the same as that game, which isn't necessarily a bad thing since why fix what wasn't broken?  Lara's competence is established from the first game and you get to enjoy the benefits of that, as she steadily proves to allies that she can be relied on and - more importantly - to enemies that she should never be underestimated and always be feared.\n\nGraphically it looks great, the setpieces are exhilarating, the setting is interesting and it manages to hit the sweet spot when it comes to collectibles/exploration/upgrading equipment etc.  Here's to more of more of the same for some time to come.

reviewText:
Completed this game in 22 hours. I guess it's a good gameplay time even I completed 75% of game (Skipped some tombs because of never ending curiosity what comes next).

You know, difference between Tomb Raider and Rise of Lara, In this game I never felt bored. I liked the world, I liked the mini-puzzles in tombs, I wanted to complete this game to see the final of this story. I like how emotional the beginning was, liked the introduction of characters, flashbacks, liked optimization from xbox (some games have such lame optimization @ start, = lags/fatals/etc). I liked everything.

For a fan, who completed all games (except the latest platformer Tomb of Osiris) from 1-st game to the last. I name this game one of the best if not the best game in the series.

Story was good, characters were emotional and I believed in their emotions, good work to voice actors and animation team. Music was well-fitted.

Only one thing made me sad.
When you had no arrows IT WAS HARD TO SHOOT ROPES sometimes (because of camera la. But, well, sometimes :D

Play on Survival Difficulty and have fun!
Can't wait for the next game.

reviewText:
Perhaps there’s no better recommendation I can give Rise of The Tomb Raider than to say that despite my initial reluctance to play it, my old stick-in-the-mud attitude about it being another reboot, my aversion to her new face and my revulsion at the early insistence on providing a slick, commercial ‘experience’, it has made me want to stay longer in its world, to the extent that I bought DLC for it, as well laying out for the previous game (TR 2013).

This new one has made me think. It’s made me reflect on the incredible veracity that modern mo-cap technology can bring to games, and how that now genuinely predicates a need for good casting and quality acting (the Big Bad in this one was brilliant). It’s made me cringe and cheer alternately at its plot developments. It’s tired me with its technical brilliance, worn me down with its approachability, and pacified me with its onion layers of choices and systems. Eventually, it made me want to play it when I wasn’t playing it, and not stop when I was. And finally, it took me on a proper ride, away from work and stress and stupid obligations and into a world of adventure, and for that I shall always remember it with a smile.

(Read more at our friendly gaming blog: http://www.xp4t.com/review-rise-of-the-tomb-raider/ :)

reviewText:
Having played the 2013 Tomb Raider game just a couple months before I was pretty excited for Rise Of The Tomb Raider. It certainly didn't let me down the graphics visually are stunning in my opinion, they have kept lots of the survival elements, and the siberian mountains (wilderness) setting is perfect. The storyline is packed with action and adventure and theres nothing more satisfying than a long range headshot with the bow and arrow. It has a very simple and easy upgrade system and provides lots of interesting challenge tombs and interesting side missions which give you bonus such as lockpicking.

So if you're looking for an action/adventure with survival and crafting elements, and enjoy stunning visuals in the heart of the siberian wilderness then this game is for you! Also made by square enix so I guess they are doing something right!

9.5/10 - Visions

reviewText:
So, I wanted to beat this before I wrote a review.  When I finished, I had completed roughly 70% of the content.  I missed a few of the tombs, but saw enough to know what they were like, and some of the weapon components.

All in all, this was a solid game, but not something I would recommend buying at full price for two reasons: 1) There isn't all that much gameplay to be had and 2) Though it's well done, there's nothing life-changing here.  The most I'd pay, if I could do it again, is 40 dollars.

This is a nonexhaustive review, I listed the things that I've most commonly seen commented on and anything that jumped out at me.

TLDR: Good graphics, but mundane setting.  Decent story, but a bit short.  Average overall mechanics (crafting, combat).  Enjoyed my time played, but less than the former title.  Though i recommend it, I would not pay more than 40 dollars.

Pros:

- Graphics.  The graphics are extremely well done.  There is a lot of polish, nothing too clunky (the occasional visual glitch)

- Tombs.  Tombs were pretty solid; simple enough that they wouldn't totally frustrate you, but not so mindlessly easy that they had no value.

- Story.  This would probably be more appropriately listed in the neutral" category.  I didn't find the story particularly thrilling.  It was extremely straightforward

reviewText:
More varied, more fun to play version of a reboot from 2013. A modest sequel and a refinement of Tomb Raider formula, a formula I had a lot of fun revisiting. There are new areas to explore, plenty of side activities to do, myriad of things to collect, and a new group of enemies ready to be headshotted. There is also a brand new story, this time centering around the Divine Source, mythical artefact that supposedly can grant eternal life.

Optional tombs were also improved. They are more memorable, make much more sense in the game world, and no longer award you with experience points but rather teach Lara new abilities. It was a joy to find and clear them all.

Multiplayer was thankfully neutered and replaced by Expeditions - new set of modes, allowing you to replay chapters, play score-attack or return to hub areas with new objectives - all while competing with other players on leaderboards. I'm also happy to report that ridiculously brutal death scenes have been seriously toned down.

My biggest problem with RoTR is that it is too similar to its predecessor. On the next instalment (and I'm sure there will be one) I'd like some serious game play changes and not just a paint job.

reviewText:
Lara's back, she's a badass, and she doesn't want your cis white male bull ♥♥♥♥.

Positives:
- Lara and her voice actress (though other characters are pretty good too)
- a good story, though, in my opinion, a bit below the previous game's level
- lots of action packed scenes, and less QTEs
- the game is ultra atmospheric, the sound, lighting, and sceneries make a really enjoyable adventure
- the graphics are just simply amazing, along with the animations (especially the faces)
- enjoyable combat and movement mechanics, not too complex, so it doesn't take a lot of time to get used to
- quick loading times
- beautiful, well constructed, and fun to explore tombs

Negatives:
- hopefully my HIV test
- the gun sounds are really sub-par, they don't feel powerful, which is kind of anticlimatic
- some people complain that the game doesn't run well on their machine

I'm running the game on a desktop PC with the following specs:
i7 3770k @ 4.20 GHz (memelord, I know)
16 gigabytes of DDR3 RAM @ 1600 MHz
250 GB SSD for Windows 7
2 TB HDD which the game runs from
MSI GTX 980 4GB (not Ti) at the factory clock speed
ATI Radeon HD 4850 1GB for my secondary monitor
2x 60Hz 1920x1080p monitor

With this setup, and everything maxed in graphics, except the 2 blur options and film grain, in borderless fullscreen mode, I usually get around 75-80 FPS with SMAA, and around 60-65 with SSAA 2x, though I don't recommend maxing everything out because the blizzards lower my FPS by 10.

I definitely recommend this game if you have a decent enough PC to run it on, I often catch myself in awe, stopping to look around , taking screenshots for wallpapers, the sights and atmosphere are just that good, otherwise, running it on low/medium is good enough, the game still looks nice, and you won't be too disappointed with the core of the game either.

9/10, so far GOTY material for me.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider improves on its predecessor in almost every way. Tomb Raider's evolution from a third-person adventure/platform/puzzle game to a slickly produced third-person action shooter with less focus on platforming and puzzles continues here.

Visuals + Performance
This is one the prettiest games I've ever played. The facial and body animations are simply amazing. The reflections, textures, lighting effects and details in the environments are absolutely stunning. This is a very high requirement game and as such requires a high end computer if you want to run it at the highest settings and high resolutions. That being said Nixxes made sure to include a very good range of scalable settings. I can run the game on my really quite old system[imgur.com] at mostly high settings and get a very consistent 30fps, 25-45fps if I unlock the framerate. One of the main things affecting framerate and performance in this game is texture quality and if you want to run it on very high textures and get 60fps you need a fast 6GB VRAM card, coupled with a modern CPU and a good amount of fast RAM. Although I have no problem running the game with medium textures which my 2GB VRAM can handle just fine. I would complain about not being able to get 60fps (even lowering settings to the lowest possible settings doesn't really get me a consistent 60fps), but my CPU is just not up to the task so I can't complain really.

There is an uncanny feeling to it at times. You almost get the feeling of being there next to the people in the game as if it was real to a degree that few other games manage to achieve. Little details such as the footprints you leave in the snow, the way Lara fixes her hair and brushes her hand against walls as she passes them, her breath in the cold Siberian air condensing and Lara's little facial twitches and expressions are just incredible.

Sound effects are mostly great. The voice acting from Camilla Luddington is particularly good. She does a great job of delivering Lara's lines with subtlety and emotion. All the bad guys and other characters are quite well voiced too, although some of the writing of the dialogue could be better and is often quite stereotypical.

It would be remiss of me to not mention some issues. The AA options in the game are not the best and it is hard to get a nice sharp image. There is some slightly ugly issues with textures/objects loading in on distant objects and reflections on water in the distance can look blurry sometimes. Some of the NPCs are not so nicely modelled. Also, there are a good few bugs and glitches that I encountered, not so much that it broke the experience for me, but they are definitely there. I've heard mixed things about how this runs for those with high end systems trying to push the settings to the max, some seem to be able to get a consistent 60fps others seem to suffer from occasional drops.

Gameplay
The visuals are this game's strength, but I found it to be a highly enjoyable game to play. Although the game is not exactly the hardest game ever made. In fact it's mostly rather easy, even on the highest difficulty mode. That's not to say there is no challenge at all. But if you are looking for a highly challenging difficult game then you may be disappointed.

I do enjoy how they have refined Lara's movement set. They brought back the abilities to run, dive and swim underwater from the older games. Stealth mechanics have been built upon. You can sneak around and watch the enemy in survival instinct to see who is being watched by another bad guy and carefully take out isolated bad guys one at a time. Or you can carefully sneak behind enemies and stab them in the neck or jump on them from up high.

Shooting and killing people is largely the same, I enjoyed it in the last game and I enjoy it here. It's not the most complex gameplay in the world but it is a lot of fun. You have a good deal of options to dispose of bad guys this time. You can blow them up with grenade arrows, you can poison them, you can set traps on corpses, you can craft makeshift molotovs or bombs on the go and burn or blow up bad guys to your hearts content.

There is platforming and puzzle solving, along with finding stuff and upgrading things, to go along with this. You get 9 optional challenge tombs, along with a few extra secret ones. They are definitely an improvement on the ones in 2013 Tomb Raider. They are bigger and a fair bit more challenging to solve. Although they are still not the most challenging puzzles ever made and they don't take a massive amount of time to solve. It's a good step in the right direction, but I would like to see these puzzles being brought into the main story line and not put as optional side things. There is some environmental puzzles to solve to get through the main story line but more would have been welcome.

Story (Slight Spoiler Warning)
About the stereotypical dialogue and writing. I particularly found the main bad guy, Konstantin, to be frequently quite laughable. He's your typical angry guy who wants power and has a personal army of stereotypical bad guys helping him. There's a mystical power type storyline going on here. Lara wants to find it because she wants to prove that her father wasn't a fool chasing after fairy tales, the bad guys want it because they are bad guys. There is a bit of soap opera with Lara's personal relationship with one of the baddies and a whole personal betrayal thing is going on.

I liked Lara's character in this game. I felt that she was very like-able. She's a strong, intelligent, confident but relatable woman on a personal mission to prove something that matters to her. It's just a shame that everybody else around her in this story is so stereotypical and lacking depth. But I felt as I played the game I cared about Lara and what she is doing. The story may be a bit lame but it is done with a lot of style and is a fun ride.

Extra Modes, DLC, and Lasting Appeal
You get Score Attack, Chapter Replay/Elite and Remnant Resistance modes as part of the standard game and you get Endurance Mode, Baba Yaga and Cold Darkness Awakens as season pass/individually purchasable DLC modes. Score Attack and Endurance modes are the highlights of these for me. In Score Attack mode you can replay through the missions from the main game with an arcade like score meter and you compete against yourself or friends to try and get the best score possible. You can use up to five cards which you unlock with currency earned from playing the main game. These allow you to make the run either easier or harder. You can have enemies with more armour, or have only one life, or you can change your equipment and so on. Endurance Mode is like a survival mode in an open-ended environment where you have to survive for as long as possible.

These modes are a lot of fun and give the game a lot more lasting appeal if you enjoy them. Endurance Mode is particularly enjoyable and can be quite challenging. It's a bit of a shame that they don't allow you to alter the main game like you can these modes as that would have made it much more challenging, dynamic and lasting in appeal.

Baba Yaga is overpriced for what it is, only really offering 1-2 hours of gameplay, maybe 4-5 if you really stretch it. I enjoyed it whilst it lasted, but it's really nothing special and I feel likewise about Cold Darkness Awakens.

Final Thoughts
I like the new Tomb Raider games a lot and am a big fan of this new Lara, I think she's wonderful. But I am also a big fan of old school Lara and do miss her and the way those games were made. It's a little bit of a shame that they don't offer something more substantial to old school Tomb Raider fans such as a skin of old school Lara. More challenge, integrated puzzles, customizability and deeper story/writing would have been nice. But overall this is a great game, I enjoyed it a lot and highly recommend it.

reviewText: One of the most fun games I've ever played.  The abilities are fun to level up.  Hunting is a blast.  Crafting is rewarding.  Stealth is as fun as jumping off an ancient artifact to stab somebody in the face.  Rise of the Tomb Raider is also one of the top three prettiest games I've ever played.  Go drool over my screenshots.    The puzzles are too easy, but I spammed the survival mode button.  The combat and action scenes in this game (playable and cinematic) will get your heart pumping.  The game doesn't have a whole lot of replay value unless you are a completionist.  I really enjoyed the story in this game.  I never tried the cards but I'm going to because there's big head mode, sometimes-enemies-will-explode-when-looted mode, infinite ammo mode, and all sorts of other fun-looking cards that make the game easier, more challenging, and/or fun. reviewText:
Having played the Tomb Raider 2013, the immediate comparison I could make after finishing The Rise of the Tomb Raider is that the newer game felt short and had less 'Wow' moments compared to the first. I guess it's because of the heightened expectations of a sequel to what was to me a fantastic first game (TR2013). Another thing that fell flat was the choice of story. I won't spoil it for you but (IMO) it lacked the needed punctuation and the ending had me go 'so what?'. Maybe Crystal Dynamics should have gone left wing and write a more mystical story than the one they used in this game. Some new characters introduced felt one-dimensional. Like Sophia. Her mistrust on Lara at the beginning turned to respect and silent awe like an on/off switch. I also felt that the antagonists were designed in the same vein.

Apart from that, whatever that was good was carried over from the previous game to Rise of the Tomb Raider. Graphics were great and gameplay stayed true to the original. However, I felt that level design was dumbed down a bit.

The RPG mechanics were good. In a way that I could level up Lara's skills based on how I played and never had to feel like I wasted a point. At about 80% through, I felt like I could get away without upgrading any more Skills but did so anyway so I could kill some baddies in a different way. But the game wasn't long enough to allow me to try new ways of killing/ambush once I got the skill upgraded.

All in all, I'd give this game a 7.5/10. Lara's still the girl we know and love. But this seemingly MOST important quest she's on is a tad boring.

reviewText:
In short, 7.5/10

Pros:
+ Gorgeous scenery
+ High quality cutscenes with good voice acting
+ More diverse environment than prequel
+ Larger and harder puzzles than prequel
+ Exciting action setpieces without being too much
+ Generally good character writing
+ Not-so-cheap collectibles

Okays:
= Acceptable story
= Marginally improved enemy AI

Cons
- Still not enough exploration - only 2 major hub regions.
- Too easy puzzles - each puzzle piece rarely took me more than 5 minutes.
- Handholding - white paint and voice comment - not to mention survival instinct - telling you where to go
- Overpowered Lara even on high difficulties
- Cheap ending with disappointing resolution - Predictable and did not satisfy my curiosity

I recommend non-casual gamers to impose a self-challenge of not using map and not using survival sense during the game."

reviewText:
Making a good sequel to a game that defied all expectations and became an instant classic like 2013's Tomb Raider is quite the challenge. And I can safely say that the people at Crystal Dynamics have succeeded in this endeavor. Rise of the Tomb Raider is just as good as its predecesor, if not better.
In this new adventure we follow Lara as she tries to clean her father's name. The story is filled with fantasy and adventure, and is supported by the usual document collectibles that you find throughout the game. Learning how people felt and how they survived is a thrilling journey that will make you want to find all of them so you can learn the whole story.
From the gameplay point of view, there are no complaints what so ever. It is as good as the previous game and there are some new mechanics that make it compelling to go back to previous areas just to kill some enemies in various creative ways. And also there's the threat of nature, as wild animals will fight you as you trespass into their natural habitat. Everything feels smooth and not forced upon you, and this is rare to find in a AAA game these days.
Now, from the graphical point of view, let me say that if you assume you can run this game with a rig that could manage the previous one, then you are mistaken. The environments look gorgeous and every detail is breath taking. But if your PC is not prepared for a highly demanding game, then you won't be able to enjoy said environments because you will barely be able to run the game. Specially if your graphics card is AMD. The folks at NVIDIA made sure that any AMD user that plays this game does not get to enjoy it at its full capacity. The optimization is terrible, and even the newest AMD cards can't handle some of these options without dropping frames like hot potatoes. Be aware before you buy this game: you need a powerful processor, lots of RAM and an NVIDIA graphics card to play it without DPS issues. You can still play it with an AMD card just fine if you don't care about the sudden frame drops in big places and the occasional crash. That's about the only negative thing I have to say about this game. And it seems to be happening with every game powered by NVIDIA these days. It's annoying as hell.
TL;DR: This game is amazing in every aspect except its graphical optimization. If you can run it, buy it. You won't regret it.

Before I start I was a huge fan of the first Tomb Raider and going into this I was very excited...and boy it did not dissapoint!

The production value on this game is insane! The visuals, the action sqeuences, the voice acting they have gone all out! And just a side note with the visuals, they are jaw dropping!

The only con I can think of is that its a bit too short. I finished the game in 11 hours and I did a bit of exploring but if you want to complete everything it would take around 15-20 hours. But while it may have been short, every second I was fixed to the edge of my seat.

Overall- 9/10

reviewText:
Exploration is improved by quite a lot although I can't really say much about the combat in the game. Some features (Like the crafting throwables) felt tacked on, not really fun to play with and littered the playing field with rubish. Overall, some plus and minus which leads to a slight improvement imo.

Biggest let down is the story. First one is fantastic where Lara is shown, sorta a damsel in distress at the start. As the story progresses, Lara was shown gradual transformation by surviving life threatening events and some very rude awakenings. One of the best part of the first reboot is the almost at the end where Lara has become such a badass her mere presence sent her enemies scampering and she was shouting, intimidating and taunting them.

On the sequel? Not so much. It tries to create drama on her relationship with her dad yet it rarely show ANYTHING about her direct interaction with him. Very few dad/daughter scene and we were asked to just take it in faith that she's driven by her dad's past. Right. And the ending? ugh........ I was expecting more from the team.

Another minus is that I beat this game in 12 hours in hard mode :(

I still enjoyed the game though, so take this recommendation with a grain of salt.

reviewText:
Main missions are fun and the boss battles are exciting. Side missions are too filler-like but are somewhat useful for gaining XP. Tombs range from easy to what am I missing?" but are fun in both cases.
Story is engaging and the world is beautiful. Most sections are just begging to be screencapped.
Bugs are few and far between. The jumping is a lot less precise than the last game and a lot of items refuse to prompt the pick up key.

I liked it. Progression was better in the previous game but this one improves upon it in almost every other aspect.

reviewText:
My overall rating for Rise of the Tomb Raider(tm): 95/100 (RotTR)

It was expected, that since publisher change occured to Square Enix in 2009, we might get a restart of Tomb Raider series. Fortunately, it was a good one, with enhanced graphics and thrilling story. Developers went even further and gave us in this title also exploration and survival challenges in harsh Siberian nature. Game, what may calmly aspire to the Game-of-the-Year title. Lets see in detail, what went good and what might be better.

GAMEPLAY

+ Respect to tradition
+ Thrilling story
+ New platforms and puzzles
+ Good locations allowing non-linear gameplay
+ Exploration possibility
+ Completable achievements
+ DLC serve their purpose, purchasable with in-game earned credits
+ RPG elements and multiple tactics
o nVidia cooperation
- Sometime controls are clunky
- Game is less intuitive

It is always hard to release a title in such famous series as Tomb Raider. Developers from Crystal Dynamics succeeded to give us a stunning story and yet perserve the spirit of previous titles. Furthermore, we can see, how it all begun, de facto, it is a restart of the whole serie.

RotTR respects platform and puzzle presency and incorporates them well. This features present challenges, without them it would not be possible to enjoy this title. There simply have to be traps in tombs, but they are spottable and you have to try a bit to solve them, after that, the player is rewared with success.

What is also positive, that the gameplay is non-linear, gives the player possibility to explore and set own tempo in progressing the game. It is underlined with human vs. nature challenge, your enemies are also beasts and harsh nature, yet resources for weapons, equipment and crafting are taken from vasts of Syria and Siberia.

RPG elements are a great addition, you have three skill trees - Brawler (melee), Hunter (long-range), Survivor (hunting and endurance), which allows you choose your best tactics from plenty available.

Achievements are completable and they serve as another motivation to play the game and advance your limits higher. Here we also go to some negatives.

Controls are sometimes clunky and game should be more intuitive and correct minor deviations. E. g. you are facing milimeter to the side, you will fall and challenge might be broken or not completed.

Cooperation with nVidia was a perfect idea, game runs with an amazing graphic, but sometimes Steam and graphic overlay were causing unexpected crashes of the game. This should be temporary, so far disabling of this feature helps.


CHARACTERS

+ Lara Croft
+ Jonah
+ Jacob
+ Sofia
+ Constantin
+ Ana
o Trinity and Remnant Resistance

Many characters are undergoing a huge transformation in the game. Lara was shy and naive in the beginning, after all of her adventures, she became determind and devoted to do the right thing. Jonah serves as an excellent companion. Mots surprising is Jacob. From the chief of Remnant Resistance forces he became the biggest plottwist, which can surprise even after so many stories told from Lara Croft's universe. Not to forget Sofia, who turned from rebel to person, who might lead the whole resistance.

Constantin and Ana were pefrect opponents, even between them struggles occured. What is sad, the rest of both forces were just to add enemies and allies to give the players immersion of something bigger. Little more improvement and it would be unbeatable.

VISUALS

+ Sceneries
+ Lara's behaviour
- Minor glitches

Sceneries are amazing, either desert Syria or winter Siberia, I could feel the atmosphere in each of my steps. What I like more that after getting from water she did up her hair and when she was cold, she was shivering (not good during the hunt :-D) and holding her arms around her. To sum up this idea, each screenshot might serve as a wallpaper.

There were several minor glitches, fortunately nothing disturbing, so I did not count them to evaluation.

SOUNDTRACK

+ Fitting to the game
+ According to the atmospheree

Another great composer work, songs are changing accordingly, atmosphere is kept in the level, that player is always amazed. Also, change of music sometimes warns you before you actually encounter enemies or beasts.

SUMMARY

To sum it up, RotTR is a great game, that might catch even players out of this genre (my example), is really customizable and players are able to enjoy it in their own tempo. Story is perfect, enviroment as well, it is up to you, whether you choose to explore or to progress.

In case you want to examine your survival activites, try Endurance mode, or uncover the truth behind the myth in Baba Yaga. It is up to the players, which tactic they choose and how they do. Challenges are motivating to go even further, replayability is great.

The prize might be a bit higher (49,99 EUR + 27,99 EUR for Season Pass), but it is completely worthy. Compared to the content and other games, it is really rich in what to offer.

Strongly recommended, and in my humble opinion, perfect aspirant for the Game of the Year.

This game does not give off a good first impression. The beginning is heavily scripted. Walk forwards, watch something bad happen, press X to not die, etc. Follow the linear path, watch the cutscenes. Please, give me gameplay already. Fortunately, after a short attempt to impress players with gee whiz cutscene action, it does start delivering the goods.

The gameplay mixes platforming, traversal (climbing and the like), combat of both the direct and stealth variety, puzzle solving, and exploration and discovery. There's a lot of good to be found in these elements.

Lara's jumping is fluid and fun to control. You can actually aim her jumps a little bit in mid-air, and her climbing is also quite fluid. She can double jump" up walls
