reviewText:
The reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise in 2013 was met with pretty much universal acclaim from critics and general users alike. It was a fresh take on the series which really focussed on Lara’s origins and gave her a very real personality. The gameplay was overhauled too, and the story was intriguing to follow. So it was a very tough act to follow.

I was hyped about this sequel, and will open this review by saying I felt Rise of the Tomb Raider lived up to this hype. If I may be so bold, I may even go so far as to say I enjoyed ROTTR more than Tomb Raider (2013).

So ROTTR takes off after the previous game and explores the circumstances surround the death of Lara’s father. The overarching story is about Lara’s quest for the key to immortality and involved exploring, or ahem, raiding ruins in the Middle East and Russia.

I felt the story had more depth to it in ROTTR. It felt grander, bigger and just more of a journey. Core elements of the game from the previous game had been conserved, though I felt there was a greater emphasis on crafting in ROTTR. Difficulty wise, they’re both about the same. I enjoyed the additions to gear that provided new ways to traverse terrain in this game. I felt they added to the skill level required with the game as one is mixing up different button combinations.

Visually, ROTTR was gorgeous. Perhaps. one of the better looking games of it’s generation, and  this is to be expected as we could say the same for Tomb Raider (2013). I think what the dev team did with this is take what made the previous game so successful and just add to it.

My big gripe at this point in time is with optimisation. At my first playthrough, before writing this review, My system was running Crossfired R9 290X, i7 4790k, 16GB RAM, game installed to SSD, and my frame rates weren’t particularly at amazing playing on high (though not Very high) settings at 1440p. I understand this is an NVIDIA title so perhaps that has something to do with it. At the time of writing, AMD is yet to push out it’s optimisation driver for this game so perhaps that has something to do with it. The open world regions would drop my frame rates to about the 30FPS mark, but most other regions seemed to hang around 50-60FPS mark, so a mixed bag overall. It wasn’t unplayable by any means, and the gameplay and story were enough to keep me going, but I expected better.

However, ROTTR has strengths in most other categories. There’s a great mix of fast paced action and slow paced head scratching puzzles, which really contributes to the scope of this game. The combat is good, standard third person shooter tactics. The bow is an excellent weapon which is utilised well in the game, both for combat and navigation. The stealth combat was one of my favourite aspects. A lot of emphasis is put on this, and I felt it was mostly well executed. I especially enjoyed the inclusion of water based stealth kills, as well as death from above and just general sneaking behind an enemy to kill them. Really good.

The world building was top notch. Exploring the lore, through artefacts and journals really added to the story and the settings were beautifully designed. I am a fan of how it was not homogenous at all, with a good variety of settings and colours. One part of the game you’re exploring sandy Syria, later you’re in the snowy tundra of Siberia, and then you explore caves, ruins, mountains.

Audio is fine. Ambient sounds were appropriate, voice acting was as you would expect from a modern AAA title. Controls were fine, I played with Keyboard/mouse. There was the odd time when I experienced some lag in controls, but I put that down to the same issues as frame rate as discussed earlier. But it wasn’t game breaking.

Overall, some irksome optimisation issues for AMD users, but a good story, lovely to look at and just fun, engaging gameplay. ROTTR took the successes from it’s predecessor and for the most part expanded on them. Recommended.

reviewText:
If you liked the last Tomb Raider, you will most likely enjoy this.

+ Lara's character is a bit more developed here than the last game
+ Tombs are fun to explore, and satisfying to complete
+ Excellent visuals, with many options to tweak.. prepare to take many screenshots
+ Lots of environmental interaction (snow, wetness, dirt) and little details to add to immersion
+ Best hair physics ever

- Too much gunplay, not enough crazy complicated tombs.
- Certain areas of the game are significantly larger than others, causing framerate drops
- Survival senses and Lara's words can easily point you to tomb solutions, taking out some of the fun in solving it yourself

Overal this is an excellent adventure game, and I had a lot of fun with it. 9/10

Graphics: We all knew from the previous title of 2013 that graphics were the strong point of the new Tomb Raider reboot but nobody could imagine such an advance.

Story: Like all Tomb Raider you search for something but in this title there is the personal involvement.

Fights: Shoot em with bows, blow em up, light em up, smoke em out, or just use your pistol... oh and skullhammer them with your climbing tool if you like it...

Puzzles: You remember the huge bell puzzle in the first title? Well I have half finished the game and not found an equal challenge but I found a lot more of them something that I liked even more.

I was never a hardcore Tomb Raider and truly the first title in 2013 was my first one but since then I bought all titles and finished them and now I feel obliged to the team that made this game to strongly recommend this title...

reviewText:
This game is absolutely GORGEOUS on max settings. To this date, these are the best graphics I have seen in a video game, hands down. During my entire playthtrough, I stopped what I was doing multiple times just to admire and take screenshots of the scenery.

The game plays just like the previous Tomb Raider, but this time, a crafting system has been added for objects you can find lying around. Wanna burn that group of enemies all bunched up while talking to each other? Just grab the nearest bottle and create a molotov to drench them in fire.

I like to think of these games as The Uncharted series for PC...with a hot chick."

Highly Recommended."

reviewText:
A worthy sucessor to the 2013 Tomb Raider game. Improves on mostly everything, including a much bigger open area, side quests, much better weapon customization and upgrade trees as well as more options on how to approach combat. As was the case with the previous game, the story had me engaged enough to care about some of the characters but it did have a rather abrupt and disapointing ending which again culminated in a quick time event. I feel like this one was setting up a sequel rather than being it's own standalone thing but i did find some resolution.

Lara seems a lot more confident in her abilites this time, with not as much emphasis being put on her constantly falling over and getting caught in traps. She is now quite the capable killer and ruthlessly slaughters hundreds of trained mercenies throughout the campaign. She comes across as a bit cold in certain parts of the game which i wont spoil but she is driven by her father to discover an artifact that drove him to his suicide, which makes her somewhat relentless in her pursuit of an ancient treasure.

I did have some frame drops in big areas on my GTX 970, but the game as a whole did run fairly well. it looks like one of the best games on the PC to date, and it is being patched fairly reguarly so any bugs seem to get fixed rather fast. The game lasted me a lot longer this time, around 300 hours and i still don't have all the collectables. My only gripe is the game is rather easy and only a few badly timed jumps led to my death.

In a nutshell, if you enjoyed the original game, this is an improvement is basically every respect. Make sure you have a fairly strong rig however or be prepared to lower settings quite a bit.

reviewText:
An excellent game that plays similar to, and produces the same level (perhaps even more) of enjoyment as the first game of the reboot.

The game suffers from some issues that in the grand scheme of things are relatively minor. Sometimes the story skips me ahead while I wasn't particularily done exploring an area and this can get irritating. The camera doesn't always cooperate (and sometimes removes your control to install a sense of amazement when you are nearing a cool structure), and I found that the controls sometimes don't do what I want. The DLC is a bit scummy. You don't really need (most of) it, and the game plays fine without.

With that said, those are the few critiques I have. Rise of the Tomb Raider is a step up from the previous installment and in general is really fun to play. The price point may be a bit steep at launch but I have confidence that it will go on sale for a 20-er within the year just like Tomb Raider 2013. If you didn't like Tomb Raider 2013, you probably won't like this one either.

reviewText:
A direct sequel to 2013's Tomb Raider reboot, Rise of the Tomb Raider looks to expand on everything Cystal Dynamics did with their last game. Although you'll need a powerhouse rig to run the game anywhere near 60+ fps on max settings, the game is visually gorgeous.
With my GTX 780 the game frequently fluctuated from a rare 30 fps to a more often 40-50 fps. Sunken city's and Icy cliff faces really come to life with astounding detail and the character models have also taken a step up with Lara sometimes being on the verge of photorealistic.
The gameplay remains much the same as the previous game with weapon upgrades complimenting the gunplay and some quite brutal melee finishing moves. This time around you can also craft weapons from bottles and cans left around the environenment to help in the game arena style battles with enemies.
My only gripe is that I didn't enjoy the story as much as the last game, and although the final sections ratchet up the action it still felt like a retread of the original games final section.
Other than that it's a great game but be wary about the games high requirements.

reviewText:
When comparing this game to the Tomb Raider (2013) Reboot, this game wins in pretty much every single aspect.

More enemy variety, tombs (that are unique), upgrades, different outfits to choose from (which have stat boosts).

If you're salty about the denuovo drm or have a potato PC, I wouldn't recommend getting this game. However if neither of those apply to you and you're a Tomb Raider fan then I would definitely get it.

reviewText:
Did you like the first reboot? Well, this is more of the same - or rather more of the good things of the reboot. Less QTE's, more tombs and caves and exploration. Still some silly problems with bining keys to mouse on PC. It shows to press the [] button for various actions, but if you have two thumbbuttons used - you won't know which ones until you tried - and most likely died a few times.

The story is slightly tighter this time around, more focused - and that is both good and bad. If you're a completionist than it will feel like you leave people to die to be able to go off the beaten path to explore and find treasure. You also have to leave certain tombs and treasures behind since you will lack certain gear and features that you lock up later on in the story line.

The expeditions are fun DLC and really should come in more flavours since this is what most will be doing after they beat the game - or well only be doing since this is the real challenge.

The game has some technical flaws and hickups. There is a hguge FPS drop in expeditions that occurs with a few minutes regualr intervention that makes it feel like something is going on that shouldn't be happening. The single player part runs with most things on on my spec flawlessly. I don't use occular and lens flaires and depth of field - but other than that - I have most things on except the hair. And I have a steady 80-110 FPS regardless of fights in firelit places.
Gameplay issues range from minor nitpicks as to how the camera works and you have little control meaning that forward moves your character sideways end vice versa in some parts of the game. Sometimes you can't see where you are going, meaning that you have to die to your death hoping you are on the right track and then redo some climbing/jumping routines - I had rather seen more difficult pathfinding as an obstacle than the camera itself as your biggest problem.

Hopefully coming patches will make the expeditions better optimized since that is really something nice - oh and that's were most of your pre-order and DLC extras will come into play.

The card system is to beef out and tweak your expeditions adventures.

EDIT notes: after finishing the game and Baba Yaga DLC.
So, the game is ended and for that I have to give cred. I don't finish all my games but this one I did. The game gets slightly tedious at the end, trying to sweep the areas looking for missing documents, loot and item chests. But all in all - a nice game. Baba Yaga wasn't a hit though - if you think you're missing out due to this one - rest easy - it is not worth the time. I got a bit disapointed here with the season pass so far. Hopefully something that adds to replayability will come out because I have no intention of playing this again on other difficulties etc. In the end, you do get more of the tedious fights from the first game. This time around it is easier to either sneak past - or have some cat and mouse game out of the fights - but still, a few too many to my liking.

reviewText:
Pros
- Decent but very predictable plot.
- Gorgeous graphics and scenes
- Good crafting element
- I like the RPG element of it


Cons
- Enemy is very similar to the first one.
- Some similar level design to the first reboot.
- Really short game. Finished every tomb and crypt there is too.

That said, I really enjoyed the game, just wished it was longer. I got it for £19 so I'm not complaining too much. Though if you're planning on getting for full price, the recommendation becomes a bit iffy.

TL;DR - Solid game, bad tombs and AI, predictable and short story - 7/10

reviewText:
This is a good sequel, I really enjoyed the premise. Especially the bits in Syria and early on in Serbia on the mountain felt really awesome, great introduction set pieces. The puzzles are a bit too simple honestly but I was fine with it as is.

My biggest gripe was how several times while far into the game I had to restart it. There are bugs here, nasty ones at that. Probably not everyone experience them but sometimes events weren't triggered, especially towards the end. The trebuchet stuff was downright frustrating, I had to restart the game several times. Not because of death mind you, simply because NPC's would be stuck inside walls and keep throwing stuff at you but you couldn't kill them. Or I couldn't remove debris that was in the way because it didn't get removed even though I was doing what I was supposed to do to progress. So really the last bit was really annoying for me. However these are bugs that will probably be fixed or may not occur for everyone. Though I really hated the trebuchet stuff in general, going back and fourth between these felt like pure filler to try and make the game longer.

As for the rest of the game, it's quite stunning and has an engaging story. Some pieces are quite cool, where you had three factions fighting each other at the end and you're just trying to make it across to the other side with things blowing up infront of you.

I must admit though I was expecting more, Rise of the Tomb Raider feels like the other Tomb Raider game from 2013. I guess more of the same is good?  But I would have liked to see them open up the world a bit more, I understand that is difficult.  Especially when there are events sometimes in tombs that block off areas as you progress.  It's not a big thing but the only time I really felt like I was exploring was when I found tombs scattered around the map for the side missions. These are done very well and I highly recommend doing these, most of the time they are a lot more engaging than the main mission stuff.

I'll end with that it's a solid sequel that needs some bug fixes and next time around maybe opening the world up more.

reviewText:
This is such a great Tomb Raider game, now with over 1000% more tomb raiding than the 2013 reboot! :D

I was very happy with the 2013 reboot, and thought it was a pretty decent Tomb Raider game (though lacking in the tomb raiding) and a good reboot for the series (I also quite enjoyed the previous Anniversary, Legend, and Underworld). Well this one is even better. They improved on just about everything: the platforming, the combat, the graphics, the tombs, the story telling, everything. They even got rid of most of the annoying quick-time events and gratuitous death scenes.

It runs quite well; I only had to turn a few settings down or off (Hairworks, HBAO+) and I had playable framerates on my aging GeForce GTX880M at 1920x1080; they did tank into the 20s maybe twice in the game in some graphics intense situations, but never never during cutscenes or combat. PC controls work fine (I chose to play with KB/M; only tiny issue is a mislabeled button in the map tutorial: it says press space to mark an objective, but you actually have to press enter). All in all a good port (or perhaps a parallel development?).

Seriously, though, if you enjoyed Tomb Raider 2013 but felt it lacked in the tomb raiding department, then you'll want this game. Crystal Dynamics NAILED IT! :)

reviewText:
This game does not give off a good first impression. The beginning is heavily scripted. Walk forwards, watch something bad happen, press X to not die, etc. Follow the linear path, watch the cutscenes. Please, give me gameplay already. Fortunately, after a short attempt to impress players with gee whiz cutscene action, it does start delivering the goods.

The gameplay mixes platforming, traversal (climbing and the like), combat of both the direct and stealth variety, puzzle solving, and exploration and discovery. There's a lot of good to be found in these elements.

Lara's jumping is fluid and fun to control. You can actually aim her jumps a little bit in mid-air, and her climbing is also quite fluid. She can double jump" up walls

column16: then hid. Another enemy examined the corpse
column17: and got a face full of poison gas for his trouble. Three enemies down
column18: still not spotted yet. I knew I was going to have to inevitably fight
column19: so I lit a fire arrow and ignited two enemies at once
column20: and that blew my cover. Well
column21: almost. The enemies started searching for me
column22: and I was able to surprise one more before everyone spotted me and it basically turned into a standard cover shooter at that point.\n\nOne problem
column23: as I see it
column24: is that there's too much open combat in the game that just takes place in linear areas. I think the game is at its best when you have many options at your disposal
column25: but sometimes
column26: you're just forced into standard shooty setpieces before you can move on.\n\nThe level design is a mixture of open areas
column27: and linear setpieces. Open areas are sometimes huge
column28: and loaded with things to do: characters to talk to (such as villagers or rebels in hiding)
column29: wild animals hanging around their turf
column30: caves to explore
column33: and your eventual goal that takes you to the next area. These areas are fantastic
column34: and I really wish there were more of them.\n\nThe pacing changes up a lot; sometimes you're progressing through a linear area and fighting through enemies
column35: then you have to climb and move through to the next area
column37: and eventually you're out in the open where you're hit with tons of things to do.\n\nSometimes
column39: the pacing doesn't quite work out. One area of the game had a village full of people preparing for a huge battle against invaders. There was a lot to do there
column40: and their upcoming battle was played up as if it was going to be epic. I was really excited about the idea of fighting enemies in such a massive
column43: caves and houses... but when it came time for the battle
column44: it was just a linear cover shooter segment. When it was all over
column45: the villagers were talking about the heavy losses they suffered over the past 10 minutes. I was left thinking
column46: "That's it?!" It could have been epic
column47: but it failed.\n\nYou'll encounter some brutally tough puzzles
column48: many of which are optional (the "challenge tombs")
column49: some of which are required to progress. They involve things like transporting an explosive to its destination
column50: moving a boat around a rapidly flowing river with the help of ropes and pulleys - some puzzles require timing
column51: while others don't.\n\nThe game provides hints in several ways
column52: such as music that changes depending on how close you are to solving the puzzle
column54: and the ability to "examine" things using "survival instincts" (which makes important and interactive things glow
column55: while also revealing objectives).\n\nThere's also tons of hidden secrets to find. The game outright alerts you to nearby "challenge tombs"
column56: with the sound of wind chimes playing when you're in their general area. The tombs are essentially multiple puzzles: first you have to find them
column57: then you have to enter them
column58: then you have to solve the puzzle inside. Successfully raiding the tombs earns you special abilities
column59: such as the ability to detect animals' hearts and kill them in one hit if you shoot them there (animals are very nasty and harder to kill than most humans
column60: so this helps a lot in encounters with them).\n\nYou can backtrack to find secrets and hidden things in locations you've been to before
column61: using your new abilities. Any campfire you've previously visited serves as a place to upgrade weapons and spend experience points (obtained via collecting items or killing in special ways) on skills
column62: as well as warp to any previously visited campfire
column63: so you can backtrack that way.\n\nThe skills you can obtain are things like the ability to turn gas cans into bombs
column64: the ability to craft certain kinds of new weapons (such as explosive arrows)
column65: and more. Some of these skills really open up your combat options
column66: and there are also special abilities that can be obtained only by completing challenge tombs.\n\nThat said
column67: this game has some things that hold it back quite a bit. A lot of the cover-based combat just feels
column69: mostly like it's just there for the sake of being there
column71: while stealth combat is a lot more fun but doesn't quite go on for as long as I'd like at times. There are scripted moments that are just really unnecessary
column72: but at least it's not as bad as the previous game when it comes to that (save for that awful beginning).\n\nAnd the ending feels rushed and generic. Lots of ghost-like enemies shooting at me with blue fire arrows that are just easier to kill and do way less damage than you'd expect. I felt like I didn't have much opportunity to do much creative fighting
column73: and it just felt like a waste of time. And the final area even goes for that annoying orange/blue color scheme Hollywood is obsessed with (Google it to see what I mean if you haven't noticed that trend already). Indeed
column74: rushed endings are a problem I've noticed in other games I've really enjoyed lately
column75: such as Axiom Verge and Life is Strange. It's like companies just feel the need to make their game end on a big note
column76: but don't know how to do it in a way that paces well.\n\nFinally
column77: and this is more of a mild complaint
column78: enemies can be total morons at times. At one point
column80: and there was a fire burning next to me. An enemy was walking towards my hiding spot
column81: about to turn the corner to where I was hiding
column82: and he walked right into the fire
column84: and died seconds later. I've seen other behavior that's not quite that stupid
column86: other than some issues with pacing and scripting
column87: overall I think this game is pretty good
column88: and a major improvement over Tomb Raider 2013. If you're looking for an adventure with a lot of different types of gameplay
column90: since I think the good outweighs the bad.\n\n(Finally
column91: ignore my number of hours on record. I tend to leave games running the entire time I do other things)"

reviewText:
This is such a great Tomb Raider game, now with over 1000% more tomb raiding than the 2013 reboot! :D

I was very happy with the 2013 reboot, and thought it was a pretty decent Tomb Raider game (though lacking in the tomb raiding) and a good reboot for the series (I also quite enjoyed the previous Anniversary, Legend, and Underworld). Well this one is even better. They improved on just about everything: the platforming, the combat, the graphics, the tombs, the story telling, everything. They even got rid of most of the annoying quick-time events and gratuitous death scenes.

It runs quite well; I only had to turn a few settings down or off (Hairworks, HBAO+) and I had playable framerates on my aging GeForce GTX880M at 1920x1080; they did tank into the 20s maybe twice in the game in some graphics intense situations, but never never during cutscenes or combat. PC controls work fine (I chose to play with KB/M; only tiny issue is a mislabeled button in the map tutorial: it says press space to mark an objective, but you actually have to press enter). All in all a good port (or perhaps a parallel development?).

Seriously, though, if you enjoyed Tomb Raider 2013 but felt it lacked in the tomb raiding department, then you'll want this game. Crystal Dynamics NAILED IT! :)

reviewText:
Pros
- Decent but very predictable plot.

Cons

- Really short game. Finished every tomb and crypt there is too.
- Even playing on second hardest difficulty, the enemy seems to be very easy to beat.
- Stupid AI
- Tombs are TOO EASY and most of the time underwhelming.
- I didn't like the shop aspect of it
- No multiplayer for longevity
- What are the cards even used for?

That said, I really enjoyed the game, just wished it was longer. I got it for £19 so I'm not complaining too much. Though if you're planning on getting for full price, the recommendation becomes a bit iffy.

TL;DR - Solid game, bad tombs and AI, predictable and short story - 7/10

reviewText:
This is a good sequel, I really enjoyed the premise. Especially the bits in Syria and early on in Serbia on the mountain felt really awesome, great introduction set pieces. The puzzles are a bit too simple honestly but I was fine with it as is.

My biggest gripe was how several times while far into the game I had to restart it. There are bugs here, nasty ones at that. Probably not everyone experience them but sometimes events weren't triggered, especially towards the end. The trebuchet stuff was downright frustrating, I had to restart the game several times. Not because of death mind you, simply because NPC's would be stuck inside walls and keep throwing stuff at you but you couldn't kill them. Or I couldn't remove debris that was in the way because it didn't get removed even though I was doing what I was supposed to do to progress. So really the last bit was really annoying for me. However these are bugs that will probably be fixed or may not occur for everyone. Though I really hated the trebuchet stuff in general, going back and fourth between these felt like pure filler to try and make the game longer.

As for the rest of the game, it's quite stunning and has an engaging story. Some pieces are quite cool, where you had three factions fighting each other at the end and you're just trying to make it across to the other side with things blowing up infront of you.

I must admit though I was expecting more, Rise of the Tomb Raider feels like the other Tomb Raider game from 2013. I guess more of the same is good?  But I would have liked to see them open up the world a bit more, I understand that is difficult.  Especially when there are events sometimes in tombs that block off areas as you progress.  It's not a big thing but the only time I really felt like I was exploring was when I found tombs scattered around the map for the side missions. These are done very well and I highly recommend doing these, most of the time they are a lot more engaging than the main mission stuff.

I'll end with that it's a solid sequel that needs some bug fixes and next time around maybe opening the world up more.

reviewText:
Completed this game in 22 hours. I guess it's a good gameplay time even I completed 75% of game (Skipped some tombs because of never ending curiosity what comes next).

You know, difference between Tomb Raider and Rise of Lara, In this game I never felt bored. I liked the world, I liked the mini-puzzles in tombs, I wanted to complete this game to see the final of this story. I like how emotional the beginning was, liked the introduction of characters, flashbacks, liked optimization from xbox (some games have such lame optimization @ start, = lags/fatals/etc). I liked everything.

For a fan, who completed all games (except the latest platformer Tomb of Osiris) from 1-st game to the last. I name this game one of the best if not the best game in the series.

Story was good, characters were emotional and I believed in their emotions, good work to voice actors and animation team. Music was well-fitted.

Only one thing made me sad.
When you had no arrows IT WAS HARD TO SHOOT ROPES sometimes (because of camera la. But, well, sometimes :D

Play on Survival Difficulty and have fun!
Can't wait for the next game.

reviewText:
RISE OF THE TOMB RAIDER EXECUTES THE FRANCHISE FORMULA WITH CONFIDENCE.

In many ways, Rise of the Tomb Raider could be viewed as a fairly modest sequel. It successfully builds off Crystal Dynamics' excellent reboot, but it doesn't introduce any massive changes; the scope is greater but still in spitting distance of the previous game. But successfully regaining the feeling created in an extremely good game is no small feat. This is the inauguration of Tomb Raider as a formula once more, but for now, it's a formula I'm happy revisiting.

9.5/10

reviewText:
rating: worth buying at sale price (<30€)
score: 7.5/10 - good
similar games: Uncharted, Prince of Persia
tags: exploration, puzzles, third person shooter

Almost everything has been improved compared to the Tomb Raider Reboot from 2013 ... except the story. The story of Tomb Raider 2013 was already REALLY bad and had nothing but forgettable characters. Rise of the Tomb Raider also has nothing but forgettable characters, the story is also really bad, but what ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off the most is how extremely serious this game is. There is NO humour AT ALL, even though the topics and the story of this game are extremely silly things.
Because of this the Uncharted series will always be better.
After the boring prologue I had a lot of fun with RotTR and I thought this might be a strong contender for GOTY, but the more I continued the more I got dissapointed and the terrible story just left me with a dissapointed feeling at the end. Still, the game has a lot of good things about it, which could easily make it a 9/10 just by have LESS story, because it is SO bad.
What I liked the most about this game is how much bigger the areas are, how much more encouraged you are to explore and how much more puzzles you can do. This also makes this game feel much more like the first generation of Tomb Raider games. Combat is also improved, but not by much. Unlike TR2013 though, you don't get thrown into a combat situation and then get attacked by waves of enemies. Here in most situations the enemies won't know that you are there, so you can always plan your attack first and go stealthy. Problem is that the game is so ♥♥♥♥ing easy even on the highest difficulty, actually it's simply broken. You get waay to much ammo and resources for everything which allows you to craft as much poison/fire/explosive arrows as you want, which are by far the most overpowered weapons in the game. With 1 poison arrow you can take down a group of the most armored enemies in the game. Not only that, but you will have millions of healing material, so you can always heal yourself in combat. Especially because of the level design there is always cover which you can use and quickly heal yourself. It gets even more ridiculous when you upgrade your healing ability, which they added because apparently it wasn't easy enough already. With the healing upgrade you can heal yourself almost instantly. I actually didn't die a single time in combat in this game on the highest difficulty. The combat was still fun, and the good thing is there wasn't THAT much combat as in TR2013.
What dissapointed me about the second half of the game is that there weren't these big hub areas anymore, where you can freely explore, do side missions and stuff like that. The second half was completely rushed and you were always attacked by enemies. I completed the game in 12 hours and I did almost all side missions and all tombs except one. 12 hours is really short.
Visually the game was really impressive, it had some really nice places, good variety and panoramas. But I had some frame drops in some places on my GTX 970 which was annoying (without AA, textures no high).

I think if the story and ending wasn't so bad, I wouldn't be left with such a dissapointed feeling and like the game much more. I don't recommend buying at full price, because the game is too short.

reviewText:
An excellent game that plays similar to, and produces the same level (perhaps even more) of enjoyment as the first game of the reboot.

The game suffers from some issues that in the grand scheme of things are relatively minor. Sometimes the story skips me ahead while I wasn't particularily done exploring an area and this can get irritating. The camera doesn't always cooperate (and sometimes removes your control to install a sense of amazement when you are nearing a cool structure), and I found that the controls sometimes don't do what I want. The DLC is a bit scummy. You don't really need (most of) it, and the game plays fine without.

With that said, those are the few critiques I have. Rise of the Tomb Raider is a step up from the previous installment and in general is really fun to play. The price point may be a bit steep at launch but I have confidence that it will go on sale for a 20-er within the year just like Tomb Raider 2013. If you didn't like Tomb Raider 2013, you probably won't like this one either.

reviewText:
A direct sequel to 2013's Tomb Raider reboot, Rise of the Tomb Raider looks to expand on everything Cystal Dynamics did with their last game. Although you'll need a powerhouse rig to run the game anywhere near 60+ fps on max settings, the game is visually gorgeous.
With my GTX 780 the game frequently fluctuated from a rare 30 fps to a more often 40-50 fps. Sunken city's and Icy cliff faces really come to life with astounding detail and the character models have also taken a step up with Lara sometimes being on the verge of photorealistic.
The gameplay remains much the same as the previous game with weapon upgrades complimenting the gunplay and some quite brutal melee finishing moves. This time around you can also craft weapons from bottles and cans left around the environenment to help in the game arena style battles with enemies.
My only gripe is that I didn't enjoy the story as much as the last game, and although the final sections ratchet up the action it still felt like a retread of the original games final section.
Other than that it's a great game but be wary about the games high requirements.

reviewText:
Couldn't See It....White Jesus.

If you played Tomb Raider 2013, you get the idea of what's to come in Rise of the Tomb Raider. Amazing scenery and dramatic playable cutscenes are abundant throughout the campaign, but never leave you feeling like the gameplay is bogged down or linear. Explosions and lascerations abound, and really make you feel the resilliance and determination of Lara Croft as she attempts to outwit her hostile surroundings.

The narative of Lara Croft, although at times a bit too emotional for a character that has long been a silent badass, leads well into the story of the games that would follow. This game is great as a standalone entity, or even coupled with it's 2013 predecessor, however for a real fan of the series it makes Lara feel far too soft and under-confident at times.

The combat is smooth, and the control scheme is seemlessly meshed into a few buttons, making the player feel the power of all the tools at ones disposal without an overcomplicated control scheme. It does not, however, do anything to improve or innovate on the standard 3rd person over the shoulder" shooter that we've come to know. In that sense it falls short of the rest of the overwhelming accomplishments this game makes

reviewText:
Disclaimer: My first Lara Croft game and thus the review is from a first timer perspective. Also, still only 25% into the game. Will update the review as I progress further if required.

Pros:
1. Beautiful graphics if your system can handle it, especially in areas without Sunlight (see first point under cons below).
2. A somewhat difficult game as it throws many enemies at you in spurts. Note that I am not used to shooting or FPS games so this might not be valid for you.
3. Interesting story line.
4. Tombs with nice puzzles.
5. Voice acting is nice but even though the setting is Siberian/Russian, voice acting is in English with what feels like American accent to my untrained ears.
6. The Skill tree seems interesting and it does not look like you will acquire everything by end game. So its a question of which" rather than "when" which is good.

Cons:
1. In areas with sunlight and shadows (parts of Soviet Installation in the early game)
date:
things are not optimized and actually the game doesn't look particularly good as well in those areas.
2. Few bugs which should be sorted in the first few patches.
3. A high end PC required as the game is graphically demanding and not exceptionally optimized.
4. The game gave me 0 credits for completing the first tomb instead of 10000 credits I should have earned. Actually
recommended: got a popup saying "Earned 0 credits" :). Nothing major but still no answer from technical support after multiple tries.\n\nFinal Verdict : 9/10. Recommended buy if your system can handle it."

reviewText:
http://fg-2.com/2016/02/11/review-rise-of-the-tomb-raider/

Two years after the release of the remake Tomb Raider, we finally get to see Lara Croft on her continued adventures in Rise of the Tomb Raider. The game is much like the first in that it is a 3rd person shooter with RPG and platforming elements in the gameplay. Not to much has changed between the the 2013 remake and this new one with the exception of a few new added gadgets. These gadgets whether it be the rope, fire or explosive arrows are unlocked over time to both further progress the story along with allow you to be able to go back through various parts of Siberia in order to do a full unlock of the game.

The platforming of the game is much better than the first remake in that there aren't any silly bugs that cause you to miss your jumps or camera angles that through your jumps off. They also toned down on the quick time events, allowing for more player interaction during the game itself instead of an interactive movie. Also a return was the on the fly crafting system that allows you to craft explosives and ammunition for various weapons much like that of Last of Us. It is a pretty simple system that doesn't require too much resources to craft. I never really ran out of any crafting materials except when I needed to upgrade my weapons and equipment. Those were a little more difficult to get however that said you could get most of them by just running around the maps and hunting the different animals and supply caches.

I would also like to mention though the gameplay was fun, it wasn't all that challenging, at least on the Tomb Raider difficulty. It might be a little more difficult on survivor mode but I can't see it being all that much more difficult as sneaking around, distracting your enemies with thrown bottles among other things made it incredibly easy to kill them and not get caught. But difficulty is never a requirement to make a game fun, as I said I enjoyed playing the game even though it might have only took me 23 hours to 100% it including all the hidden items.

One year after the events of Tomb Raider (2013), Lara is searching for answers for what happened on the island Yamatai and is looking to her father's research when she comes across what events pushed her father to the edge of “suicide”. She comes across him referencing the city of the Prophet, Kitezh and the Divine Source, some mystical artifact that supposedly gives those that find it immortal life. In pursuit of this artifact a secret organization of God called Trinity is also chasing it and killing all who oppose them or don't follow their beliefs. It ends up being a race to who can get to the Divine Source first. Overall the Story isn't anything special but the characters are interesting enough and it had enough to drive the game overall, making me want to find out more. What added a lot to the story, and I feel like a lot of people don't bother with it, is the various lore you find from the Mongolians that invaded the city first, the Greeks that followed after, the soviets that controlled Siberia looking for the city and Trinity themselves in their recorded messages. It was those subtle codex items that added a lot to the overall story and history behind Kitezh and the Prophet.

I want to touch on something that it seems like I constantly see people complaining about Lara being a killing machine and don't seem to understand what drove her to do that in both games. Since these are both reboots we won't talk about the fact that in the games before she was a killing machine, we'll just focus on these two new games as their own series. In the first game there was no mysterious force chasing Lara and her expedition team, they were already on the island, that said she was already starting to be broken emotionally from leading her team into the Dragon's Triangle and marooning them on a deadly island. Once she found out a force of mercenaries were capturing and killing her friends she saw it as time for vengeance especially after she was almost ♥♥♥♥♥ and killed herself before she killed her first person. You could even see her progression through the game where she accepted who she was and what she had to do to stop those that were there to harm her and her friends. All that even led to this pretty often screen capped photo in game where, in my opinion, shows that she has lost what made her human.

In the new game it is much the same but this time she knows what Trinity is after and knows that they were the one that defamed her father that led to his death. On top of that she meets a new group of people that have lived near and defended the city of Kitezh for thousands of years. A people that she wanted to protect from Trinity. Lara may have a murderous tendency but it isn't without reason. Some would argue that she should be more likely to sneak around and avoid killing and Nathan Drake (of the Uncharted series) is more prone to killing. I disagree with that and argue that it is the complete opposite. A lot of times Drake has no reason to kill, he is a thief that doesn't really have a play in most of these enemy forces, he just happens upon them. I will take the exception of Uncharted 2 where they attack the villagers in Nepal but that wasn't until ¾ through the game.

This game is one of the most beautiful games I've seen, from the scenery all the way up to the particle physics and  facial animations. Crystal Dynamics did a fantastic job of making every little detail pop out and all while having it run great (at least on my PC, I've heard of others having problems but I didn't – 5820k, 780ti, 16g ddr4). I really noticed when Lara or other characters had looks on their faces, so the voice actors didn't have to sell the emotions as much, you could definitely see them. There are so many great screenshot moments in this game I don't really want to bombard you with all the pics I took while playing but to say the least some of the most talented screenshot takers are taking some of the most amazing photos (I have one friend that is very talented at this, but if any of y'all have some impressive photos feel free to put them in the comments below, I'd love to see them).

On to the sound too, the music really sets the tone and has a similar composition of the 2013 remake which was great in its own right but makes this game really feel like a continuation of a series. The voice actors are also really on their game and make the characters believable especially since a lot of game developers use motion cameras to capture even the voice actors as they are playing the role.

Overall this game is fantastic continuation from the reboot that started in 2013, though I did 100% it in about 23 hours there is a lot of other content including endurance, score attack and if you decide to spend the money the DLC that is coming with season pass. Maybe not as much of a replay-ability as say an MMO or giant RPGs but definitely a great bang for your buck especially if you can find a sale for it at $40 like I did. The Graphics, Gameplay, Story and sound are all top notch with the only blemish might be not as strong story as some others but still very solid.

Story – 8
Gameplay – 8
Graphics – 10
Sound – 10
Fun – 9
Replay Value - 6

reviewText:
After 11 hours of gameplay, I finished the main story.

The first minutes inside the game are fantastic. You have a breathtaking graphic, insanely fluid movements, wonderful voiced characters and of course the cutest and sexiest girl in the gaming world: Lara Croft.

The game is linear, even tho you are kinda allowed to roam around and do stuff, you basically wanna follow the red string of the story. You will occasionally encounter some special hidden quests which are fun to do and give you a good reward. You solve everything in typical Lara Croft style, climbing walls and jumping off roofs. And all of that doesnt only ♥♥♥♥ing feel awesome, it also looks awesome.

Your character can level up, and you can invest points per Level into abilities, which are divided into 3 main groups. It allows you to customize the way you wanna finish the game. Do you prefer shooting around, stealthing around or building traps? It's all up to you.
Your Weapons can also be upgraded, in the same way as your character.

I really enjoyed it. Maybe because I have a huge thing for British girls. Or, and thats what I think, because this game just combines some of the core elements of some good games and brings us a wonderful next gen Lara Croft!

reviewText:
If you spoke to me when I was a kid and told me that one day there would be Tomb Raider games where Lara Croft didn't use her iconic dual Desert Eagles but she instead swapped them for a Bow, I would shun you and probably throw a tantrum.
But here I am in 2016, having just finished the second game and I am beyond amazed. This game takes the best aspects from the last game and adds things we all missed from the original games... RAIDING TOMBS!

PROS
-Great Graphics
-Amazing gameplay. Especially the crafting system when in combat
-Pretty solid story that keeps you intrigued
-You can finish the entire game with the Bow. The weapons found later on in the story were not automatically superior

CONS
-Constant hunting in areas for things like coins or strongboxes tends to get boring
-Combat was never really challanging. Bears were more of a challange than 10 or more Trinity Soldiers
-Framerate drops in movies (under 20fps for me in some places)

As a Tomb Raider fan since I was just out of nappies, who started his first Tomb Raider experience by being allowed to sit on my brothers lap and press the space bar to draw Lara's weapons when she needed to them, I Definitely think this game is a game worthy of the Tomb Raider name and any one who is a fan of the originals or just the newer ones should give it a playthrough.

OVERALL SCORE 9/10

reviewText:
Did you like the first reboot? Well, this is more of the same - or rather more of the good things of the reboot. Less QTE's, more tombs and caves and exploration. Still some silly problems with bining keys to mouse on PC. It shows to press the [] button for various actions, but if you have two thumbbuttons used - you won't know which ones until you tried - and most likely died a few times.

The story is slightly tighter this time around, more focused - and that is both good and bad. If you're a completionist than it will feel like you leave people to die to be able to go off the beaten path to explore and find treasure. You also have to leave certain tombs and treasures behind since you will lack certain gear and features that you lock up later on in the story line.

The expeditions are fun DLC and really should come in more flavours since this is what most will be doing after they beat the game - or well only be doing since this is the real challenge.

The game has some technical flaws and hickups. There is a hguge FPS drop in expeditions that occurs with a few minutes regualr intervention that makes it feel like something is going on that shouldn't be happening. The single player part runs with most things on on my spec flawlessly. I don't use occular and lens flaires and depth of field - but other than that - I have most things on except the hair. And I have a steady 80-110 FPS regardless of fights in firelit places.
Gameplay issues range from minor nitpicks as to how the camera works and you have little control meaning that forward moves your character sideways end vice versa in some parts of the game. Sometimes you can't see where you are going, meaning that you have to die to your death hoping you are on the right track and then redo some climbing/jumping routines - I had rather seen more difficult pathfinding as an obstacle than the camera itself as your biggest problem.

Hopefully coming patches will make the expeditions better optimized since that is really something nice - oh and that's were most of your pre-order and DLC extras will come into play.

The card system is to beef out and tweak your expeditions adventures.

EDIT notes: after finishing the game and Baba Yaga DLC.
So, the game is ended and for that I have to give cred. I don't finish all my games but this one I did. The game gets slightly tedious at the end, trying to sweep the areas looking for missing documents, loot and item chests. But all in all - a nice game. Baba Yaga wasn't a hit though - if you think you're missing out due to this one - rest easy - it is not worth the time. I got a bit disapointed here with the season pass so far. Hopefully something that adds to replayability will come out because I have no intention of playing this again on other difficulties etc. In the end, you do get more of the tedious fights from the first game. This time around it is easier to either sneak past - or have some cat and mouse game out of the fights - but still, a few too many to my liking.

reviewText:
What is Rise Of The Tomb Raider? Well, it’s a drama riddled glitché-fest episoode of CSI Miami  featuring Oprah Croft – a little girl with daddy issues.

Square Enix has done something right though. You can now disable any aiding feature of the game which turns it into quite a challenge which I enjoyed very much.

Visually the game is a stunning journey through variations of scenery and side-quests and raidable tombs never felt repetitive. Latter I can’t say for the story though.

Overall go ahead and buy this game – it’s a very good game. If you expect a Tomb Raider game though then you will be disapointed.

reviewText:
The reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise in 2013 was met with pretty much universal acclaim from critics and general users alike. It was a fresh take on the series which really focussed on Lara’s origins and gave her a very real personality. The gameplay was overhauled too, and the story was intriguing to follow. So it was a very tough act to follow.

I was hyped about this sequel, and will open this review by saying I felt Rise of the Tomb Raider lived up to this hype. If I may be so bold, I may even go so far as to say I enjoyed ROTTR more than Tomb Raider (2013).

So ROTTR takes off after the previous game and explores the circumstances surround the death of Lara’s father. The overarching story is about Lara’s quest for the key to immortality and involved exploring, or ahem, raiding ruins in the Middle East and Russia.

I felt the story had more depth to it in ROTTR. It felt grander, bigger and just more of a journey. Core elements of the game from the previous game had been conserved, though I felt there was a greater emphasis on crafting in ROTTR. Difficulty wise, they’re both about the same. I enjoyed the additions to gear that provided new ways to traverse terrain in this game. I felt they added to the skill level required with the game as one is mixing up different button combinations.

Visually, ROTTR was gorgeous. Perhaps. one of the better looking games of it’s generation, and  this is to be expected as we could say the same for Tomb Raider (2013). I think what the dev team did with this is take what made the previous game so successful and just add to it.

My big gripe at this point in time is with optimisation. At my first playthrough, before writing this review, My system was running Crossfired R9 290X, i7 4790k, 16GB RAM, game installed to SSD, and my frame rates weren’t particularly at amazing playing on high (though not Very high) settings at 1440p. I understand this is an NVIDIA title so perhaps that has something to do with it. At the time of writing, AMD is yet to push out it’s optimisation driver for this game so perhaps that has something to do with it. The open world regions would drop my frame rates to about the 30FPS mark, but most other regions seemed to hang around 50-60FPS mark, so a mixed bag overall. It wasn’t unplayable by any means, and the gameplay and story were enough to keep me going, but I expected better.

However, ROTTR has strengths in most other categories. There’s a great mix of fast paced action and slow paced head scratching puzzles, which really contributes to the scope of this game. The combat is good, standard third person shooter tactics. The bow is an excellent weapon which is utilised well in the game, both for combat and navigation. The stealth combat was one of my favourite aspects. A lot of emphasis is put on this, and I felt it was mostly well executed. I especially enjoyed the inclusion of water based stealth kills, as well as death from above and just general sneaking behind an enemy to kill them. Really good.

The world building was top notch. Exploring the lore, through artefacts and journals really added to the story and the settings were beautifully designed. I am a fan of how it was not homogenous at all, with a good variety of settings and colours. One part of the game you’re exploring sandy Syria, later you’re in the snowy tundra of Siberia, and then you explore caves, ruins, mountains.

Audio is fine. Ambient sounds were appropriate, voice acting was as you would expect from a modern AAA title. Controls were fine, I played with Keyboard/mouse. There was the odd time when I experienced some lag in controls, but I put that down to the same issues as frame rate as discussed earlier. But it wasn’t game breaking.

Overall, some irksome optimisation issues for AMD users, but a good story, lovely to look at and just fun, engaging gameplay. ROTTR took the successes from it’s predecessor and for the most part expanded on them. Recommended.

reviewText:
There are many reasons to play this game, its been ported really well and maintains the same interesting gameplay from the reboot. It's still quite linear though and the optional challenge tombs aren't really all that challenging. Still I think this kind of gameplay in a high profile title is definitely a good thing.

The story isn't very strong though, and doesn't seem to develop Lara's character at all in regards to how much of a change the original reboot was. There are some semi-decent scenes involving her relationship with her father but I can't help but think the narrative is a bit of a step backward.

Overall it's really worth 15-20 hours of your time, especially if you played the original reboot.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is an action adventure game developed by Crystal Dynamics and the sequel to Tomb Raider.

Some time after the events of Tomb Raider, Lara Croft turns to her late father's research in an attempt to find the mythical city of Kitezh. Unfortunately for her, the Trinity organization is also in its tracks. While the reboot established her origins, this time her character is being more developed and fleshed out. The game takes place in Syria, and for the most part in Siberia. While the plot feels a bit formulaic, I still greatly enjoyed it.

The overall structure is pretty similar to the previous installment, but with some clear improvements. This time, hunting actually makes sense, as you need specific resources to craft certain consumables, gadgets and ammunition. Combat received a few notorious changes as well, with the ability to clear entire areas stealthily, which can break the monotony and add some tension. There are also more tombs to explore, with them being generally more expansive, but still entirely optional.

Otherwise, you still level up, gaining skill points to invest in three distinct categories, and are able to craft weapon upgrades. While not really open world, there are large hubs, where you have plenty to explore, do side quests and complete challenges. The platforming sections are similar and still satisfying, but with a few new gadgets to spice things up.

The graphics are very impressive, with the Siberian landscapes being particularly good, in par with the voice acting, which is outstanding. The multiplayer has been dropped, which I personally don't mind, as it was pretty generic. In its place, there is an expedition mode, where you can replay chapters in different game modes, such as time attack. You can also use cards, which will affect gameplay in these modes. While not extremely good, I find the expeditions to be a nice addition.

If you disliked Tomb Raider, you should probably give this one a miss, as it's fairly similar. On the other hand, if you enjoyed it, you should definitely give Rise of the Tomb Raider a try.

reviewText: the ''sequel'' to Tomb Raider 2013 ( because this is Lara's first tomb raid, so not exactly a sequel but... ) is as good or even better than Tomb Raider 2013. The gameplay is relatively the same, which is not a bad thing since it already was really great, and in ROTTR they've added new movements and abilities to this already great gameplay. Graphics wise.... it's jaw-dropping, this game looks so good ( maxed out atleist ), it's the best graphics i've ever seen in a video game and it runs great ( apart from the texture quality settings, if you have anything less than 4 Gb of VRam, don't bother going ''very high'' you'll stutter ) and there's a lot of options here as well. Story now, it's great. I mean, it's Lara's first Tomb, following her dad's footsteps and showing her determination... it's just really well made. My only complain is the game's length, being really short. i was expecting it to be atleist a little longer than Tomb Raider 2013, but both games took me exactly 10 hours each to beat on ''Tomb Raider'' difficulty ( normal i guess ), which is a little sad to be honest... But hey, it's not the end of the world, replayability is there, though i don't think it's really something that i'll do. Great game, definitly buy it if you've played the 2013, or even if it's your first TR game.

reviewText:
Rise of the Tomb Raider is another step in the right direction for Lara Croft since the series nadir - The Angel of Darkness. This game takes the formula set by the previous game and adds a few flourishes but ultimately plays out the same.
Graphically one of the best looking games ive seen its a visual treat to see Lara running and exploring her way across forgotten corners of Syria, and later Russia.
The level design is great with huge open areas with multiple routes to reach a goal, and often side quests can be obtained to further reward additional backtracking/exploration.
Story wise, its a solid entry - Lara is searching for an artifact that is rumoured to grant immortality with a shadowy cult also trying to get the artifact for more nefarious reasons .
The gameplay is solid, and the levelling up process straight forward. Crafting gets more of a heads up this time round and parts need to be collected and created in order to make new weapons and ammo to further assist Lara on her journey.
If you enjoyed the last Lara Croft outing this will also appeal but ne thing the game developers need to get their heads around is the fact that Lara Croft is known for raiding Tombs and very little of that happens in this game and indeed the last game. You could swap Lara out for Nathan Drake and call this Uncharted and noone would question it as they are both now very similar games. Get Lara back to raiding Tombs!!!!

reviewText:
I was almost convinced: this is one of the few games that I like to give a 10.
But then the end happened.

Rise of the Tomb Raider(Rise for short) has Lara follow the same path she followed in the 2013 reboot. She gets dumped in a wilderness with nothing more than a makeshift bow to start out with. With meager resources you help her survive cold and hunger and make her way forward for the sake of curiosity and redemption. For those are Lara's primary motivations: to discover secrets out there that can benefit the world. (Lara actually has the well being of humanity on her mind: make a note of that) and to redeem her disgraced father who was bold enough to assert that there was a thing out there that gave life eternal. And the scientists, being the jerks they are, banned him for it, cause that is the way the coven of scientists operates of course: if you are not for us, you are against us. Disgraced, father Croft killed himself. Or so we are told.

So Lara sets out to vindicate her father, and her own name, by finding that divine source located in a lost city in the outback. This time around her boots take us to Siberia, after a little detour to Syria for the trail she follows starts with a prophet who preached his brand of Christianity in those regions around the 10th century AD in a country people nowadays mostly recall for the headlines: it is that place where everyone is fighting and bombing everyone because of reasons..

Now it is time for the Illuminati to step in, but since that trope has been beaten to death far too often(for instance in the movie Lara Croft: Tomb Raider) they renamed the nefarious organisation to Trinity and make them out to be a band of religious fanatics, of the christian kind to be on the safe side.

The evil boss is a guy named Konstantin who does evil because of reasons. Embrace the suffering
date:
he whispers to one of his minions who has failed him while he pushes his fingers into his victims eye sockets. He is the brother of Ana, who is Lara's stepmother. Since we all know how stepmothers are we  also know that it is just a matter of time before the proverbial poisonous apple surfaces and the hunter will be sent after the princess.. eh Lara..: treason.And so the story proceeds along a beaten track..

The real gem in the game is Lara herself. She is so well done and so believable that you suffer through the story just to see what she will do next, what she will discover next and how she will develop next. You get to steer Lara through the world, unearthing treasure, solving puzzles, seeing marvelous sights, stalking wildlife and humans alike. And the game underscores this all with good music most of the time.

But then, in the end, the makers of this game get a brain seizure and trample over Lara's personality and motivations. They make her conclude that some things are not meant for humanity and have her reject to benefit mankind or to redeem her father's reputation.
Why?
Because of reasons.
There could have been many reasons to destroy the big secret but now Lara is set up as judge and jury over mankind. 'Humans are not meant to live forever, ' she says suddenly. How she got from unearthing secrets to benefit mankind" to "it is not meant for mankind" is not developed. It just happens. Like you wind vane she suddenly twists around when the wind changes.
This is called poor writing: having a character make a decision in the end that is at odds to her starting opinion and which isn't worked towards in the story line.This is the deus ex machina of decision making.
But there is more.
In the epilogue yet another another u-turn is made for we are blatantly told next that discovering stuff for the benefit of humanity is what motivates Lara. Hold on. Did she not just destroy something that would benefit mankind because she was of the opinion that it wasn't meant for it mankind? How did she get from a to b and then back from b to a?

This flip flopping of Lara's personality takes the whole experience down several notches for the end apparently did nothing to her personality. In other words: she went through some kind of personality change instantly and reverted back instantly.

My 10 thus dropped to a 7. It is a captivating game
recommended: but has a seriously broken character development. And the latter is something mankind can do without."
hoursPlayed: April 11

reviewText:
What can I say? I got this game for free with my graphics card, and hoping that they would have improved on TR2013 I decided to play it to see if they made any improvements to the reboot (instead of giving the code to someone that acutally wanted to play the game), but there was nothing new to be found. It felt like it could very well have been an expansion pack to the original TR2013. The shooting is still bad. The guns still sound like BB guns, and the controls are as bad and unresponsive as they were in TR2013. I can not comment too much on the story since I only played three hours of it, but what I got was boring and not very original. The one improvement I found was that they had cut down on the QTE's, but they still used them to much for my taste.

Graphics wise the game is great. Nothing more to say really. The game went for a photo-realistic look instead of having an unique artsyle, which means the game will look old in an year or two. I always prefer when a game chooses to have a nice artstyle instead of going for photo-realistic graphics, since games that have a nice artstyle age way better. Just look at Wind waker. That game still looks great to this day.

And tombs. Tombs where boring. I got trough two of them before I decided to uninstall the game, and they were both way too easy. The game holds your hand way too much. If you are presented with even the simplest of puzzles, the game will have Lara comment on what she needs to do to solve it, which completely ruins the whole point of having a puzzle. This segment will represent the process of getting trough a tomb in this game:

''Hmm, I wonder what I need to do to get past this part?'' I wondered as I was presented with a puzzle.

''Why not do that and then that to solve it?'' Lara then said and the puzzle had solved itself for me.

I hate when games treat their players as if they are two years old, and this game does it exceptionally well.

This is very subjective, but I don't Laras' voice actor. I don't know what it is, but I find it unbearable to listen to her for more than 5 seconds at a time.

If you liked the original TR2013, you will like this. But if you did not, you should pass on this glorified expansion.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A game with almost as much of a collect a thon as your avid Ubisoft game. It feels like half the game time, if you were to do everything, is just boring side stuff. The Tombs are still only optional and not part of the story, geez. It's called Tomb Raider. The graphics looks good, but the game is horribly optimized. The cutscenes are stepping way too deep into the uncanny valley and the dialogs are horrible. The voice acting and directing for Lara is so cringy and just out right bad. Her characters is anything but likeable aswell. The gun/bow play is improved and you now have a crafting system, TLOU-style but much faster. It speeds up the killing and it all feels a bit to easy. As before everything is made of graham crackers and kids glue and gets destroyed just from having Lara lookt at it.

I only recommend this game if you have a beast of a computer (980Ti or better) or can settle with capping at 30fps. Still, look up vids about how well your system would do. Because damn, this game is dropping framerate all over the place in big areas. About the price. I feel like spending 45 bucks, which I did, was way too much for this experience. I'd say wait til winter 2016 and buy it sub 20 bucks.

Cheers!

reviewText:
I would like to give this a 9/10 but I just can't.  I would have to give it 7/10 but would still recommend it.  I had lots of fun playing it, but the more I played the more glaring issues came to light.  While they aren't game breaking they are there.

Pros:

-Graphics are amazing
-polished gameplay
-great voice acting

Neutral:
-Story is a typical tomb raider.  While interesting it is sort of underwhelming.  The villains are very well done and well acted but I have issues with Lara's motivations which make no sense at some points and ridiculously selfish.  The twist with one of the charaters is seen hours before it is revealed.

Cons:
- Way to easy.  I played on the second hardest difficulty and Lara is a roiling death machine.  While fun every now and then I breezed through the campaign.  The only time I really died was my own fault when I missed a jump or screwed up a quick time event.
- The last act of the game is very similar to the final act of the first game.  Both involve fights on very similar arenas and levels.  A force of undead that sound very similar even while speaking different languages.  A long climb up a fortress.

All in all I would still recommend but I don't agree with other online reviews that gave it stellar reviews.

reviewText:
As a long-time fan of the Tomb Raider series, I really enjoyed playing this installment! The new gameplay and item additions are fun to utilise, the main problem is experiencing glitches when climbing or trying to interact with certain items but these aren't game-breaking - just frustrating! The controls are otherwise simple.

The game does, however, feel super long. Compared to Tomb Raider 2013, there seems to be a lot more to do in regards to challenges, things to collect, optional missions etc, so the 100% can be tedious to some. I liked the story, but it does seem to feel less 'Tomb Raider-y' than its predecessor, built largely around conflict and not exploration. The 'evil organisation mercenary group' enemy also feels recycled from the last game.

I also recommend the Endurance DLC if you like the survival-type tactics for a quick game, the score attack replays are also nice as they give you new objectives to complete - some extra stuff to play until the next game!

Overall, great game. My only complaint is 'what happened to Lara's face?' ;.;

reviewText:
A bigger, better, beautiful sequel

+Interconnected areas and large hub locations offer hidden loot, tombs, wildlife, and enemy patrols.
+Expanded crafting system: new special arrow tips, bombs, visible gear mods, and craftable outfits
+A boatload of optional outfits
+Larger arsenal: weapons have varying stats and benefits
+Increased offensive options: death from above, silent knife take downs, improvised explosions
+Tombs have impoved greatly in both art and design
+Beautiful art direction throughout
+Dialouge/script improved a bit

+/- Less story focus
+/- New Lara is still actually Rambo

-Puzzles are still easy
-Story is still drab
-Mess of collectables

The three DLC pieces are overpriced, wait for deep discounts if you're interested.

reviewText:
I haven't finished the game yet, but I played through Tomb Raider in a weekend and loved it to death. The only problem I had with that game was that it gave the impression of survival, while also wanting to be a high adrealine action game - so in the early game, it was survival, then it quickly ramped up to action movie.

This game has the same problem - however I can look past it because we have already been through the first game, So Lara should be, as is a bit more hardened.

So - gameplay. What do I think? Well I honestly think that this game improves upon everything that Tomb Raider had. You now get to be sneaky in most combat situations, so you feel a bit more free in how you approach things. The optional dungeons are massive - and it generarily feels a lot more like a Tomb Raider experience.
The story feels  a bit dull - not exactly amazing. I really enjoy the whole Language" thing - "You can't read this until you've learned more about the language".. Nice to see language play a role in a game.

My only downside really so far is that you can't change up the difficulty
date: at least not from Seasoned raider (the second hardest) to survival. Which is dumb; So if you're uncertain
recommended: start the game in the highest diffuclty
hoursPlayed: and then go down if it's too hard."

reviewText:
It's good! The graphics, moving foliage, lighting is great.

Few complaints, however:

1. Main campaign is a bit short. I feel like it could've been longer, I finished in 10 hrs of gameplay.
2. Lara's face change. I mean, come on. TR 2013's face was so much better. I don't like the new round-face Lara one bit.
3. Instead of $70, I would recommend to pay $40. For the short storyline, $70 is a bit steep.
4. AMD's TressFX in TR 2013 is a lot better than HairWorks in this one. A lot more of a resource hog is HairWorks.
5. The story, no matter how long it is, is a little cliched. We've seen it all before.
6. The best parts of the game is post-campaign when you're trying to 100% it.

Anyway, I recommend this game. I'm on my way to 100%ing it. Should be fun.

- Matt

reviewText:
I would like to give this a 9/10 but I just can't.  I would have to give it 7/10 but would still recommend it.  I had lots of fun playing it, but the more I played the more glaring issues came to light.  While they aren't game breaking they are there.

Pros:

-Graphics are amazing
-polished gameplay
-great voice acting

Neutral:
-Story is a typical tomb raider.  While interesting it is sort of underwhelming.  The villains are very well done and well acted but I have issues with Lara's motivations which make no sense at some points and ridiculously selfish.  The twist with one of the charaters is seen hours before it is revealed.

Cons:
- Way to easy.  I played on the second hardest difficulty and Lara is a roiling death machine.  While fun every now and then I breezed through the campaign.  The only time I really died was my own fault when I missed a jump or screwed up a quick time event.
- The last act of the game is very similar to the final act of the first game.  Both involve fights on very similar arenas and levels.  A force of undead that sound very similar even while speaking different languages.  A long climb up a fortress.

All in all I would still recommend but I don't agree with other online reviews that gave it stellar reviews.

reviewText:
As a long-time fan of the Tomb Raider series, I really enjoyed playing this installment! The new gameplay and item additions are fun to utilise, the main problem is experiencing glitches when climbing or trying to interact with certain items but these aren't game-breaking - just frustrating! The controls are otherwise simple.

The game does, however, feel super long. Compared to Tomb Raider 2013, there seems to be a lot more to do in regards to challenges, things to collect, optional missions etc, so the 100% can be tedious to some. I liked the story, but it does seem to feel less 'Tomb Raider-y' than its predecessor, built largely around conflict and not exploration. The 'evil organisation mercenary group' enemy also feels recycled from the last game.

I also recommend the Endurance DLC if you like the survival-type tactics for a quick game, the score attack replays are also nice as they give you new objectives to complete - some extra stuff to play until the next game!

Overall, great game. My only complaint is 'what happened to Lara's face?' ;.;

reviewText:
A bigger, better, beautiful sequel

+Interconnected areas and large hub locations offer hidden loot, tombs, wildlife, and enemy patrols.
+Expanded crafting system: new special arrow tips, bombs, visible gear mods, and craftable outfits

+Larger arsenal: weapons have varying stats and benefits
+Increased offensive options: death from above, silent knife take downs, improvised explosions
+Tombs have impoved greatly in both art and design
+Beautiful art direction throughout
+Dialouge/script improved a bit

+/- Less story focus
+/- New Lara is still actually Rambo

-Puzzles are still easy
-Story is still drab
-Mess of collectables

The three DLC pieces are overpriced, wait for deep discounts if you're interested.
